reviews.review: Ever wondered where Salt comes from?. The salt mines were started in Inca times and the same methods of collecting the salt are used hundreds of years later. Excellent place to visit

Simply amazing!. I did a hike from Urubamba to the Maras Salt pit and I have to say that it's one of my best memory of my trip there. I went there with a local community initiative called Media Luna and I was impressed by my guide! An old men but with all the energy brought us up there and gave us tons of information! I strongly recommend a visit to Maras, it's definitly worthed. If you'd like to have info for the community just send me a message :)

Ojo con las lluvias . Amazing place! You can find the finest salt ever produced in the world in here.. a kilo bag will cost you 5 soles=1.50 usd!!Just beware of the weather... rain won't ruin your excursion but it will make it pretty muddy
Great day out of the city. Booked it together with maras and another place. The salinas were without a doubt tbe highlight of the day.

Amazing place!. The day we visited here it was raining but it was still a fascinating experience. I wouldn't recommend taking small or over exuberant children on a wet day as the paths are very narrow in places. Remember to dip your hand in the spring that feeds the salt pans. It is so warm that you could take a bath in it. Almost as salty as the Dead Sea! It gets very busy and sometimes tricky to pass people coming in the opposite direction.Not suitable for those with restricted mobility.

Great Day trip with nearby Moray Inca Site. The Maras salt mines are very cool and photos to not do justice to the scale of the site!Approx 45min-1hr from CuscoWe did the Maras Salt Mines as part of a day trip tour which included the nearby Inca ruins at Moray.
IMPRESSIVE. ..a bit out of your way, but these are the only "salinas" that aren't under ground... Take a moment to lear the system they use to take salt out of this incredible place

Incredible. It's amazing how much bigger it has gotten. It's a must if you are in Cusco, you can buy different types of salt, pink salt, medicinal, medicinal mixed with herbs you name it and taste the salted chocolate !

Pink salt discovery. This is an amazing venue to see; I would certainly not want to work there. I have great empathy for the Peruvians who climb up and down these slopes to extract the pink salt the evaporating pools produce.

Nice view. This place is really cool, it is not so far from the city, but you will have a nice view from where you are, try to go in the afternoon cause in the morning is too busy some times. Enjoy it!

Amazing. This is an incredible sight and when you think that this started in Inca times, some 400 years or so ago and is still owned and run - mostly by hand - by a large number of families I think it is amazing. Go and see how all that trendy Peruvian pink salt that you buy is harvested and buy some. It is also very cheap to enter (S/ 10).

Amazing use of the land by native Peruvians . We rolled up here as part of a guided day tour and it was an unexpected pleasure. Due to the rain it was very muddy to walk around but that was pretty standard in the Sacred Valley at this time of year, the salt pools themselves were an amazing patchwork of terraces on the valley side, well worth a visit if you are in the Sacred Valley area

So photogenic, so historical, a wonderful site!. The tiny stream tastes salty. It fills the numerous terrasses with salty water which will evaporate into first class Andean salt. You see the local workers harvesting the salt, the salt bags, the finished products of many gift items.
INCREDIBLE. The salt mines are absolutely incredible. Unlike anything I'd ever seen before. I went on 4 wheelers and it was a blast! HIGHLY RECOMMEND
Salt mines. This place is amazing showing how the locals make there own salt. There are hundreds of individual areas that are owned by each family

Amazing place in the middle of the mountains. This places looks magical between the mountains. The terraces with salty water that evaporates and let the salt crystals form changes the landscape. Not for people that cannot climb stairs, since there are a lot of stairs to go down and the to climb up.

Salinas de Maras - quick trip. We booked a private taxi to take us here and to the Sacred Valley before heading to the airport in the afternoon. The salt mines are beautiful and looks like nothing I have ever seen before. We didn't spend too much time here because were on a tight schedule but after taking photos and our taxi/"guide" explaining the salt flats we were on our way. Definitely something you shouldn't miss, it really is more beautiful to see in person

Striking!. Awesome! Fascinating and a must visit! Only 10S. Taxi man pulled over for scenic view first and it was striking! Get to go into (along the top) the salt flats which is cool. My recommendation is stick your hand in the stream, let it dry and boom.....you have a thick encrusted white salty hand! ;)
Marvellous spectacle . This is a must see if you have time while in cusco or passing through, a marvellous spectacle of engineering working hand in hand with mother nature (Pachamama)

Was I wrong in thinking I might pass on this one.......... This was really Great. I enjoyed the whole part, not only the lovely drive but the salt flats alone and how they began and to exist today, is amazing.The families continue to work and service these salt flats everyday. They are very valuable and the families just do not give them up. It settles in a very lovely valley off the Sacred Valley and should not be missed. Yes you need a guide, just to learn all there is here, and you can hire one at the entrance again. What we like doing is just hiring a driver for the day, that will cost you about $75.-85. Then also hire an English speaking guide or whatever language you want, that will be about $100. with the tip.But gosh do you get to see and know everything. Stop for a lite lunch where they know it's safe to eat, and take you to the markets for a little shopping of Alpaca of course, and then back to the Hotel. We were gone about 6-7 hours and it came in under $200. per day. We did this in the Sacred Valley for 2 days and saw most of it. Then just hiked or took taxisfor anything in between. I recommend 4 days in the Valley to see and experience it all. I would stay in Ollyantaytamo, we just enjoyed that village sooooo much.
Great tour!. This tour is surprising, great view... It is interesting to go in a guided tour so you can hear the history.

Cool place!. This place was very cool! It is a little ways from Cusco but you can stop at other interesting sites along the way to complete a full days worth of touring. The salt here is harvested by hand, the old fashioned way. There are plenty of stores to purchase salt and salt products there on site. No entry fees.

Amazing. Seeing how the Incas and the people even earlier then them developed this salt at 12,000 feet above sea level is an tremendous insight into the brilliance of these people. If you look carefully as you are walking around, you will find sea shells, as this area was under the ocean millions of years ago.

Peru Excursion with Active Adventures . I actually visited in June of 2015. We hiked into the town. The people were very warm and inviting. Most of the income in the town is generated by the sale of the salt that is collected by the residents. While we were waiting for our other travelers in our group we watched a woman gathering salt from her pond allotment. Amazing.
interesting. Wonderful to see the work they do in this place, the view is very nice and very friendly, very interesting people like the locals

Impressive but not worth a special trip. The best part about this visit is the actual drive out of cusco which is stunning mountains especially with the blue skies and clouds. The salt pans were interesting but we didn't bother spending much time here. I suspect the best time is in the morning when the sun shines on them. The afternoon is somewhat disappointing. Great to include if you have a day trip to moray and other sites.

So cool to see. This is a really neat place. There are over 4,000 pools for drying salt. You can watch people working in their family's pool, raking and shoveling the salt. There are merchants selling salt, snacks, and other souvenirs. You need the Boleto Turistico to get in. It sounds weird to go visit salt pans, but it's worth it.

Really interesting site!. The salt pans have a really interesting history and were fun to visit. It is a bit of a hike down to the area, but not too hard for the average person. You can choose to hike even farther to the river valley. I would definitely recommend going to this site.

Very interesting!. One of my favorite places in the Sacred Valley. Beautiful drive there, and the salt pools were interesting and uniquely beautiful. I liked that the community handles it in a cooperative manner. It was not overly commercialized, though of course there were plenty of tourists there.
Great and must see. A must see, but very crowded, bus was worth the visit. Combined with Moray during a private Mountain Biking Tour.
wonderful. Hundreds of pools of salt to decant white color give an amazing look to the landscape of hills of Maras sector.
Enthralling!. Magical & not too far away from Cusco. Can be one of the places to visit when you reach Cusco ( due to the city's high altitude) as it is easy to visit, not requiring much effort.
Salt From the Hills. Worth a visit. Interesting to see how salt is obtained from the water running from the surrounding hills. You need to go out of your way to visit this site.

see where Peru's salt is made!. We stopped here on the way to Cusco from ollantaytambo. The drive to the salt field in through the gorgeous Peruvian countryside. You're allowed to walk along the salt ponds, just don't step in the water! Beautiful views all round.

Really interesting, one of our favourite sites!. Really enjoyed our visit to the salt mines. Fascinating to see the different steps and the whole process. And also such a great photo stop. Learning how the locals work this area was great to hear. Very much recommend stopping here.

A must see on your trip to Cuzco. If you have half a day free, you can't miss this place. Most tours would take you to Maras and Moray. Maras (located in the Sacred Valley) is a place that produce salt since the pre Inca times, and it is amazing to see the stream taking salty water to the 3000 ponds, each pond is about 5 square meters and not deeper than 30 cms. They produce tons of salt every year and the best is that it is managed by local people. Salt from Maras is well known everywhere in Peru and travellers are looking for it even at the supermarkets in Lima. When you go to Maras, do yourself a favor and buy some salt with medicinal plants, take a bath using it, your body will thank you! And of course, you can get some pink salt for your consumption!My last tip: go during the dry season (May to October) so that you can see it better.

Nice place to visit. . Nice place to visit and to walk. Cost 10 soles. Saw that some people came with ATV from Moray. Do not recommend as the way is in the dust especially if there are many tourist going by bus or car.

From afar, the white terraces looks like Santorini. We ran into a couple who recommended a quick visit and we were not disappointed! Our driver took us to this little gem which is quite breathtaking. The tiers of salt come in all shapes, sizes and hues. You can wander around with little supervision and explore the area. We left purchasing some souvenir salt that - if you look vendor to vendor - has varying prices for the exact same product. We paid 1 sole for the small bag of salt.Worth the 10 sole entry per car...
Great place; and so unusual. really enjoyed walking around this attraction. It is so unusual and very picturesque. Would recommend a visit.
A must do in Cusco. I've been to Cusco several times and it was the first time I went to Maras and I was impressed. The view is amazing, even though there's not much to do apart from taking pictures.

Interesting Salt Mines Tour. Not a highlight but definitely worthwhile and interesting spot ...found it interesting to see in action as locals were at work during out visit. Something different to see...
Tourist trap but also interesting. It is an interesting site. I went by bike tour which made it particularly challenging at the elevation but also more adventuresome outing.

"Stunning Landscape". The people who designed this place is exceptionally brilliant. It was very unique and interesting. We hired a taxi driver to drive us around. He was very nice and knowledgeable. We loved the people there. Simple, friendly, helpful and honest.
Very different and very interesting. Salt pan terraces with mineral waters from the mountain side. This was a worth while visit. Very interesting.
Such an Interesting Place!. Visited the Salineras and talked to the co-op members -since pre-Inca times, families have passed on the rights to mine the evaporation salt ponds. Don't miss it!

Salinas de Maras a strange and interesting place. This was a unique place in the Sacred Valley of Peru. They have been using this place to harvest salt for over 500 years. A beautiful landscape of small ponds on a hill side. I spent a couple of hours walking around and taking pictures.

Salt.... If there you need to choose a place where you don't need to go, this is it. All you do is walk around beside salt pools (watch out you can fall!!!) and then buy stuff made of salt. Nothing special. Don't go if you are having stomach issues. You need to go up and down steep stairs.

Unique. Never seen anything quite like this. Extensive series of terraced salt pools with a dramatic mountain background. Worth a visit. Would avoid walking the road to access the mines unless you don't mind eating the dust of the many passing vehicles.

Salinas de Maras is a beaustiful place to visit. This place cannot be missed, we hired a driver from Cusco to several places this one was one of it, really nice, worth to visit, is it not easy drive, the gavel road is very narrow.
Interesting place to see and experience the cultural .

Interesting sight, beautiful drive out . We were traveling in a group of six and were able to hire two private taxis from Cusco for 120 soles per car to take us to Salinas de Maras, wait an hour for us to explore and then drive us back to Cusco. The drive out to the salt pans was very beautiful with dramatic mountain landscapes. Once we arrived we paid our 10 sole entrance fee and continued on to walk through the salt fields, taking pictures as you went. There was a group of school children there so it was quite busy but the views were still impressive and the salt that we bought from the nearby shops is really good and really cheap. We're on a long backpacking trip so the different salts have come in handy for adding some flavor to our daily cheap meals :) Worth a trip from Cusco if you have a free day and fancy a little road trip. If traveling solo and can't afford the private taxi there is a local collectivo that goes to a town close to maras at which point you'd have to taxi a taxi the rest of the way.

No reason to skip (cheap) when close by. Entrance to the salt mine is only 10 soles so if you get there like I did with the atv tour there is really no reason not to cough up the additional $3. The sight is quite impressive

Very interesting place. Awesome place with a great view of the salt mines.
It is worth going to see the white pools of salt.
It is located near Urubamba.
Really cool to see!. We loved seeing the salineras - the views of it are amazing! It is also really interesting to see how the salt is made/collected. Really glad we went!

Unique and interesting . We really enjoyed this visit to an active salt mine that has been in use since the time of the Incas. Our Gate-1 guides provided so much historical and geological perspective. We highly recommend a guide. The place is beautiful and the variety of salts for food and medicinal purposes makes great souvenirs of your journey to Peru.

Very Nice Place!. This is a beautiful place of Cusco and I visited on a tour by bike because I love the adventure.
It's unique, but also you can visit Moray that is located close to Maras.
Amazing beauty. How many different shades of white and grey can fit in one picture? Take a extra battery for your camera and start shooting.

Very interesting. This was an interesting site ..worth the visit. You can walk along the salt pools and see the different stages of the salt being dried out. We did this without a tourist guide ... you may get more details with a guide.

Maras, Moray. Another place that is very interesting to visit in Cusco, is the salt mines in Maras and the circular terraces of Moray, which you can visit in just half a day, departing at 9 am and returning at 3 pm, ehimperdible very patchable a place to visit in Cusco.

A lovely white stain in the Sacred Valley. This place is really incredible. I liked it so much, expecially walking among the ponds and watching people gather the salt. I even tasted the naturally hot and salty water flowing from the underground. Nice experience and good products to buy.

Most interesting salt winning area from the Inca period upto now. The sale winning area in Maras has been exploited bij the Inca's and is still in use. Small 'salt lakes' that are linked to each other and spread over the valley.

Nice place. The salineras is a nice place to know, there are little shops to buy some souveniers and salt. Is nice to go with a guide, because they explain how the place works, the types of salt produced there and a lot of nice stuff more.
Impressive. I had no idea what to expect here but was pleasantly surprised. These salt pans go back to the days when the Incans ruled. It is very interesting to see how the salt is harvested.

Amazing to see!. The salt mines are amazing to visit. It's a learning experience and you get to walk on the salt but be careful not to fall in. There are many salt items for sale at the location and it's really amazing to see what they make from salt.
Great view. Cool place. Do not go when it's raining or has recently rained. Get a tour guide to explain this location and the types of salt mined.
Fascinating.. The inca have been harvesting salt here for 800 years. It is amazing to see how these families work the salt pans.
Unique. I loved the salt pans and the patchwork effect. Very interesting to see how the salt extraction takes place. Quite quiet but loved views including residents grafting to collect the salt.
so cool to see, unique experience. You just have to come see this place, i doubt you'll see anything like it. Great photos, great thing to see while you are out in the sacred valley

So cool to see! Hope you have good balance!. I had no idea what to expect when I went to the Salinas de Maras. I was truly amazed though when I reached the area and saw how large of an area this covered. We were able to walk around the salt ponds which can be very narrow areas! At one point, my legs were shaking as I was doubting my own balance, but no one fell in, ha! This is definitely a fun educational experience. Try the salted chocolate at one of the vendors before you leave!

Impressive salt mines. Breath-taking salt mines located about an hour outside of Cusco centre. Easy to visit by hiring a taxi or as part of a Sacred Valley day tour, along with nearby Moray & Chinchero. Beautiful views, great photos & the opportunity to buy some local salt. If you’re short of time, I recommend looking into Ragsos del Peru tour company, as they offer a tour that visits all the main sights in the Sacred Valley in a single day (Chinchero, a local textile centre, Maras, Moray, Ollantaytambo & Pisac).

Incredible white salt pans. These are Inca salt pans cut into the hillside which are still in use after over 400 years. As you approach and look across the mountain backdrop, the terraces stand out as a dramatic white landscape. When I went it was bright sunshine which made for incredible photos as the white salt terraces glistened in the sun.The source of the salt naturally comes from an upstream mountain hot spring, where the salty mineral rich water is channelled into hundreds of small pans where it is evaporated and then harvested. The entrance is not included on the "Boleto Turistico" ticket but it only costs 10 Soles and is well worth it. Try the afternoon for less crowds and if possible walk down the terraces in between the individual pans to get close up. Probably allocate 45 mins and try and combine your visit with the nearby Moray agricultural terraces which are great too.
interesting. Worth visiting- an ancient salt "mine" still in use today- In good condition- local families still run the salt production

Amazing!. This was a fascinating stop on our ATV tour with Maras Adventures. We spent time exploring from above and then walking down along some of the ponds for a closer look. A family was harvesting the salt from one of the ponds, which was interesting to watch. It's amazing how this is constructed in a way to provide water diversion through all the ponds. Really interesting to explore.

So cool! . Checking out the salt ponds was amazing. Ive never seen anything like this in person. After seeing the many ruins in the area, it was cool to see something a little different. It's definitely recommended to listen to or bring a guide that knows the history of the ponds to get a better understanding. A must see!

Much more interesting than anticipated.. I found the salt ponds very interesting. The little stream that serves the pond comes in from the left and you can touch it. You can walk among the ponds but it is a bit precarious in places. But fun.

Great Stop in the Sacred Valley!. We stopped by here on a day trip from Cusco to the Sacred Valley. Its down a crazy windy road but definitely worth the stop. Its best with a guide so you know the history behind the place. Very beautiful and a great place to buy salt!

Mountain salt and a stomach-rolling ride. This was just a unique excursion on our tour. We walked down to the actual salt ponds and dipped our fingers in the salt spring coming out of the mountain. We watched the workers skim the salt and haul it up. We went early in the morning rather than the afternoon b/c our guide said the light would be better. Well, the light was amazing.

Cool to see, but do it on the fly!. Not knocking this wonderful sight, but not what I was expecting. I thought it was going to be up on a mountain side, but it was just down in a valley. Just was kinda....blah after a few minutes. Worth seeing just do it on the fly!

Interesting. Very interesting place to visit. It is really dazzling to see salines formed by a little salty water source. But it is far from Cuzco to there, it is was Ok for because I would visit Maras Moray anyway (which is close to there).
Worth the drive. We hired a taxi and took a day trip from Cuzco. This is a really cool place. We walked through the salt mines and bought some local salt from the market. Great experience.

Maras Hike is a MUST!. Visiting this place was a combination of both a trek back in time and visiting the moon. There are over 4,000 salt pools that are passed down to local family members through the association. I've visited the salt flats in Carmargue in the south of France but this was a completely different experience. The volume and size of this place is unbelievable.

Unique salt mines. MARAS-SALINERAS Salt mine is located 7 miles from Moray and is a small village famous for its 3000 salt mines at different levels of readiness and access with very thin paths. My understanding is these have been around since the Inca times. Salt is sold here and exported all over the world. Very interesting to see how the salt is recovered from these mines. This is a very unique site which you should not miss seeing.

Very busy but fascinating site. I visited this as part of a tour that also included the Inca Moras. Entry weas an extra 10 soles as this is a private business which has been opened to tourists - there were hundreds of people there. It is very interesting but therefore also very crowded with lots of small stalls also selling the usual tourist stuff, plus salt (the main product of the factory)

Good visit. Salt mines are beautiful. Shouldn't take you more than an hour to do your tour. Bus ride there is fun and exciting. Plan ahead, bus ride includes Moray which requires separate ticket. Carry cash.
So unique!. The attraction is out of the way and a rocky drive, but it's like nothing I've seen before. Highly recommend.

A visit to another world, white, bright and warm!. Great experience, this visit has many angles, a picture from above gives you the perspective of the beautiful site and the green valley behind it, so stop for a second while you are driving down the road to admire from the higher ground. Once you are down to the entrance, you go down to the very first floor of the salinas, great pictures from there, and if you have time, walk around it, make sure you touch the water, it is warm, and be safe, the places between the pools are quite tricky.

Salt, salt everywhere!!!. Salinas is a quite curious location to be visited during your trip at Cusco, it can be visited during a tour containing other places to be visited.At first glance you'll think that it may not worth to be visited, but once you get there you'll change your mind.The salts spots in different levels and also different tastes impress, and the most intriguing question is where does the salt come from, as Cusco is not close to the Ocean.Well, If you are questioning yourself about going there or not, I'd say GO. After all Cusco is a destination to visit more than once.

Day trip from Cusco: Learn how salt is captured and harvested. While you are acclimating to the altitude you'll want to take a day trip. This is a good choice to pair up with the Moray terraces. The pink salt water that flows from the mountains is captured into small pools where it eventually evaporates - leaving salt to be harvested by the locals. Over 700 pools are here and each one is owned by a local family who sells the salt to the town of Cusco.

Try to go on your own - without a tour operator - and spend some time. We went by Combi from Ollantaytambo (5 Soles for 2 people), and walked to the Salinas. When climbing over the mountain, you turn from one Waaaw effect into the other. The Salinas are really huge, and when walking from one side to the other you see (and can speak to) people working in these salt pans.Besides from being very photogenic, it's very impressive and lovely to spend some time.Try to go early in the morning, as it can be very hot, but you still want the sun to shine on the salt pans, for the photos

Very unique. You will never see anything like this anywhere. It's massive and really cool (albeit a bit slippery) to wonder between the ponds. Not good for anyone that has difficulty walking if you want to go walk amongst the ponds, but could still get close enough to appreciate otherwise. It's farther from Cusco than we thought, but worth the day trip. We got there just in time as they were closing - but since no one else was there we got great photos and the sun was setting creating beautiful colors on the ponds.

Interesting but only if you drive along to Machu Pichu. It's OK to visit if you pass along on your way to Machu Pichu but don't spent time if you think of a day visit to this place. You can walk around for 30 minutes but then you are done.
Dream. Amazing place to visit when drop in Cusco. Nice view, amazing feeling and deeper integration between man and naute.

Very Interesting Side Stop. After seeing Machu Picchu and staying in Ollantaytambo a couple of days, we decided to pair this trip with Moray. We did this in the morning going to both locations by taxi on the way back to Cusco. I would say an hour is sufficient to see these salt flats. You do have to pay about 10 soles to enter. It is not covered by the Turistico Boleto. You can purchase small bags of salt for a sol each so we decided to make these little gifts for friends back home. It was neat to see. I want to say that it is about 20 minutes from Moray.
Salt Mines. A terrifying drive in to this place is well worth it. We got to climb around the mines and it is quite slick so bring good shoes and go before the farmers stop allowing easy access.
Salt Mines. The salt mines were interesting to learn about and the scenery was beautiful! The drive to the salt mines was beautiful and a bit surreal. Try the chocolate and treats when you get there!

Lovely salt mines. We have visited this as a part of our sacred valley tour. The salt mines are amazingly beautiful and surreal sometimes. Please carry water, sun protection as it is in the middle of mountains and very hot. But definetly worth it.
Worth visiting!. We found this place on the way back from Urubamba to Cusco. We were amazed by the scenery. It is worth visiting there if you have time between Urubamba & Cusco.

Worth the Drive. This was one of the highlights of my stay in Sacred Valley of Peru. When I was researching it, I knew that I wanted to visit it. There's 3000 salt pools at the salt flats on the side of a mountain, which are fed by a small salt stream. It makes for beautiful photos. What a sight to see. I highly recommend it.I took a taxi tour with Taxidatum.com having been picked up at my hostel in Ollantaytambo and then being driven to Moray, Salinas de Maras and Chincherro before being dropped off at my hostel in Cuzco. The taxi tour cost me only $65 USD. That's for the entire taxi ride. If 3 people are in the same taxi, you split the fee by three.
Quite something!. Amazing to see these salt pans, considering they are from Inca times. The whole sacred valley tour is worth doing.

Very cool to see how they farm salt on a hillside.. Great short little visit - well worth it to learn how the locals have managed to harvest the salt from the water that flows in these hills and valleys.

Community efforts. The 1 st few salt pools are from Inca times.Now more than 3000 each family in the area has one and it is a community effort. there is a facility to package product in town.Admission is 10 soles.several vendors on site and washrooms. no one knows how long the spring has been feeding the pools nor how long it will continue . Cool stop for an hour or so !

Try to do it by yourself. The salinas themself are gorgeous.. but try to figure a way to do it without a tour or at least make sure they don't put you in a huge bus of 30 people. I think a lot of tours are the same so here is a warning : This was annoying first because a big bus on those roads is quite dangerous, and second we were just too many people for one guide. Also they only give you 10 minutes to enjoy and take pictures.. really? Plus they never stop to have lunch. Get yourself some food before going. So that made a quite bad experience for us. The site itself is beautiful but very touristic. Loads of touristic shops.

Most fun ever. Took a 4 wheeler excursion to see the salt mines and lets just say it was the most fun I have ever had. Driving through the towns and even passing livestock in the road it was beyond epic!

worth a visit. An interesting place to stop on your travels and if the light is good you will capture some great photos. and grab some salt. I went with Photo Tours Peru Day Tours as My guide very informative and helpful guide.
Original and interesting. Very interesting for children to see one way salt can make it from nature to their dinner table. Our 13 year old loved it and so did we.

Still making salt pre-Inca way. Maras is salt fields where they are making salt from Andean salty water, still by manual labor. After seeing many of the ruins around the Sacred Valley, it was intriguing to see the fields still in production from those times. Be sure to buy salt there as they would put it in fancy bottles and sell at much higher price at the airport.

Stop if you have time. Tucked in the Sacred Valley are the salt mines dating back 300 years pre Inca. The salt mines are still working salt mines and was interesting to see how they harvest the salt from each individual family plot. You also have the opportunity to purchase the salt in local foods and scented bath salts. The drive to the salt mines offers stunning views of the snow capped Andes. A nice morning activity for anyone that has extra time before leaving the Sacred Valley.

Great day tip away from the city. We combined the Salins de Maras with the ruins at Moray, biking between the two sites.The salt mine themselves do not take long to wander around, but offer a stunning view down the valley.Best to try and go when they are actually harvesting the salt, it is said to be very impressive.

Best part of Sacred Valley. Salinas was my favorite place we went on our trip through the sacred valley. It was a magical place and was a beautiful but not too difficult hike to arive at the top (about 30 minutes). To get there, we took a carro from Ollataytambo and asked the driver to let us off at the turn off. He dropped us off and told us the road to follow to get there.

Interesting side trip via 4 wheelers. My friend and I took an excursion from Cusco to the salt mines. About 1 hr from Cusco we took 4 wheelers to the salt mines. It was very very very dusty . It was a welcome change from visiting churches and museums. We dressed is light jackets and jeans .

Salt Ponds. After several days of visiting Incan sites the kids were excited to see something different. It was fun to taste the salty river water and try chocolate bars which had salt in them. Fascinating place to visit for a few hours. We did it on the same morning as Morey- which was a great combination as they are fairly close to each other.

Salt pond walkabout!. Arrived by tour bus at the top of Salinas de Maras, and met the driver at the bottom. The walk down offered a beautiful view of the mountains and close up view of the salty irrigation system (can see different phases of the process). Wear sunscreen! The white ponds reflect the sun.

Interestingly unique and amazing. Really very interesting to see how they harvest salt. And the different types they get. You can walk down to the salt sections. I bought some bath salts at the little stores on the way out

One of the most incredible sites I've ever seen. An ancient ocean, trapped under a mountain, releasing a steady stream of salty water, and harvested since pre-Inca times, and still functional. The narrow, winding mountain roads approaching the site are an experience themselves, and the site itself is simply amazing.

Worth knowing how mountain salt is extracted. Nice experience to see the water coming down from the mountains and filling the salt terraces. There are small shops where you can buy salt and other small things.

Very cool to see the locals coming together to support this effort!. You will want to visit these salt mines, with each plot run by a local salt miner. One of the most unique places we have ever seen..... Ignore the touristy part and understand the history and culture that makes these mines so unique.
Interesting trip. Quite an adventure getting here as the road is steep and no crash barriers. However worth it for the fascinating insight into how salt has been produced using salt pans.
Salinas . A very interesting place to visit for an hour or two. If you can hire a local driver, pair the visit with a stop to nearby Maray.

Breathtaking and Unique. I'm always amazed to find out how indigenous groups in the Americas utilized their natural resources to their fullest extent and, one of the more fascinating places I've visited in Peru are the salt flats. You can walk directly onto the flats, where locals are still harvesting salt that they irrigate from the mountainside. Descending into the flats is an incredible experience, observing how the salt is organized and harvested is fascinating, and being able to purchased some of the fruits of their labor in the form of flavored salts is a real treat.

Unique Experience. We combined Salineras de Maras with the the Incan architectural phenomenon Moray. Salineras de Maras is interesting and very cool to see now the salt is produced, but it is a full day journey from Cusco, so choose your transportation wisely (AC vehicle and negotiate your fare prior to the adventure). Pick up bags of natural salt while you are there.

Well worth the time / Salt is the best. When touring the Sacred Valley this is a must do. Very fascinating to see them making salt like they have for hundreds of years. The salt will make your barbecue a miracle take it from a Texan. Brought several bags back everyone wants some.

Quite incredible sight. The photo opportunities are worth the trip out here- best to combine it with nearby Moray Inka site and 'crop laboratory '. The salt pans are hundreds of years old and still functioning. No need to spend 30 minutes here unless you're a pro photographer. The water is surprisingly warm when it enters the salt pans and the colours range from brown to pale blue. The banos are probably the most disgusting in Peru by the way !

las salineras son muy hermosas!. The salt mines in Maras are truly a wonder! They look, and feel both other worldly and deeply natural. I recommend visiting in a way that is not crammed into a brief tour, as we greatly enjoyed being able to take our time, walk around a lot, and bask in the amazing earth and the people caring for her. :) Also, taste the stream!

Extraordinary sight! . The salt pools are another example of the advanced architecture of the Incas. The sight is fantastic, but bear in mind that it's not possible to walk around, so visitors are limited to a rather small area where they can take fotos. For this reason I would recommend going there on your own instead of with a guided tour. We took the tour, which really wasn't worth it as the tour guide didn't really give much useful information. Also he seemed to be in a rush getting away again so we only had around 15 minutes at the salt mines.

Must see!. It costs 10 soles per person to get in. It's worth it! You are able to walk around the mines and even dip your finger into the irrigation system and taste the water. You'll also feel the water is warm. You'll have to pass through some booths of trinkets to get into the mines, which you'll most likely buy something! You can't help it!Total time spent: 1-2 hours

Awesome setting, interesting. We spent a couple hours at Salinas. The setting with the tall mountains is quite fantastic and enhances the experience as with so many attractions in this area. We enjoyed touring this site, would recommend as part of a visit to the Sacred Valley.

The salt pits are really interesting. We visited the salt pits on a day excursion out of Cusco that included visits to Chinchero and Moray and are very glad we went. Seeing the salt pits was really interesting for us and for our kids.
A pleasant surprise. I wasn't expecting much of this, so I was pleasantly surprised! It's really clean and peaceful, I felt energized. As a foodie, I bought some flavored salt as well.

Unusual ancient salt production. Mountainside salt water diverted into multiple large drying pans on a huge hillside. I've never seen anything resembling this ancient technique of salt production. The salt is ultimately sold retail. We are taking little bags home to our cook friends.

amazing. Salineras de Maras is place you must visit. The original was made by the incas and now its followed by local people. it consist in water that comes undergound which is warm and salty, they let little pools where the water get evaporated by the sun and they get the salt from it.

Very interesting and entertaining!. I had no idea how salt was made and learnt a lot. If I'd had had my way I would've spent the entire morning weaving though the salt terraces. They're an amazing and unique view!

Fun for the family. These salt mines use the natural springs that bring the salt out from under the ground. The water is pooled and then evaparated using the sun. It is interesting for the whole family, and then you can purchase some high quality salt to bring back home. In this same area you can find the Moray Inca terraces which you shouldn't miss.

Hot and Enjoyable. Salinas de Maras is a fairly long trip from Cusco. It is a n interesting place where the locals own the salt areas and produce their 'goods' for sale. If you are feeble of foot DON'T go as there is a lot of walking and moving between salt beds, the small pathways and slopes. We enjoyed it but no need to stay long.
Visit if there is extra time. We did not do a full tour of the place but thought 30 minutes would have been more than enough to have a quick look.

Cool place!. Very cool place to check out and learn the history about. We spent about an hour to an hour and a half here, eating snacks, tasting the different salts, and walking around. Definitely a worthwhile stop just to learn about the history!

NICE PLACE TO SEE A NATURAL SLAT MINES. The salt mines are a very natural place where you can visit with your tourist any time so have to know that this mine work only in summer because they need the sun to do the evaporation to get 3 qualities of salt and specially the pink salt and it has 80 kind of minerals , also you can buy directly this pink salt in the same places from the same farmers , definitely I recommended visit this places .

Best side trip during your stay in Cusco!. If you have to do see one thing outside Cusco before or after your trip to Machu Picchu, I would recommend the Salineras de Maras ( couple with Maray lietrally 10mn away). The mix of colors and the view over the valley are absolutely stunning! You can also buy gourmet salt directly from there !

First View is Breathtaking. We loved our visit! The views from above are mindblowing. Watching the families harvesting the salt oozes history. You will absolutely enjoy your visit. Be sure to get yourself some salt before you leave.
Buy some salt!. Great views for a hidden place by the sacred valley. Deffinitely get some spiced salts that are great for cooking with!

Interesting for a quick visit. A natural saline spring, since before the Incas, has provided water that is channeled into pools and evaporated. Local families are each allocated 4-5 pools and harvest the salt once they are dry. You are allowed to walk along the channel at the upper edge of the complex but are discouraged from exploring further. Mostly, the complex consists of the (presumably family-run) vendor stalls, each selling various grades of salt, as well as the usual mix of textiles and souvenirs. Toilets were reasonable, but bring 1 sol. Good for a 30-45 min visit.

Quite a unique and fascinating site. A bit out of the way and a bit hard to get up and down to (our legs weren't working so well after going up and down Machu Picchu). It was interesting to see the salt being collected and the way it changed with successive evaporations. The salt flavoured chocolate was an interesting take away.

Great place to spend an hour. Strange but true- this is the fourth salt facility I've visited in various places throughout the world. This is the most interesting of the group. While the contention is that the salt fields have been used for 10,000 years, that is likely a bit of an exaggeration, given the history of the area. Nonetheless, the supportable story of the facility is fascinating and worth the time to visit. You get to walk through the pond area and see people working the ponds, and you learn the uniqueness of the geology that leads to the salt. It's a very cheap way to get educated on something unusual.

Day ATV trip. The Salinas de Maras was more beautiful than I had expected it to be. It was interesting watching the local people collect the salt. I was glad we were able to visit, we visited this area during a strike.

Interesting and enjoyable for any age. See where that table salt cones from! In August and the rest of the warm season you can watch people actively piling up the salt. My sons reached down and popped a white grain into their mouths- and were very excited to confirm that it was, in fact, salt. And you can easily bring some home with you to try - the price of a bag of the highways lot salt us only 3 Solas. Great for photos!!

Unique place! A must see! Where do you see a stream of salty water coming out of a mountain that is 3000 meters high?. Make sure you go with a local bus or ask your driver for a fair price! Many people take advantage of tourist's ignorance to charge high fares. Oh, stay in Chinchero and go to Salinas and Moray.
A beautiful place in Peru. You won't spent 4 hours on site but it is place has to be seen in Peru. It is actually amazing and beautiful. Totally worth it !!

Nice site, again tourist attraction.... Went there after the Moray site. It is full of people if you arrive there mid-day. Very crowded. In addition, the place is not on the ticket of 16 sites so you have again to pay 10 Soles more at the entrance.Beside that the site is quite impressive with more than 3000 salt pools. Please respect the place and keep you items out of the pools...
Must see!. Very well kept; a little bit out of the way, close to moray ruins (recommended) but worth a visit. Its included in the tourist pass and has nice cultural vibe.

Wow. I love salt!. This place was amazing, bought salt here too and can't wait to get it home to sample it. I've never seen anything like this anywhere, couple it with a trip to moray and it was a great day out.

Inca salt pans Incredible and beautiful place. It cost $7 per person and is a well-worthed place to visit. I bought cooking and medicinal bath salts to take home. Our tour guide was very informative and the place was beautiful and interesting. Definitely, a place to visit in the sacred Valley of Urubamba.

What a fascinating place !!!. Though tucked away in a valley, this is a sight to see ! Hot volcano water with a high salt content fills these terraces. Salt is then dried and harvested. We started at the top and wandered to the base which is 2000 feet down. We walked to town of Urabamba.

Just Wow!. The Sacred Valley is one of the treasure of Peru. The Salineras of Maras were on my list for a long time before I got the chance to go. During the visit, I was guided by a man from a really tiny community called Media Luna, in Urubamba, a unique way to discover this amazing place. You should absolutely include a stop there for your trip in the Sacred valley and if you'd like, the community also offer workshops about their traditionnal knowledge : about guinea pig (!!), chicha, weaving, medicinal plants, etc. I had a great day with the community members. Don't hesitate to send me a message if you'd like more info about it :).

Fascinating !. 1 hour drive from the city, but worth it to get out of town. Entrance is 20 soles per person and the visit lasts about an hour.We went with private taxi for 140 soles, including other ruins.

Salinas for backpackers. I started my trip to Salines up in Maras. We (my friend and I) were suposed to go to Maras walking but it started raining so we took a van (10 soles each) to Salinas. Then when we got there, we realized that the trekking to Salinas was going to be quiet hard. Yo have to climb down a mountain (there is a road but is not so easy). The entrance is 10 soles, but there is just a postman i think if you go there by walking and enter from another way there would not charge you. When we got there we saw the Salinas, is wonderful. There in the Salinas, we saw to much people was no so funny because you couldnt walk by the Salt pits. If you want you can cross all the Salt pits and go to the valley down the mountain we didn because we have just paid the van driver.We didnt bought the salt there because (im peruvian) i know is normal salt with a bit of pinky color on it.
Really interesting. A place with a very unusual view and where you can shop for some of the most typical items in the region, such as the salted chocolate.
Very scary drive down!. I did not like the drive down to this attraction. It was a neat attraction but for me, who does not like that kind of driving and heights...I do not recommend!

Salinas de Maras. My husband and I briefly visited the Salinas de Maras while on a 6 hour driving tour of the Sacred Valley. This was easily one of our favourite destinations along the way. The road there winds down a steep cliff, providing some incredible if scary views. Worth the trip!

Never seen anything like this, amazing!. We visited this place during a day trip through the Sacred Valley, so didn't have a lot of time to admire this place. But I think 30 minutes would do anyway. It's a very special place in a beautiful environment and I loved it to stroll around the salt fields. There are also some nice stalls for souvenirs (like salt of course) and drinks. If you are nearby, I would definitely recommend going there!

Breathtaking. This was my first time seeing salt flats so I was in awe. Scenery was beautiful, and worth the pretty steep 25 minute hike from the main road. We stopped on the way from Ollantaytambo on our way back to Urumbamba. The bus driver dropped is off at the road we were to hike up. 20 or 30 minutes to explore the place was plenty!

Amazing!. Salinas se Maras was a very unique site to see. Hidden deep down in a beautiful valley, the contrast of colours are just brilliant and and unlike anything I have ever seen. Must say that the site has huge anounts of tourists and you kind of move with the crowds to get a good view of everything but it is still well worth a visit! Would recommend as a quick stop while traveling in the area.
great view. Really need to walk between the terraces . Not for people with vertigo or afraid of hights ; because small ridges .

Great place to visit. Its an amazing and cool place to visit. Tickets are 10 soles and you can get there from Cusco by tour or on your own... Its not a problem. Salt in there is cheaper than in Cusco...not a lot, but if going is better to buy in there... You can also get discounts if buying more than one package. Just be careful when walking around.....

Fascinating. It's worth having a guide to explain the importance of the salt ponds, throughout history when the Incas used them, to nowadays when they're split (mostly evenly) amongst families in the area. There's a little shop/shack there too, selling chocolate with pink salt from the ponds, among many other things. It'll cost you 10 soles per person to get in the gate.We organised a taxi with Cusco Transport (pricey, but effective) who also stopped off in Urubamba on the way back to Cusco, and took us to Maras. There are cheaper ways to get there and back (rather than the $90 we paid between the two of us), but this was definitely much easier.

Wouldn't eat the salt. A great place to visit. Went there several times over the years. Good place to take some lovely photos, but I wouldn't eat the salt because I've seen some of the workers piss on the salt.

Impressive!. That is something quite uncommon to see over there! This place is unrealistic (out of the context of its surroundings) and impressive.It is only a pity that it is not included in the pass of s/130. But for s/20 it is definitely a place worth visiting.The road to get there is a bit harsh also, as many sites in the area.The suggestion is to get a taxi for a private tour: we did Morray, Salinas and Ollantaytambo in the same day (around 8h) for s/170, which is pretty cheap!

Beautiful experience. This place is very beautiful, and it's really fun, to walk through the salt lakes, and see people working with it. You can also touch and taste if you dare. There's a lot of touristy shops, where you can buy the usual. Souvenirs, snacks and water. We had a private chauffeur driving us out here, which was great.

Very cool!. The salt mines are really fascinating and it was kind of exciting to get to walk on the edges to explore. It was a little precarious- not for kids or people who are not sure-footed unless they stay at the top and don't walk on the actual pool edges. Highly recommended. Only 10 soles.

Shocking Salty Surprise!. Visited Salinas de Maras with a Edwin Cusi, a guide for "Toursbylocals.com". This was an amazing place. Edwin explained how the salt is harvested, how long salt has been harvested and how many owners make up this amazing co-op. Everyone gets access to the actual pools as well as an opportunity to purchase the salt in many forms, including salty chocolate bars. This is truly a world wonder and well worth your time.

Impressive. The salt mines are quite extensive and very interesting visually by the myriad of colours. You can (carefully) walk through the middle of the 'pools' so I would recommend steady shoes if you are keen. You can also purchase some salt and other products at the little market. Toilets are paid for each time you go in (although quite cheap). Worth a visit!
Amazing/ Life-Changing. This place was so cool! We really enjoyed it! We ate the restaurant at the top and it was great too. We were there on a slow day and we had the place to ourselves.

Salty!. Sorta cool stop to check out ancient salt ponds. We stopped by on a sunny / hot afternoon in July so didn't stay more than 1 hour, but it was worth the visit if you're traveling around the Sacred Valley.

An amazing sight. The salt water comes out of the rock and is collected in pans. They top up the pans 5 times after allowing evaporation. This gives three layers of salt of three different qualities the poorest use for medicines and the others for flavouring food. Quite a site and lots of stalls selling tourist presents and of course salt.

Interesting but small and crowded . I was on a bus tour, it's a very commercial place, just like everything else in Cusco. You have to pass through a market, more buses were bring more people. Everyone wanted to take a photo. The paths were narrow. The salt basins were nice to look at. It's also very dusty there.

Worth a visit. Rent a motor bike in Calle Saphi (Cusco, next to the Plaza de Armas) and drive there by yourself. The trip is lovely with great views and good streets. The Salinas a very picturesque and unique and a really worth a stop. Compared to other sights, the entry is very affordable.

Sacred Valley must see. Wow, the sight as you round the corner on the sketch access road is simply stunning. To think this pre dates the inka and that it is still in use today is amazing. Takes about an hour, brought home salt as well. Word of caution, if the weather is poor this would be a miss. We met folks that did and the road, really a single lane, which becomes a double with buses passing each other on with no road shoulder... scary for sure but if nice, can't beat the visit

Salinas de Maras, quite different to anywhere I have visited.. An amazing sight, which you can walk around if you are careful ! We visited as part of a Quad biking tour, which also make a nice change from the bus! Beautiful and breathtaking.

Unexpected wonder - cliff with 3500 terraces producing salt. While touring the Sacred Valley we has the Maras Salt Flats as a stop. I wasn't expecting much - but what a remarkable wonder of nature and human ingenuity! I always assumed natural salt was produced at the sea but in this mountain area, a salt water stream has delivered highly salty mineral water to these terraces for centuries. Family cooperatives still use sun and patience to evaporate the pools into salt. You can buy 1000 gram bags of pink Maras salt for S/5 ($1.75). The quality of the salt is exceptional for cooking.

Good trip, combined with a visit to Moray. Salt is still being extracted for commercial purposes, but you do not need to worry about it. It is a good combination, as you can do Maras - Moray in the same day for a very convenient price - Moray is amazing!

Like nothing I've seen before. The salt flats of Maras are quite a sight. Thousands of pools of salty water are connected by a system of water paths. Each pool is owned and managed by a local family as part of a free collective. Anyone from the area may claim a pool but where your pool is located is dependent on how well you tend your pool and how long you have been a part of the collective. There are a number of vendors who have set up shops around the perimeter of the salt pools. You can buy interestingly flavored salts for very little cost and know that you are supporting the local people directly.
Amazing Site!!!. Visited with Family. Was way more than I expected. What a site. Impressive. Bought all kinds of salt products. DO NOT Miss this.

Amazing view!!!. I went to Salinas de Maras with my husband and two kids (7 and 5 years old). What an amazing view of the salt mines. Is spectacular! Be careful not to slip in the salted water and bring your camera. Must see attraction that is about 1 and a half hour drive from Cuzco. Entrance cost S/.10 soles (about 3 dollars) per person. For children under 10 is free.

Don't miss this. This is a very special attraction. These salt mines are dismantled in the rainy season (literally washed away) and rebuilt again every year. Only when you visit can you appreciate the effort and engineering that goes into this endeavor every year. Walking through the salt mines is an adventure in itself as you're walking gingerly on the side of a mountain- we were with our kids so yes I was a bit nervous but apart from one salty, wet sneaker we were unscathed. Do go early though to avoid crowds as the path through the salt flats becomes increasingly more crowded and thus more tricky.

Wow!. This place is just amazing! We were so lucky that our guide took us there because is a place where not that many tourists get to visit. Is just amazing. Beautiful views of the mountains. Breathtaking!

Go from Urubamba!. This is a spectacular working salt mine, allowing for amazing photographs. If you go early you may catch the workers on the flats.I recommend going from Urubamba, you can ask for a moto to take you to within 15 minutes walk of the Salinas, you get a perspective and more time than you would if you went on a regular tour from Cusco. You can head back to Urubamba or get a lift from Maras to Cusco

Great place to visit. We took a private taxi from our hotel in Yucay to Maras; what a view when you get closer and the best part is that you can walk around anywhere you want. It's amazing how big it is and the stream that feeds those pools is a small, warm and salty. You have to walk down from the parking lot thru stalls selling souvenirs and salt and salt products. I'm glad I bought my salt over there for a good price. I saw the salt in grocery stores in Lima, stores at the airport for more than triple the price. These pools have been working since the Incas and today local families still work them. It's not a place run by the government. The money they collect at the entrance stays in the community.

Like Nothing I've Seen Before. Visited on the way to Sacred Valley Hotel from Cusco Airport. Not part of the Boleto Turistico. I believe we paid 10 Soles for adults and 5 for kids. Took some information from the internet to get an idea of the salt pans. Turns out they have been there for quite some time and are still actively used today. You can walk around salt pans, no danger if falling into them as they are roughly about one foot deep. Makes for interesting pictures because the site is just very cool looking. Some of the locals were actually tending to their pans and extracting salt while we were there. There was also a small group of stalls selling a variety of items, including salt.

Great little day trip. We really enjoyed the Salineras. Really interesting and truly beautiful. Beautiful ride along the way as well. Great place to pick up some foodie souvenirs as well. A must while in Cusco!

Interesting . There are lots and lots of things to do while in Cuzco and Valle Sagrado. From Cuzco itself, that deserves several dates, to a trip to Machupichu, you may not always have enough time to do it all. Urubamba, Ollantaytambo, Pisac ... lot to see. If with enough time, it's an interesting place to continue discovering the genius of the pre Inca culture that first discovered and exploited these Salinas, and also how they are still being managed today, in a cooperative environment by the 5 thousand inhabitants of the near village. But if short of time, won't make the difference.
Something Different. A good stop off the usual Inca ruins. Not to hard to find and easy to do as a day trip from Cusco both independently or in a tour.
Cusco Vacation. Expect to walk and bring sun protection. This is very interesting and does not take long to view. The walking is on a very narrow walk with people moving both ways be accepting.
Very cool. Did bus tour. Very cool to see all the different colours of the salt flats. Lots of walking and steep. Lots of vendors!

Quite stunning. At the end of a walk from the agricultural circles at Moray we descended down to the salinas de Maras.They are very extensive and you can walk right along the top edge of the salt pans.Quire scary as it looks like ice,but is of course salt.

Just one part of a fabulous day trip. This is an excellent location to visit with a good tour guide and camera. The air is fresh and the view is fantastic on a clear sunny day. The warning is given very clearly not to consume the salt water in any form, although some don't know or do not heed the warning. There is plenty of actual salt (crystals) for consumption sold in packages at the markets on-site. The Cusqueno chocolate bar with salt from the site is absolutely delicious and totally worth the purchase. They also have bath salts in packages. A fabulous part of my day trip and with treasures to take home as an added bonus!!!!

Incredible salt plains in the Sacred Valley. Well worth a visit as long as it's in the dry season. We travelled by taxi from our hotel and it's worth doing a round trip with Moray, the Inca ruins. There's nothing to do there except walk around but it is a spectacular sight.
Glad We Experienced This. My wife and I had a great time exploring the salt mine. We had never seen an above ground mine before and we enjoyed learning about it.

very unique place. I lived near Salineras for several months and highly recommend this place for it's absolute uniqueness. I'm not sure if there's another place like it in the world. Native families harvest the salt from their individually owned plots. You can buy salt there directly from the families after you watch them harvesting it. Highly recommend the extra stop before or after Machu Picchu if you have the time, it's definitely worth it!

Otherworldly pre-Incan salt pans, easy to/from Cusco, well worth the visit!. We arranged to have our driver stop at Maras and Moray on our way from Ollantaytambo to Cusco. The first stop was at the Salineras de Maras, which is an otherworldly sight to behold. These salt "pans" (more like evaporation ponds than mines) have been used since pre-Incan times. You can walk among the pans, watch the workers go about their day collecting salt, and buy some to take home with you. The landscape surrounding Maras is also beautiful. Well worth the side trip and visit!
Fascinating. Knew nothing about salt collection pre this but felt well educated afterwards. Really interesting but don't go in middle of day as white glare and us shine is very harsh

Visually stunning and interesting engineering. We walked in from the road between Urubamba and Ollantaytambo. It was a great hike (about 60 to 90 minutes). We ended up getting a taxi from there to go home - I don't recommend that - it was expensive and took just as long as walking back (the road goes around the mountain in the other direction).

Incredible . Great time here ...cheap to get there , just for 30 soles from the plaza mayor in cusco ... Have to be 8:30 in the agency .. There are a it and the tour last 4 hours ... Was worth it totally

Nice short stop. We did a quad bike tour there. its definitely interesting to visit, but plan not more than a short stop there (ca 20/30 min). The salt pools are interesting to see from above (while you going down the switchbacks on the road you can stop and see it) and also you can wander around between the pools, see people gaining the salt, etc. you can also of course buy local salt at the souvenier stores. Its good but make it part of some other trip. Entrance is 10 soles per person.

One of the most amazing places I have ever visited. Loved this tour. I had so little information but loved the pictures. What a marvelous surprise. Wish we had more time to walk around. So many beautiful pictures, check if you can see some of the locals working the salt, loved it. Worth revisiting some day.

Strange and Wonderful. You would think there would be cheaper ways of making salt these days, but here they are still using the traditional, labor intensive method of drying briny water in the hot sun. A magnificent, strange place.

Nice Sacred Valley Diversion ..... Must see to appreciate. Really interesting and amazing that the source has been used for salt since pre-inca times. Really need a guide to give some insight. Lots (and lots) of vendors but no one was high pressure. Can buy bags of different salts and other food, clothing and touristy items.

Very unique sight!. Beautifully located at the end of a dusty road and carved into the side of a valley, the salt mines are like nothing else I've ever seen before. Very unique experience in the Sacred Valley, worth the drive.

Marvelous nature industry. Ancient peruvians discovered these mountains with saline chloride . The water is not sweet it resembles sea water. With local technology Incas And ancient peruvians used it for salt production. You can buy pink salt.

Amazing site. It's an amazing creation with levels of salt pans covering the side of the mountain. It is truly a site to behold. I took a little walk further out and could not believe the extent of the site.
Absolutely worth a visit.

Privately owned. These salt ponds are privately owned. The workers come from the area and city of Moray. The underground saline water is dried by the sun. Learn about the desalination process and qualities.

Fun side trip!. It's not everyday you can walk around salt wells. I was actually surprised they lets tourists roam around so closely since some areas were very narrow and conducive to slips and falls. Interesting place and educational as I never knew how salt was mined. The site also plays an important role in Peru's culinary culture with its country's top chefs and restaurants claiming to use salt from here.Worth the trip out if you're in the Sacred Valley!

Incredibly interesting . Our daughters weren't sure what to think when told the destination, but were very impressed with the place. We had a tour guide that was able to explain the history and it was quite fascinating. Definitely worth the trip.
Very interesting . The scenery is fantastic around this area. We caught a taxi from Ollantaytambo to Cusco 150 soles. We toured the entire area en route. Salinas was on the way.
Amazing site to see. I have never seen salt pans quite like this. Visually it is a spectacle. You can walk amongst the area and watch the owners work their pans. Fascinating and well worth the visit.

Skip it. I admit, these salt ponds are intriguing since you are 1,000 KM from the ocean and the salt come from a underground stream; however, unless this is something you really love, spend more time at the terraces of Moray.
Well..salt flats. Not very impressed by it. They cover 10 soles entrance fee and the place is way to small to handlecall the people they drag in.

Great but unkept . We went on a tour of the salt mines. The only thing that disappointed me was how little people that visited cared about its boundaries. So many shoe prints in the actual salt mines.

It is not easy to walk when it's busy.. When we visited last month, it was busy and too many people. The path is really narrow so it is very difficult when people walk pass you. One of my foot slipped in the water so my feet got wet.!!
However it is really interesting place. You can buy good quality salt and lovely banana chips (freshly made) there.
My 12 year old son loved it. Interesting place. The kids really enjoyed touching the salt crystals. It was a really hot day and the heat bounced off the white salt but the kids still liked it.
Great excursion!. A really fun day trip when combined with Moray and Urubamba. Lots of salty souvenirs to buy and interesting local history

Unexpected experience (Very Good). I got here as part of one of the tours and the discovery of this place was surprising and refreshing. The view is stunning and in the local market you can buy all kind of products made with the salt produced in there. I recommend the chocolate bars.

Salt Works were fascinating. Our visit to Salinas de Maras was quite interesting. Seeing the site from a distance was intriguing and being able to walk through the salt works and look closely at how the salt is produced were quite educational. We bought some of the pink salt and some chocolate infused with the local salt. Sadly, the chocolate is all gone but we are enjoying our pink salt.

Cool to see, but a quick stop. This was a neat spot to stop and see on our tour. It's a few steps down to the actual salt area and you have to walk through a lot of vendors before you get down there. I was able to buy 3 small (250g) bags of salt for 5 Soles. Word to the wise - one of the salts they sell is mixed with coca leaves and the USA will *NOT* allow coca into the States anymore - even in small amounts mixed with the salt. My tour guide assured me they would and I had to dump it at the airport. :) Live and learn!
And now for something completely different. Salt pans have been in use for 100's of year and are still in use today. Many vendors nearby to take some salt back home.

The view from above is epic. If you can get there in the earlier afternoon its nice to be in the sun while you are there, the pictures look a lot nicer. Beautiful views from above the salt mines, but what looks really cool is there are so many little trails you can cruise around and get different angles. Not too far outside of Cusco you can take ATV's for a fun ride through the countryside.

Nice day trip from cusco. We did this on public transport - a collectivo from Cusco to pisac (4 soles), walked around pisac, collective to urubamba (4soles), then as we were short on time a taxi to salineras (50 soles return without haggling at all, and he waited 40 mins). The sight is really impressive. We aren't on a Sunday when only a couple of people were working -the rest of the week all the pans are being worked. Entrance is 10 soles. If you want you can take a collectivo to the junction (clearly signposted) and then taxi/walk the last 6km on a quiet road. Collectivos also go direct from Cusco to urubamba (6soles), and take 1.5 hrs.

a place to reach when you want salt. well, not really salt, what we wanted was solace driving into another type of terrain and if possible do those trails by mountain bike, cusco is an excellent area to find both... and all options you can customize with trans tour cusco.

Very interesting. We stopped to visit the Salinas on our way to Cusco and we thought it was well worth it. It was very interesting to see the salt at different stages and it was cool to see all the different salt pools.They sell salt to the tourist in cute packages that make a nice and inexpensive souvenir.

A waterfall of white!!!!!. The salt flats are owned by farmers independent of the Peruvian government and are beautiful!!!! It is located in Maras, amidst the Andean mountain range and as you walk down the hill towards the salt flats, it gets very very hot, so layer up your clothing and bring a hat, water, and wear plenty of sunscreen!!The water that flows through the flats is very salty, and walking amongst the flats can be slippery, so beware! In addition to the Boleto Turistico/tourist tickets (130 soles), you pay an extra 10 soles to the Maras community. There are plenty of souvenir shops that sell salt products mined from the salt flats. Overall I really enjoyed visiting the Salinas de Maras and I would recommend going with a tour as it's an hour journey from Cusco.

Really cool place to see!. This interesting site is often part of a Moray, Salinas and Chinchero Tour. A very interesting place to see. You can walk near the salt pools. Fun to photograph this "white" site!

Salt terraces for more than 8 centuries. Salineras de Maras is far from fully developed as a tourist attraction. That's because it is a working salt farm, held by local residents on the same cooperative ownership system which was established in around 1,300. Locals are generous letting tourists wander all over the terraces, and we had a full explanation and demonstration from a local, in very halting Spanglish and gestures. He was charming. The rugged hillside and surrounding mountains increased the overall beauty
How do they do it?. Just how do all of those salt pansd get material from that little spring of salt water? Interesdting place for a quick tour.

Nice place to visit. We visited Salinas on June 26. It was a little bit overcrowded (probably because it was next day after Inti Raymi festivities). The place is amazing and it is working salt factory with people using the same method as hundreds years before. Instead of taking a tour we just hired a taxi in Cusco and visited Salinas, Morray and Chinchero. We spent about 6 hours on our way from Cusco to Olla with 3 main stop and many stopovers for vista and pics.
Must visit.. Beautiful landscape, very interesting excursion. I will recommend arriving early to beat the crowds, and don't forget to get some salt!

ATV ride to the Salt Mines. Did one of the 2 hour ATV tours to the Salt Mines and around the Sacred Valley. Got to the Salt Mines right before it closed at 5:00pm. Definitely a perk since our group were the only ones there making it a very intimate experience. Would recommend doing the ATV tour as the drive to this place has unbelievable views.

totally unexpected. A must for everyone visiting Cusco. We walked from the top of the salt mine to the bottom, crossing one salt field at a time. I was surprised to see that the mine was still being "farmed".

Neat Place to See!. We visited the salt mines as part of out ATV ride through the region. They were definitely near to see and a lot larger than expected! We had fun walking around them and seeing the pools in different salt stages. The tourist shops have everything imaginable with salt added if you want to indulge, we didn't but there was lots to choose from!

its a wonderful tours with plenty of vistas. if touring the southern highlands of peru is very tiring for old people like us we should advice the services of trans tours cusco as the best option for the trip among each main region attraction as we did recently.

Interesting . Strategically dig into the mountainside, thousands of shallow pools filled with salt water eventually evaporate and leave behind the crystallized salt. This process has been in practice for more than 500 years. There is well over 3000 small wells. We went on our own without a guide since we had a private driver for the day, so we just kinda explored around. We did see many smaller tour groups, but you could not hire anyone on the spot, you would have to arrange this ahead of time and go on an organized trip. We didn't feel we missed out on any real vital info by not having a guide, but it is a personal choice whether you want one or not.

Salt, Salt, Salt. Great stopover visit - good to have some kind of guide with you, or latch on to another group for an occasional explanation. Can be done well in 1hr. The ride down to it is impressive.

Incredible! One of our Sacred Valley Highlights!. I never expected to be so blown away! It is truly incredible and a must see in the Sacred Valley! As you approach the salt ponds, even from the distance it is quite something to see! It looks like a city!We walked all the way down to the salt ponds and took a stroll along the upper edge to almost the middle from where we were basically surrounded by them. They ponds differ in colour from white, pink, brown… Put your finger in one of the streams feeding the ponds and taste it – it is VERY salty and your finger will have salt crystals lingering on it afterwards. There are many stalls on the way between the car park and the salt ponds where you can buy salt and other souvenirs really cheap! I bought a pestle & mortar, hand made from granite for S/.20 – AUD8! Small bags of salt go for S/.0.50 each! Definitely allow yourself some time to shop here on your way back up to the parking area. They sell ice cold bottled water here for S/.2 The visit, including the hike up and down, takes about 45 minutes. If you want to shop at the stalls, allow at least 1 hour. If you’re only going to hike down to the edge of the ponds, spend 3 minutes taking photos and hike back up – as we’ve seen many people do - you’ll probably be able to do it in 15-20 minutes. I saw some toilets on the way back to the car park, but did not use them so can’t comment on the facilities Entry is S/.8 per person (if I remember correctly) and it is not included in the Boleto Turistico.Take a hat & wear sunscreen as once you’re through the stalls, you’re in the sun all the time. Don’t step inside the ponds!
Unexpected variety. A must visit if in the area. Since before the Incas families have been irrigating these pools. Truly fascinating. Go early in the morning before the crowds and strong sun!

Very pretty salt mines!. Worked as a cooperative by the citizens of Maras this is worth a trip for it's beautiful location and great views. Salt from these pools is highly recommended in some of the most chic establishments around the world and you can purchase some there if you'd like. It is best to combine with a visit to Moray Inka ruins which is very close by...you can do it on tour from Cusco or you can take a collectivo from cusco going through Chinchero to Urubamba and ask to be let off on the main road at the entrance to Maras...plenty of taxis at the junction can take you to see both sites.

Incredible Incan salt mine site, still producing salt today. This is a working historic site originally built by the Incas to produce salt. Today, you can see descendants still working the mine and harvesting salt from the tiered ponds. Be sure to stop at the overlook pull-off on the road in for a birdseye view and photo.

Unique salt works. The 2000 salt pans provide a unique tourist attraction and source of income for those who work them. They are fed by a highly saline stream originating from deep within the mountain from an ancient seabed. The pans are highly concentrated with minimal separation between them and reliant on evaporation to alllow for the removal of pure pink or white salt which is widely marketed. A well worthwhile visit in the Sacred Valley.

A must tour in the sacred valley. You are driven through the valley to the saltpans of Maras (Salineras de Maras), dramatic terraces with pools in different shades of brown and white, capturing water from a salty spring and sealing it off until the water evaporates - a method of salt extraction used since antiquity.
