As the terraces are on the side of the mountain, salt stalactites form where the salt has dripped down. Each pool is owned by a different family who collects the salt as it dries and sells it.

Beautiful salt pools in the middle of the mountains. Those are amazing, mostly for the view. You can buy their salt if you feel like it, but in the end, salt is salt. I don't think you'll find it tastes different than other salts.After seeing so many ruins, it was really nice to see something different.There's a little river there that brings the salted water; it's worth a try to dip your fingers in and taste the water.

AMAZING. This is a MUST SEE if you're in Cusco. We went with a tour and he explained how the salt is extracted and it is so interesting!! There's stalls where you can buy salt from the Salina and I had to stop myself from buying everything! The view when you stand at the edge.. breathtaking. Well worth your time.
So beautiful!. This was a very interesting experience. I have never even heard of salt being extracted this way. The history and information given by our guide was awesome. A sight to see for sure!

Worth your time. This is a little bit out of the way, but worth the extra time and hassle. These salt mines are incredible and have a beautiful view of the Sacred Valley. So glad we went here thanks to our private guide and transportation

Something very rare to see!. And - it really is beautiful when you stand at the edge and just look at the vast landscape of salt vats! The 5,000 vats each show a slightly unique color despite all being one essential product - salt. In use since the time of the Incas, the colonial town of Maras greatly benefits from the ponds as well as tourism.

Mind boggling!. We visited the salt mines as part of our Sacred Valley tour and were blown away. It's difficult to believe that these thousands of salt mines are man-made. It's a fantastic site. You can buy salt and other products from the pans from the many stalls at the site. Definitely worthwhile to visit.

Interesting!!. This was part of a tour that included Moras Moray. I will say that all the tours we took besides the Cusco city tour all went out toward the Sacred Valley, so you spend a lot of time on a bus and cover much of the same territory.
Truly a sight to behold.. The pictures I took here are stunning. I brought this salt home for my chef hubby he is more than pleased.

Salt mines. Took a cab ride from Yucay, 120 soles round trip and driver remains at the mines. Spent 1.5-2 hours at mines plus 30-40 mins each way driving. Fascinating how they collect the water and dry the salt. There is a mountain trail towards end of mine complex.

Well Worth the Trip!. Salinas de Maras was included in our Sacred Valley Tour. We toured the salt mines for almost an hour which was not enough. But the history and sights here are Beautiful! We took the road from Moray to Salinas de Maras which was very interesting. The mines were not very crowded which was nice, but we had the opportunity to walk around and explore the salt mines for a while. I think there are 2,500 flats here and they are all still being used. There are three colors, white, pink, and brown, all have their unique uses. If you are into photography, this is a great place for it! Almost every steps is a picturesque photo! It does get hot here, so dress accordingly. There is a small market here to where you can shop. Overall, I recommend making Salinas de Maras a stop while touring the Sacred Valley.
Picturesque!. Tour doesn't last long but definitely worth a look and a few photos. Quite impressive what they have done here.
Visit. Great place to see but what a hairy road down to them and back up. Again more walking but there is a cafe when you get back up.

Interesting place to visit while going to Machu Pichu. The Salinas look stunning, great opportunity for beautiful pictures.I would advise you to go with a guide so that you can get an explanation on how where the Salinas formed, the Incan times, etc etc. Too many tourist shops, but apart from that it was well worth it.

Interesting. We take ATV tour for Maras and Moray, the natural beauty is magnificent; there's a small fair that sells organic salt and products with super low prices than other places.Important : bring sunscreen, water to hydrate and you have to walk and climb stairs , don't try to wash your hands or take water from the mines it will leave you white because of the salt and give you much more thirst.

Worth a visit. It was very crowded with buses and people, however I can't imagine not visiting. Creating the pans with dammed earth to allow the salty mountain water to evaporate made for an interesting and picturesque site. The beauty in the simplicity of using naturally occurring forces in addition to their industriousness was once again a marvel.

There are also markets there that sell salt in bags and sell products with their salt. We took a tour that was sold near the Western Union in the Plaza de Armas. Enough time to see everything, take beautiful pics and also shop in the market

Never seen anything like this. Most interesting place to visit and learn the history of these unusual salt "mines". We had a guide who told us much about how these mines have been owned and operated over the centuries.

Coolest place ever. I enjoyed my day here. I started off quadding here from quite always away. The salt pans are way bigger than I expected and the guide was very interesting. My group leader is actually from Maras so his family owns some pans there and was very knowledgeable and loved showing us around the place. I would definitely come back.

Amazing!. My first sighting of the Salinas de Maras was that of amazement - all those salt beds! My tour was interesting and we even saw a woman minding her salt bed. Tasting the water from the spring made me understand just how salty the water coming from the mountain is.

Visited on Quads. We loved the salt mines, and especially enjoyed the experience of taking quads to get there and other sites in the area. It's amazing they were developed pre-Inca time, but so sophisticated in their construction. Very cool to see. It can get warm with little shade so be prepared with sunscreen and hats.

Salt Pans. This was a really cool place that is worth going to. The drive in is a little nerve wrecking but part of what makes the place cool. The natural salt water evaporates into salt and it makes for some cool pictures
Very interesting!. This was definitely a worthwhile excursion. A small amount of hiking to get a good view - learning about how it was built and process of making the salt was fascinating

The BEST thing we saw in Peru. Although there are many great Inca attractions we found this incredible. Inca families 700+ years later are still tending to these salt pools. Wear sunscreen! - I got a wicked burn from just roaming around the pools for 20 mins. They let you walk around and on top of the pools and you can hike right to the far end of the mountain. Amazing place!. Looks like a cross between a Star Wars set or a white slum city on the edge of a ravine. Interesting to learn of the salt harvesting process, plenty of stalls selling the produce as well.

Maras Salt Mines. We stopped at the Maras Salt Mines as part of a full Sacred Valley Tour with Action Peru Treks. Our guide was Savi and he did an excellent job teaching us about the culture and showing us ruins, local food - Cuy and Chicha, and explaining how the salt is harvested at the mines.

A must close to Cuzco. Beautiful place to visit near Cuzco. Beautiful. Beautiful place, definitely recommended. It's outside of Cusco so you have to book a tour with an agency or get a taxi (in May 2016 we payed 80 soles round trip and the driver waited for us to visit for as long as we wanted - but you don't need much more than 1 hour there). Gem. Its a wonder to see salt plant on so high altitude.
Beautyful to see white salt basins on brownish mountain its like a gem , it looks like it doesnot belong there , People have worked hard and long years to make it as it is!Love it

Interesting tour site. Interesting place to do a short visit.I think families would appreciate it as an educational experience. The patches of different shades of white are seen from above as you drive the gravel cliff side. We saw the spring where the water came from and learned the process by which eventually the collected liquid dries up and thus salt is harvested. Different products are made from this salt.Kids enjoyed learning and walking on the path.

Short visit to Salinas. Very visual and interesting area. Suggest going with a guide to learn about the history. Our guide, Juan Manuel Diaz Villasante, provided a lot of interesting information for our Sacred Valley Tour (booked through Andean Treks.

Beautiful!. This salt terraces give fantastic landscape. I was impressed how Incas built unusual site to get salt. It was funny that driver of our tour team lost the way to get there, which means this site is not a must see spot, but I enjoyed very much.

Nice Short Tour. Interesting and educational experience to see how salt is harvested from these mines. STAY ON THE PATH. We saw so many rude tourists jumping from terrace to terrace vs staying on the path. These mines belong to hardworking people.
Interesting side trip on way to Urubamba. They are a series of flats used to dry the salty water coming from the earth, a side business for local farmers.

Fascinating place; beautiful views!. How amazing is God's creation--salt water comes out of the mountainside. It's interesting how the people have "pooled" the water so that the salt forms and then is harvested. The ride from the main road to the salt flats can be a little scary as it's quite curvy for part of the way. But put your fears aside & go see this place!
Cool tour. It was interesting to see how they extract the salt from the water. Also most of these ponds are owned by separate families.. lots of interesting salts to buy too
For photographers a must. Our photos from the Salinas de Maras are among the most spectacular of our entire journey accross Peru, Bolivia and Chile. Go and take your time!

Amazing view, scary drive. I had no idea how salt was "mined" and visiting here was fascination. The ride there was full of hairpin turns. The view is amazing. We saw some people working their mines or plots. They are communally owned and no family can sell to an outsider. The gift shop had a great collection of products derived from the salt that was mined there.

A unique experience: well worth the visit. OK, so we had a little adventure. We took a colectivo to Maras and hiked from the town to the salt mines.Boy, was it amazing. You get a good view of the Andes and a new appreciation for nature. The locals said it's just one beaten bath, so we thought we can't get lost. Well, you CAN get lost, but don't worry. there are a few locals and farmers around who you can ask directions. The view from the top of the hill as you descend is breathtaking. Try the snacks sold outside the mines. They are tasty!The mines are quite pretty and you can walk between each section. It was unfortunate to see some people writing their names in the salt. We then hiked down further to the Rainbow Bridge( Punta Arco de Iris) and stopped a colectivo going from Ollantaytambo to Cusco.Over all this was great!!!

Great place, views and history. We visited with our young adult kids. We all loved it. The scenery is amazing. We took awesome pictures. They have many different kinds of salts for cooking and for bathing.

interesting place . well, I the Salinas is not included in the boleto turístico. u most pay to get in private property, to use the toilet u also have to pay 1 sole and theres a lot of stores there to sell artisans work and salt. the view is nice, but but that's all
A must!. It's an incredible place to visit! We were shocked when we arrived there. I really suggest to visit and I also suggest you to bring with you water and hat if I very sunny day!

Looks like snow from afar. This is in Maras, about 45 mins to 1 hr from Cusco, about 45 mins from Ollantaytambo... a bit of a detour off the road between Ollantaytambo and Cusco. A very interesting site, from afar, it looks like snow on the terraces; turns out it is salt. It is an interesting landscape. Taking a walk onto the terraces is an interesting experience to see how the salt is "mined" - taste (don't drink!) the spring water - you will find that it is warm and very salty! It is interesting to look at the terraces but it becomes more relevant if one understands the process of "mining" the salt from the salty spring water. Generally, if I understand it correctly, the terraces are filled with the salty water, after which the input is stopped - the water is evaporated over a period of 3 to 5 days(?) leaving behind a layer of salt (maybe 10mm thick?). They then break up the salt insitu, and refill the terrace with the salty water again. Water is again evaporated, and the process is repeated a few times till the salt reaches the required thickness. Generally there will be 3 layers of salt - the bottom-most layer is not for human but for animal consumption - the middle layer is pinkish and has the highest grade, and the top layer is regular salt. Each layer is washed separately and the middle layer is iodized; then they are packed and sold accordingly. The process takes about 1 month to complete. (or something like that).Lastly, apparently this process is known to the Incans, but these terraces do not date back to the Inca days - apparently these terraces date back to the 1950's if my sources are correct.
Interesting to see!. I love salt. I loved seeing where it comes from and what it takes to make. Great little shops too, the salt makes a nice gift

Well worth a visit to see this Unusual & Surprising Landscape. This unusual place is very different from most other landscapes you'll encounter and well worth a visit. The salt production apparently dates back to pre-inca times and is still happening.We visited here as part of the Moray Maras tour which we arranged at Liz's Explorer for 30 Sol each, not including the Boleto Touristico that you'll need to get in.

Ensure your guide takes you into the Salt terraces!!. If you just look at these salt mines - they are interesting but.... You need to ensure your guide is able to take you through the terraces. You learn how the salt mines work, the labor that is needed, the process of how they extract the salt over a period of time. Super fascinating!! Highly recommend but only if you spend time to explore and walk through the terraces.

Wow!!. A part of our trip was visiting Maras. A salty spring comes out of the mountain here... and the peoples thought about it, than they did like 3.000 terraces in which the water is rested till evaporate. Behind remain the salt, pure and simple.Great achievement of ancient people of Peru!!
A unique experience!. This was an amazing place, quite unique! A saltworks that has functioned since Incan days. A bit out of the way but well worth the visit if you're visiting the Sacred Valley

Worth the trip . In the middle of a the countryside the salt mines are worth the trip for sight seeing. Make sure you get to understand how the community operates as this is a part of genuine Peru. Tourist market around the village is cute and worth exploring too. It is not a must see, but certainly a nice to see!Up to you

Maras. The drive alone is worth the time. The beauty of the mountains, valley overlooks, wheatfields that touch the clouds, different colored patchwork farm fields across the rolling hills is something out of a storybook. The salt pits are something I couldnt imagine without visiting. The manner in which the Levees are built into the landscape in such a low tec manner, the different shapes and sizes are strongly artistic and highly photogenic. I liked the old man that shuffled the salt with his feet. He must be included in the photo for it to be complete. The view from the road high above is unworldly. You should go.
Very interesting. This was very interesting and well worth the drive. We were able to purchase salt from the site as well as other products made with it eg chocolate and mixed spices.
A must see! . We really enjoyed the walk we took here! Definitely a place to see! The landescapes are just gorgeous and definitely worth the 30mn walk under 30°.

Exceeded Expectations!. Pictures dont do this place justice. We were all blown away by how large this place is! I recommend having a guide or a guide book to get a little information about the mines. If you dont have one of these things it's still really neat but you lose out on the details.

Salt Pools. Visiting Salinas de Maras was quite an event for my grandson, 9 years old. After climbing down the steps, you see the various pools where the water evaporates and salt is collected. It is a quite large operation. The water to fill the pools comes from an artisan spring from deep in the earth. You may taste the salty water that comes from it.

Off the beaten path...sort of...a must see!. I was mesmerized by the terraces that seemed to go on and on and on. We stayed on Ollantaytambo and hired a driver to take us here. Definitely worth the trip!

Go by horseback!. I did a half day horseback to the Salineras and it was wonderful! We rode in through the back so the pictures look pristine and we got to see local workers. Bring money so you can buy their various healing salts, and lotion if you plan to dip your finger in the water because your skin will chap. Also the bathroom is one sole. Overall, beautiful spot!

Oldest and coolest system of Salt production. We tooka a 1/2 day tour of Maras and Moray from Cusco through a guided tour arranged by our hotel Torre Dorada. These intricate evaporation ponds have been operating since Incan time. The guide explained how well the salt water is channeled from a stream into these various working ponds. A little bit of walk to the ponds and you can walk around the ponds too. Few small shops around here, local selling souvenirs.

Awesome site!. Saw Maras as part of a day tour from Cuzco, and it was an incredible site! It was cool to be able to see something so unique. However, it was sad that people were walking all over privately owned plots of land without any kind of direction or people ensuring that tourists stayed on the path.

interesting. This was an interesting side trip - cool to see how they did, and still do, make salt by evaporation of the run-off water. i would not make a whole trip just to see this, but it was linked to a sacred valley tour so worthwhile.

Very interesting day visit and landscape. The salinas were super interesting to visit for me! We did a day tour and stopped by a llama fabric place on our way, which was very interesting but overpriced.

Owned by licals. What an interesting spot if you want to arn an unusual way to make different types if salt. The water from the springs in this location is filled with all sorts of elements on the periodic table.

Salt!. An impressive site. Went via half day tour so slightly rushed.
Functioning salt mine for 7 months of the year with shops. Worth a visit.
Interesting and nice!. With our personal guide Oliver it was very interesting to know and understand the Salinas de Maras. Of course we brought a lot of salt back home! ;)

One of My Fav- Impressive Views (Pictures) of the Salt Fields. This place is hard to get to without a tour or hiring a private car, but it's totally doable when combined with Moray and totally worth it!!!! You can see how salt is provided in Maras (people are working there all the time), and walk through the salt fields. It's fun for kids and adults alike. And don't forget to bring home some salt as gifts. There's not too much shades so be prepared. Bathroom costs $1 sole but it's pretty clean.

Fascinating site...... My first visit to anything quite like this.... very interesting site.....!! Lots of opportunities to buy local goods surrounding the site as well. Not a bad hike from this location back down to Urubamba area.

Amazing place!. Amazing views, I bought pink salt with minerals, very recommend it. I took a taxi, I can recommend Eduardo Quispe, he took us to Maras, Moray, Chincheros, Pisac and Cusco city,it was the best way to see these places by ourselves. You must pay to enter the site, touristic ticket doesn't include this site, you must pay I think 10 soles per person.

Definitely worth a stop. If you are going or coming to Machu Picchu spend the extra time to see this & Moray on your way up or down.We hired a driver from our hotel in Olly & the fare was $65USD but that included stops here & Moray & drove us from Olly to Cusco. We felt it was worth the price to go at our own pace.The salt ponds were extremely crowded with hordes of tour buses. It’s an easy walk down into it but a steep 15 minute walk back up.We found them fascinating & I think it’s worth the time to stop.If you like my review, I hope you'll click the 'helpful' button; those of us who write reviews live for those and it motivates us to do more.
Worth a visit . We did a private day tour of the sacred valley and this was part of it. I found this the most interesting stop. It is very unique. It helps to have an informative guide.

Must visit!. If you visit cusco during dry season, May to August, please go and visit this place! Gigantic Salt mine with beautiful white color! Although tourist ticket cannot cover the entrance fee, I would say this is the best tourist attraction around cusco! You can purchase the salt from the mine too! Do not miss amazing view of sacred valley from the salt mine!

Very cool day trip from Cuzco. I liked the salt flats because it was something different from the massive amounts of Incan ruins you will see. We used llama path tour group for our trip and had the best time. Very impressive way to mine salt on the side of a mountain!

A definite highlight. This was amazing to see so try to include it as a must see day trip experience. We hired a driver for the day through KB Tours and we could customize our trip and we found the salt mines well worth the stop. You can purchase the salt as an easy souvenir to take home!

Salt fields from subterranean spring. We visited Maras salt fields on May 29, 2016. It is 90 minutes drive from Cusco. It is a private site and is not covered the the Boleto Touristico. We were there about noon and it was very crowded. It is a working salt production site which uses subterranean saline spring to produce salt by evaporation. The salt fields are on the side of a mountain.

Interesting spot near Cusco, but can be skipped if it's rainy season. If you go on the rainy season, the white salinas will be all brown and the workers will not be active there. It only still worthy the visit if you wanna have an idea of how does it work and taste the very salty water coming from the underground. If it's rainy season and you have short time, it can be easily skipped.

Fascinating!. The salt pans of Maras are so interesting! At the time of our visit, families were just cleaning out their pans so they could be flooded. It is quite an operation and it is amazing to think it is thousands of years old. A word of caution, walking on some of the narrow walks can be difficult as they are often covered in salt crystals.

A bit of the beaten path but worth a visit. It was great visiting the salt mines tucked away in the mountains. It is definitely strange to find such a concentration of salt so far away from the coast. A small stream supplies all the water/salt to the area and families maintain their own small plots. There are some souvenir shops here that have very reasonably priced items. I purchased Alpaca shoes and saw the same shoes in Cuzco for 3 times what I paid for them at the salt mines.

Fascinating and worth a visit. A travel agent arranged tours for my wife and I during our stay in Peru. On our first day in the Sacred Valley, we visited the salt pans at Maras. The history of the salt mines (salt pans) was interesting. The process for recovering salt from the salty stream was intriguing and fascinating. I think it's helpful to have a knowledgeable guide to get a better appreciation of the salt pans.

Loved it!. This places almost looks like another planet! The salt terraces are all owned by the people of the town so it's kind of like a salt cooperative. It's very interesting to see and makes for some unique photos! I would recommend going!

A salty experience!. Walking shoes are necessary because of the climbing involved. Beautiful panoramic views so a camera is necessary. Interesting benefits of salt and an opportunity to buy salt products that are coveted in the world wide market for its health benefits.

Very different and thoroughly enjoyable. A bit a hike from the parking lot. but the salt mines are unique and, from my perspective, a must-do as it's a wonderful contrast to the very terrace'y ruins that often look very similar...

Impressive setting for this interesting place. The guide we had was fairly generic, so I wouldn't say I learnt loads about it, but it was interesting to hear how the site is used by the local communities, and it is so visually interesting with a valley and snow covered mountain in the background. There is a shopping centre on site, the salt is cheap but there is plenty more too. The bars of chocolate were innovative flavours and in fancy packaging - great for presents. Glad I came.
Nice authentic place.. We came here by bicycle and really enjoyed.The salt pools are impressive and there are a lot of them.It costs 10 soles to enter.

Amazing Sight within Day Drive of Cusco. We booked with Viajes Cusco Perú for a Sunday morning day trip to the Salt Flats of Maras. The flats are beautiful and a reminder of how rare salt is to find in nature. You need to pay 10 soles (May 2016) for entrance in addition to the cost of the driver and English speaking tour guide. In total this day trip was ~30 soles +5 soles for Inkal Sal! The roads are switchbacks and my travel friend became car sick on the ride back to Cusco. Our visit to Maras was paired with a trip to Moray, and we only had 30 minutes to visit the site with Viajes-Cusco-Peru travel. We left from Cusco at 8:40 and returned around 14:30. Bring sun-screen, sun hat, and motion-sickness medication with you if you feel car sickness! Overall very beautiful and worth the trip.

Short visit. Pretty cool to see these pools on the side of a mountain. Walked through and watched all the workers with traditional practise. A bunch of small shops where you can buy gifts like hand made books, the salt from the pools etc. Definitely recommend. Went as part of the quad biking tour.
Salt flats. You have to see this place. Very interesting. Enjoyed learning about the process. We walk back to town & it was a nice hike

Fascinating example of Cuezan ingenuity still in use today. We hiked up the mountain from the base to view the salineras though it is much easier to take a bus to the top and walk down. We encountered local families on their way up to work in the salt pans, who were much swifter than us. These are salt pans that are worked in the same way that they have been for 600 years, perhaps more. A saline spring is diverted and the water is evaporated. The resulting salt is broken up and bagged for sale.
Amazing place !!. Very interesting tour, amazing place, we really enjoyed it. You can buy the salt naturally from there even the water runs salty.

Unexpected Feature of the Sacred Valley. We previously visited the Sacred Valley in 1981 but had missed a side trip to the salt flats of Maras. This year after a visiting the Inca terraces at Moray we walked down a trail leading to the Urubamba Valley and passing through the 4000 salt fields fed by a natural saline spring. The view from the trail of the salt fields is amazing.

Sal sal sal. Even if you're not a fan of salt, you'd be missing out not to go and marvel at the ancient Inca salt reserves in the Sacred Valley. You can even stick your finger and try some, it's delicious! On a hot, dry day, the views are stunning, especially by car on the way along the hair-raising ravine edges. Gotta buy a little bit of salt while you're there too :) Tours depart daily from Cusco, you can find them around the Plaza de Armas.

Incredible!. This is a great 60-90minute side trip. The views are incredible, never seen anything quite like this! The walk down from the parking lot has stairs and an uneven path for about 10 minutes, not terrible though. They have markets where you can buy packets of salt (do it!). We had our own guide, but I didn't see any guides at the site. The history of the place and the fact that its still mined in the same way is awesome.

Amazing. We hiked from Morey to the salt pools in Maras. A beautiful walk through amazing landscape where we saw people farming and herding. Our first sight of the salt pools was almost surreal. Seeing how they harvest the salt was an amazing experience.

Fascinatingly simple. Wow! Such an interesting stop. Beautiful to look at and plenty of shopping to be done. Salt is sold on site (at similar prices across vendors). If visiting Cusco, Maras salt can also be found in the food market there. The canal system used to to fill the many pools of beautifully simple. Lots of steps but doable if you take your time.

Fascinating site, still in active use. There are so many ruins to see in the Sacred Valley that it is refreshing to find an inca site still in active use today and such is Salinas de Maras. There is a collective that still collects the salt from this fascinating site where water from a spring (that is 60% salt apparently) still flows across a series of over 5000 pools where evaporation lets miners collect and then sell the salt. The site is impressive as you descend from the hills - blazing white against the brown of the surrounding mountainsides.The stream is fast flowing and there is an interesting system of channels to move the water where is needed by a series of gates. It really is fascinating and you can freely walk out there on crunchy paths of salt. There is a small charge but it is worth it and you can walk a long way out. As always with Inca sites there is walking and climbing to get there but not much for this site. There are the ubiquitous market stalls to walk through but very non-aggressive stall holders which has been a common theme here in Peru.Salt is for sale of course! We were there in the afternoon and it was sunny and pretty warm and of course, no shade. You won't be here that long but apply sun screen! Well worth a visit, makes a fascinating change from Inca ruins.
amazing. Def worth going if you are around cusco area. It is amazing with 300+ salt pools with different color.
Awesome. This is a must see when you are in sacred valley. The water is pretty salty don't forget to taste it.

very interesting salt proccesing process. Surely worth the detour to visit. Interesting to see how they process and build the salt pools. We bought some salt, it's cheap and pretty good. Thee are nice restrooms and food and water to buy.

Interesting piece of history/culture. Went via a tour and it was interesting. The tour company was ok as I booked with the Hostel I stayed at. Guide provided a good history but definitely was lacking a key detail I overheard from another tour company that had been there the same day.

So amazing!. A must if your in the sacred valley! We passed here on our way to La Escondida in Urubamba, so gladd we did. You can buy local mined salts, chocolate and walk the salt pans that stretch over the mountainside!

Important to see. Definitely worth the trip. It gives a good idea of what the Incas and the Peruvian use of their natural resources.It's a good idea to buy the different types off salt.You can also see the locals working.

Not What I Expected!. Very interesting, but not something I would go out of my way to see. It's rather a tourist trap. You walk through vendors to get to the salt pans then back through them again with all of them trying to sell you the same thing.

MUST see. This was one of the coolest things I've ever seen, and well worth the effort to get there. I visited with a guided tour group, but there are many other options if that is unappealing. You do not need a guide, just do your reading on the area beforehand and prepare to be amazed.
Great afternoon trip from Cusco. I took a local bus to get here. Spent an afternoon walking around here. Great place to visit while you are in cusco.

OH my Gosh, A great Day!. Ah wao, The salt flats are so interesting and not what I was expecting. I took a day trip with a local tour operator and had a blast!
The guide was so incredible explained all about the history and about Maras, 10 out 10!
Highly recommend if you go to Cusco!

Those amazing Incas. This is difinately worth a visit. Not an underground mine but terraced wells that are filled with salty spring water, allowing evaporation. Our guide said there were more than 5, 000 pools, worked for generations. Even if the salt isn't of interest, the drive there is magnificent.

Amazing and a very different experience. I rode to this place on a horse but you can hike up or go by car/bus.
The view is amazing and the salt flats are very different and unexpected. A good place to purchase local bath or cooking salts.
Worth the Trip. The salt flats are interesting and not what I was expecting. Take a finger lick of the water - you will be surprised how salty it is.

Must see!!. You have to see this place....simply amazing!! Wonderful history and beautiful to see the layout of the salt pools like a patchwork quilt. We did the ATV tour to this area, and it was worth it!

Wow! Such a fascinating place!. We split a week between Ollantaytambo and Cusco before hiking the Inca Trail. The day we transitioned from Ollanta to Cusco we hired a guide to drive us and make stops along the way; Las Salineras was our favorite stop. We bought flavored local salt packages for friends and family and are enjoying them ourselves. Recommended!

Not good for cycling, but ok to hike. Very interesting to hike., but not the best place for mountain biking which is what one of the bike tour companies had us do. It's too steep and rocky for tourist cycling, but the place was interesting

ATV Ride in the Sacred Valley. I booked an ATV tour in to the Sacred Valley and this was one of our stops. The Salt Pans near Maras were an amazing sight! We took a winding road down that had no rails and steep drops. Once there, you paid 10 soles to explore the Salt Pans. There are paths above, and through, the salt pans so you can get right up close to inspect all the interesting pools and streams feeding in to them etc. Very cool place and photographs very well!

Interesting. Very interesting site. Unfortunately the salts had been contaminated by torrential rains which meant the salts are unusable which was also very interesting.I would recommend a stop. Also a great place to purchase local bath or cooking salts.

Something different.. Something different. The vast size is impressive and the method is interesting. There are plenty of vendors selling all kinds of salts and some beers if you want to sit in the sun and take it in.

Fascinating look at Inca salt mining.. The ancient salt terraces used to collect salt from salty mountain stream are truly visually impacting. Walking through the terraced salt ponds very interesting. A very worthwhile visit.

Incredible, interesting and informative. The drive is lengthy but so worth it. You will learn a lot about the Peruvian people and their amazing abilities - in this case the ingenuity to devise terraces to collect salt. While I had never thought about how salt is obtained, this is certainly an interesting way. These terraces are handed down from generation to generation and at times the plots are split dependent on the children in a family.There are flavorful salts for sale and with some negotiating you can purchase them for a decent price. You cannot get them for a more reasonable price anywhere else so do not leave without getting what you want! Make the time in your Cusco itinerary to visit Salinas de Maras.

Interesting . This was interesting. You see all the different salt mines. There's a store to buy different types of salt or other tourist gifts. I bought medicinal salt and used it when I returned home. Lots of leaves in the bag - eucalyptus possibly. I haven't used the pink or grilling salt yet.

Interesting site!. I really enjoyed seeing how the salt collection process took place. Our guide was amazing, so I think this made a big difference but still very interesting and we hiked through entire site and down into the nearby town. Definitely make sure that you buy the salt and Inca corn with the salt it was the best we bought in the country!
Salt! My favorite food group!. This is a testament to the global salt market. Distinctive flavors of salt are available for purchase.

An interesting place to see. We went to a local travel agency in Cusco and went on Maras, Moray day trip including this Salt Mine. It was a collective (a bus of about 30 people who also booked from other travel agents) and it cost 20 soles per person including transport and guide which lasted about 7 hours. To get into the mines, there is a 10 Soles entrance fee. This place was very nice to see. I have been to a salt pans before which was much, much smaller than this. What impressed me was the scale and at such a high altitude as well.

Great example of Peruvian Ingenuity. This expansive salt cultivation site is a prime example of how previous generations worked without the aid of machines. Excellent visit if you are interested in learning how salt was farmed/harvested by hand using an intricate system of cascading ponds.

Amazing views but steep climb. An amazing place to visit near to Moray. Huge evaporative salt pans in terraces set into a hillside. However there is a tricky climb up and down which would defeat any disability. However having seen mothers carrying babes in arms up and down the steep steps (many of them and no other way), it it the norm. Lots of shopping.

Very interesting. These are salt parcels that are family owned and worked. The salt comes from a river that they flood the parcels with and let the sun evaporate the water so that they can gather the salt. There are shops along the way where you can buy the salt. A very interesting place to visit.

Interesting Place. I have visited salt mines before, but never one with a spectacular view. The place looks beautiful and you can walk around the salt fields/mines. It was interesting to learn how they extract salt at such altitudes. Feel free to grab the roasted nuts on the way to mines. Unlike the other cities, this place didn't seem like a tourist trap and the visit was much more enjoyable after interacting with the locals.

Impressive Landscape. This is one of my favourite sites in the Sacred Valley. The view from the top as you approach is magnificent and the experience of walking in between the salt pools is out of this world. The water flowing down to the mines is warm and the landscape is truly unique. With the snowy peaks in the background, it makes for a surreal experience. Pro Tip: If you're continuing towards Ollantaytambo, walk all the way down to the river through the salt pools. At the bottom you are not far from a bridge were you can cross the river and continue your trip to Ollantaytambo via bus, car, or a long hike.

Not worth more than 15-30min. If you have never seen something like it just like us it was nice just to see and learn about the process. But after that there isn't much else to see or do. If this is on your way and you have a few mins to spare I would say it's worth it. Otherwise I wouldn't come out of my way for this.

Well that was unexpected in a great way!. We had no idea about the salt mines! In all our Peru research it never came up, weird as it's #2 on the site. This place ended up being some of the best local/flea market shopping on our trip, mixed with a great tour of something unique and wonderful. If you don't like narrow roads on high cliffs, try to get over it to get to this place. Close your eyes and trust your driver, it's worth it. So glad we stopped here!

Highly Recommended. We were floored by this site. The fact that naturally a occurring salt water stream (coming from a hole in a mountain) has been feeding salt ponds on the side of a steep mountain since Inca times is amazing. Great location.

Fascinated Such a Place Seems To Thrive in the 21st Century. You have to see this place! To see salt being harvested the same way it has been done for thousands of years is truly amazing. Our guides explained that each salt pond is owned by a separate family, but the "harvest" is sold cooperatively. We walked around for quite a while, fascinated that such place could exist and seemingly thrive in the 21st century.

Interesting. We made the mistake of visiting this the day after Machu Pichu and were pretty tired. It is very interesting and the different salts were good. Our guide had good connections with some of the vendors and gave us more information.
Worth a visit. Such a stunning contrast to the surrounding landscape. Bundle the salt mine into a day tour from either Cusco or the Sacred Valley.
Nice stop. If you are visiting the other sites in the sacred valley, this is worth a stop. The water is naturally salt and the locals have been extracting the salt this way for centuries.

Cool to see. This is a cool place to stop at but isn't necessary to make a special trip here. We went while on an ATV trip and it was a cool place to walk around and see. If you have the time and can get here, go, but there isn't much to do other than see the salt mines and leave.

Spectacular.. I was recommended by the Hotel as a picturesque couple of hours to see the Cusco salt pans. I took a local taxi for around $ US 50 return and the journey was around 90 minutes. The view en route was excellent with snow capped mountains and colourful landscapes. The flats themselves are unique and an interesting escape from the bustle of Cusco. You can walk on the flats and also purchase Andes salt for that extra special bath. Entry is 10 Peru dollars. Worth a trip

??? Salt in the Andes???. Yes, some while ago ;-) it was a sea. An underneath little stream is the cause of this all. It was a challenge going down with the car coz of all the big busses going up and down. They should do something about the road coz it's dangerous. Can't imagine the traffic jam in high season (June, July, August, September). But you can make arty pictures down there.

Worth a trip to Maras. The salt pans are a fascinating phenomenon - when viewed from afar they look interesting, but being able to walk among them is really amazing. Great story behind them and fantastic photo opportunities. Vendor stalls in the area are very reasonably priced.

Amazing but steep climb.. Very interesting site, steep rocky climb both ways (in fact we didn't go all the way down). Watched local people working with the salt. Many salt products at kiosks along the route, including the locally made chocolate. Cheaper here than in town. Worth a short visit, but the views from the top road are equally amazing.

Salinas de Maras. This place is one of a kind, pools and pools of salt mines in terrace style positions. Our tour guide said that any Peruvian family can have a share in there as long as they clean the place & make salt pools, then they will be the owner of that certain pool/s for free.

Way cool!. This has been taking place here since Roman times! Local families each own several of these "pools" and they maintain them. Pay particular attention to the maze work of streams that allow for the salty water from the mountain to flow into each of the tidal pools of sorts. The water leaves the mountain in a fairly warm state as it begins it's trek down the mountain or to the desired pools.

Very Interesting.. Salinas de Maras is really worth a visit, not only was the drive there very scenic but the views of the salt mines are impressive.Our tour guide was very knowledgeable and this added to the experience.The salt is available to buy and it is extremely cheap.

Neat place. Great stop as we toured the Cusco area. No one in our group had ever seen a salt pond so it was pretty neat to see how things work. There aren't any guides on site but we were part of a tour group so we got the overview of how things work. There are also some nice little shops to by salt, chocolates, etc.
Salt mines. So interesting - and huge!! Salts are amazing. Our guide was very informative, which added to the experience. Also, lovely gift ideas.

Interesting place to visit. This is in a great location near the Moray Rings, take the taxi over to the salt mines to see how the salt is formed and buy some inexpensive salt items. I purchased a large bag of medicinal salt for 15 soles! Downside is that if you go with a taxi and not a tour guide your left to your own devices on information about the formation of these mines
Stunning scenery. The drive to Salinas was beautiful although it was drizzling. The salt ponds are down a valley and are pretty impressive. They make for beautiful photos.

Interesting place, I highly recommend it. I was on the ATV tour and this was one of the stops. The entry is only 10 soles and it's well worth the money. There is also a small artisan market at this place where you can purchase snacks and different salts that were produced at this place.
Very interesting to see. Quite interesting to walk about and see. High mountain road to get there. A few small shops to walk thru and purchase salt.

Very interesting. What an amazing site! Incredible that such a place exists and thrives! It must be such hard work! The day we were there, there were only a few workers and they were far down in the valley. It is such dry, hot country side I cannot imagine working in such conditions all day long! The entire site is very awe inspiring.

A life experience!. The Salinas of Maras are located in the middle of the andes, far from the ocean but this part of the country used to be part of the ocean millions of years ago.Now there is a salty underwater river that flows to the surface a fill thouthands of pools that you can see in the mountain.Each pool belongs to a family and this is a way to get salt in the andes.The salt collected there is pink, not white and has too many minerals, buy a bag to take home.During the rainy season they are not so beautiful ( january till may) because they look a little muddy but when the the rain stops they become so white that they look like snow.It is an amazing place to visit, you have to think you are far from the ocean and you can find this amazing natural attraction.Don't look them just from the parking, walk down and take a lot of pictures in between the pools, you will have something to tell your friends about Peru.

Amazing sight!. The Salineras salt ponds should be a must-see on any tour of the Sacred Valley. Only 15 minutes from Urubamba, on the other side of the river, the salt ponds are nearly as amazing as some of the ruins in the area. A little touristy perhaps, but still fun to see a working salt pond terraced on the mountainside.

Interesting. These salt ponds are an interesting site because they are so old and is still active. A hot spring feeds the ponds and then the sun evaporates the water leaving a mildly salty slat. We bought several bags as gifts.

You won't believe it, so go see it. A novel way of harvesting salt in the middle of the mountains all made possible by a stream of water that is very salty, said to be the result of a seabed that was pushed up into the Andes millions of years ago. It's a manual process that doesn't seem to have changed for centuries. Worth having a look

You probably won't see something like this again. The salt pans are a sight to see. The hidden spring delivers water with 70 percent salt content. Try to go as part of a guided tour to get a better understanding of what you are looking at.

Salineras-salt terraces with English guide. I took a walking tour called Urubamba to Salt terraces organized by Inca Discovery Peru. After visiting the lovely town of Urubamba we took a local bus to the salt terraces. Keith, who has lived in the valley for several years gave a very informative guided tour of the area. These terraces have been in use since the Inca times. A salty spring emerges from the hillside, and the Incas cleverly built terraces capture the flows and harvest salt. In the rainy season, the pools fill with earth-toned water of varying hues, and in the dry season the water evaporates, leaving a plentiful salt residue to be harvested and sold.Definitely worth a visit if you want to see something a little out of the usual.

Interesting, but not a 'must see'.. We hired a guide from lamanitatravel.com.(great trusting company) Diego our guide was great! He drove us to these salt mines and also to Moray ( the circle terraces you see in photos) These places only except soles, not credit cards or dollars. The drive and these sites were fun and interesting but only go if you have time. This salt mine is at the end of a dangerous road. If you get car sick, this is not for you. Diego explained that the salt water comes out of the mountain naturally, but there is not much more than that. We were only at this site for about 20 minutes. I would probably skip it.

GREAT. Our guide made the visit more interesting than ever. Edward Bellota, look for him for a guide that is passionate and has great knowledge.Maras is an example of team work between the local families. You'll enjoy it

Interestin. We took a private tour from Cusco and enjoyed it. It's about 90 minutes drive and you usually to Moray then Maras. Interesting to see the salt pans. A lot of push to buy salt and snacks but that's everywhere in Peru. Moray is really interesting site from an agricultural point of view and the views are amazing

Salinas de Maras visit. While interesting, Salinas de Maras, does not compare to the beauty of the Andes Mountains and various Inca ruins. You must pass through an area of vendors before getting to the site. The vendors are not pushy and this is a real source of income for them, it does not add to the site.
Never saw anything like this on earth!. Very cool salt mines in the middle of no where. We biked here - not an easy ride but all downhill. Rock formations are amazing.

salty walk. Is a nice place to include in your visit. It is very interesting to see the process of salt recollection and family collaboration they have. It´s not well adapted for tourists so the road to get there is rather difficult and in the "ponds" you walk between ponds.

Very cool place. We watched the locals work the salt fields and what a tough job. Do not envy it all, very interesting stop on our tour. We bought some salt here for medicinal purposes and it really soothed our bodies in the tub

So Interesting. We have never seen anything like this before. We found it to be absolutely fascinating as it was so totally different - and so completely different from all the surrounding areas! Definitely worth a visit!
What a cool place to go!. This is a must see! So interesting what the Inca people started. It's a amazing. And the chocolate with salt they sell is delicious as the other salty nibbles!

Amazing!. What a fantastic site to visit. Tucked in a beautiful valley with a winding unpaved road leading to it the Salinas is a must for the photo enthusiasts. Such an interesting place and so photogenic. I'm very glad I decided to visit it and I highly recommend it as a day trip from Cusco specially if combined with Moray. Don't forget your camera!

Scary ride to an interesting site.. In a half a day trip (combined with another attraction) you go back in time to learn and see very unique way of producing salt. I wish it was not so touristy, but if you go to the very end, you can have some "people-free" time and pictures. On the way back on the bus - sit on the site behind the driver for good photos or on the opposite with your eyes closed if exposure bothers you.

Another must see in Peru. A huge salt mine carved out of the hillside, with terrace after terrace of mini salt-pans spread out in front of us. we get there as part of an ATV trip to Maras and Moray, was a great experience to see how a complete town live from the salt they get from this place generation after generation
Ancient Technique. Interesting display of techniques to harvest salt, when salt was an extremely rare and valuable commodity. Also of interest is how they are now marketing their unique product.
Cool site to visit! Great place to eat for lunch!. Had a great day at Salinas de Maras! Amazing photo ops and Llama Burgers!!!! Nice shopping and interesting history to learn about!
moray & salt mines. the best place and quite, we love all nature esceneries a native comunities nearby and all the culture of this country, just amazing.

Great excursion! Scary Ride. When we traveled to the salt mine this was great. It looks like a bee hive from up top. You must have to have good balance not to fall into the pools. Also going down the step be careful were you step. Remeber to bring money to buy salt products they sell. They are place at a good price.

So interesting!. Our hotel (Aranwa Sacred Valley) arranged for a driver (Rene) who spoke a little English to take us for $73. We stopped on the side of the road as we descended to the entrance for a great pic. He stayed at the entrance and we went on our own. We had read up on the process earlier so we understood a little of how the salt was managed. A driver/ guide would have been better. It was 10 soles each to enter. We were on a gate 1 tour and didn't want the early tour departure; so this worked out fine for us and for less money. For 2 people: $108 with gate 1 and $79 with Rene ( including entrance fee) It would have been less to share taxi with 2 more people. It took a little over 3 hrs to see the Salt mines and the Moray. Both were so interesting!

salt puddles in the middle of the Andes. This was a place I was intrigued to explore, because you can obtain there salt at an altitude above 3000 Mts. of the sea level and far away from the coast. You can obtain white, rose or brown salt. You can use it for cooking (white and rose) or for therapeutic uses (the brown one). This place is running since Inca times (500-600 years).

good trip. very interesting place and very beautiful scenery to get here.
They do have a place where you can get some food and a hot or cold drink should you need anything.
as with all things Peru, a lot of walking is involved
don't forget to buy some salt.
Fabulous place. I went here as part of a 4x4 quad adventure day. We parked at the top worked our way down looking at the pools.

Cool to see - pretty straightforward quick visit. Worth seeing if it's along the way as it's a quick, easy stop. It isn't exactly a salt "mine" as the salt is essentially created using the sun as a drying method.
Interesting place. Very interesting and picturesque place. Learnt how salt is produced and also a little bit about lives of the mines workers.

Loved this place . Worth the visit :) the salinas de maras are amazing! You really get to see the effort that the people invest every day there ! Also buy some salt , is great for cooking or bathing !

Amazing!. Up in the mountains of Cusco, there is a hot salt water seeping out of the earth from an ancient ocean. 2016 Peru Salinas de Maras or The Salt Pools. Salt is a necessity of life and while there are a number of ways to harvest it, the Salt Pools at Salinas de Maras is perhaps the most unusual. Salt can be mined, scraped off dry seabeds or as a byproduct of distillation. Since pre-Inca times, salt has been obtained in Maras by evaporating salty water from a local subterranean stream. The highly salty water emerges at a spring, a natural outlet of the underground stream. The flow is directed into an intricate system of tiny channels constructed so that the water runs gradually down onto the several hundred ancient terraced ponds. As water evaporates in the sun-warmed ponds, the water becomes supersaturated and salt precipitates as various size crystals onto the inner surfaces of a pond's earthen walls and on the pond's earthen floor. The pond's owner then closes the water supply off and allows the pond to go dry. Within a few days they carefully scrape the dry salt from the sides and bottom of the pool and puts it into a suitable container for removal and distribution. Then the process starts all over again.If you have 1/2 a day in Cusco to spare, this is a fascinating side trip.

Strikingly scenic. A scenic and interesting side trip in the Sacred Valley. The steep valley slopes are rust brown covered with coarse scrub, making the bright white salt ponds all the more striking.Since pre-Inca times, salt has been obtained in Maras by evaporating salty water from a local subterranean stream, which surfaces as a trickling spring.The salt ponds are less than 3 feet square in area, & none exceeds 12 inches in depth. All are shaped into polygons.The flow of water is carefully controlled & monitored by the workers. When the pond's keeper closes the water-feeder notch, the water evaporates under the equatorial sun within a few days. After which, the salt is carefully scraped from the sides & bottom of the pond, put it into large bags & hand carried up the slopes to be brought to market. Then the water-supply notch is reopened, & the process starts anew. The pale pink salt bolsters the Peruvian economy being shipped worldwide to meet the rising demand for salt on highways as well as being used by Peruvian chefs for its unique pink color & flavor.

One of the best excursions we have ever taken. The salt ponds/terraces of Maras are NOT to be missed. I feel so very grateful to have seen this wonderful site. Breathtaking. Our guide also included a 2KM walk up to the site vs being driven to the location. The walk up requires you to be in shape - and altitude acclimation necessary but walking through the small community at the base of the mountain is an extra added treat.

Salt ancient and now. Not nearly as beautiful or moving as other Inka ruins--but this hillside of salt flats, which was certainly a source of Inka power, is still producing salt in the same way that it did before the Spanish conquest. It is a strange and astounding site, these shallow pools slowly evaporating. Very interesting to walk between the pools and gather a few crystals.

You won't believe it. I think there are over 4000 salt ponds, all at various stages of evaporation. We hiked from the top of the ponds all the way down to the valley, taking about 90 minutes. Great place!

Still a pretty secret wonder !!!. This place is not that famous and is amazing! Not as many tourist wonder around the salt mine so you can take awesome pictures for a relatively cheap price. Also I don't know if this is good or not but you can wonder around, go up and down the mine and pretty much do as you please and discover this wonderful place. You can even purchase some salt too. Btw you can take a cab for S./50 to both Salinas and Moray. Don't pay more.
Must go place. Really cool place to be in! Unique!Pictures are looking great, and you can taste the salty water as well..

Impressive view. Downhill in the deep canyon to the valley where Maras is located, these salinas offer a great view and allow very nice photography. In the stalls you can buy Maras Salt, the rosy one highly recommended for cooking.

Interesting!!. It was quite interesting to watch the salt pans on a mountainside and being able to walk between them. The drive up there from Urubamba brought in motion sickness for me. But whenever I could open the eyes, the scenery is breathtaking and I thought the town of Maras was very interesting with groups of people walking around in traditional attire. I have seen salt pans before on flat lands but this is definitely the best one.

Amazing experience. You will not find this anywhere also! is a very unique experience. Those ancient salt ponds are in a mountain and you can walk and experience them very closely! keep in mind is far from Cusco and you will spend quite a short time there.
Great to visit. We were originally not going to go here as we only had three days. I am glad we did. Absolutely enjoyed it. We booked through Tikariy and John was our guide. Wow best guide ever

Very unique experience!. These ancient Inca salt evaporation ponds are something you have not likely seen anywhere else. We visited here as part of a mountain bike tour. The ponds are amazing! There's a stream of quite warm salt water coming out of the mountain that is channeled to create thousands of small ponds. The water evaporates, creating a bed of salt which is gathered typically by families who own the pond. We observed a couple of family groups, including small children, beating the salt to break it up so it could be harvested. The ponds are closer to Maras, which is above the town of Urubamba. The whole system of ponds is quite amazing and visually impressive. You shouldn't miss them if you're visiting the Sacred Valley.

Interesting to see but not much else to do. The salt mines are interesting to see, but not much else to do there. We stayed for ~15 minutes, took a buch of photos and left. Not sure it's worth the day trip from Cusco.

Interesting place . The salt mines are beautiful. You'll want to do this with a guid or at least learn more about it before you go, as simply visiting the mines with no understanding of it takes away and limits its wow-factor. After your visit, you can purchase salt as well. I suggest visiting the salt mines with a tour that also goes to Maras. My fiancé and I arranged the two as private tour from the Cusco airport and got dropped off at our hotel in Urubamba after the tour. This removed the need of a hotel pick up when we landed.
Unexpected gem. Fascinating insight into this community-led salt production initiative, sited in an impressive valley.

Incredible experience. These Inca salt flats are an amazing site. Coming through the Sacred Valley the scenery is dramatic and stark but descending into the valley near Maras and coming across the flats of salt - still being mined! - too my breath away. Definitely buy some of the salt they have there. We arrived on motorcycles and instead of cramming some into my tiny pack, I mistakenly assumed I would be able to get it all over Cusco. Not so.

Interesting to look at. That's about all. I am not terribly impressed by some salty water evaporating in little pools to make salt, however it is very aesthetically pleasing to look at from above. Also the road in provides amazing views of the Andes. Worth seeing once if you are already in the area.

Salinas de Maras // Self Guided. If time is not a concern Salinas de Maras is 100% doable on your own and for relatively cheap. From Urubamba take a cab about 5-10 minutes towards Ollantaytambo. Get off at the Rainbow Bridge aka Puente Arcoiris (cab drivers should know this). This should cost you 5 soles if you lucky, 10 is alright in a private taxi or around 2 soles a person in a Collectivo, just be sure to let the driver know where you need to get off. Get off, follow the road and soon you will come to a hut and someone will greet you and you will pay 10 soles for admission. After that, just keep walking and you'll figure out the way. The walk/hike is about 30 minutes and there is snacks/drinks at the top, but you may as well pack your own. Return the same way you came!

Go there early morning. Salinas de Maras definitely worth a visit. Embark but there early in the morning, until the arrival of mass tourism and give yourself enough time to explore and the pedestrian walk from the salt fields in the valley.

Very interesting site, take the cab, it s worth the trip. We went there after renting the cab at the URUBAMBA mini van station. It s about 1 hour riding from here, and there is very few tours offering this opportunity. We visited Maras first then Moray. The Salinas is really impressive, many people still working on it. We had to pay the entrance for the maras because it s not in our Sacred Valley Pass. The taxi usually stays there for 1 hour.I highly recommend this site, less crowded with tourists.

Neat salt terraces. Definitely unique to see the salt terraces, but there wasn't much salt formed when we were there, so it looked a lot like just pools of muddy water. Worth a see, but not the best attraction in SV

Cool sight, touristy closer to the terraces. A unique sight to see as these salt terraces are carved out of the mountainside which allows high salinity level water to feed into each terrace. The view, looking down onto the terraces from the road was amazing. Once you get closer to the actual sight, the more touristy it becomes, but I guess that's to be expected. Definitely worth checking out

Very interesting and eye opening attraction . Paid 10 sold per person to access this site/attraction. To get there, either go by a tour coach or hire a private car to access this site and other sites. The site is equivalent to the salt pools of Turkey and China and were very attractive to look at. Though working in the salt pool may be a backbreaking job. It is interesting to walk amongst the salt pool and understand the dynamics of the place. Do note that the road there is unpaved and only small buses can access it. Interesting visit that is ranked as 1 of the top attractions.

Sighsteeing. Fantastic view from the road while approachign the salinas. Best time to take advantage of the sunlight for fantastic photos: mid day. You need your car or an organised tour to get there. Make sure you have shoes good for walking on a difficult terrain, ie boots. Take your time while at the salinas, to see as many pools as possible. Not suitable for those who can't walk uphill / downhill, since the parking lot is at a higher level than those of the pools and once you visit the pool level, you need to walk uphill again to reach your car.

Interesting Site, Not Worth Exploring. We visited this stop after a scenic ride from the Urubamba Valley. It was a great site to visit, but I don't think that anything more than an explanation of the site and actually being able to see the intricate structuring and levels of the salt mine was necessary.There were many small shops all selling basically the same products; we took home a few different types of salt that were produced at the mine, and I look forward to cooking with them!

Stunning site. Don't miss out on a tour of Cusco surrounds including a visit to the impressive salt mines of Maras. As the bus rounded the corner we were presented with what seemed an impressionists work of art. Thousands of shades of white, off white, beige, cream, pinks and reds seemed to form a haphazard 3d work of art.Grab yourself a bag of cancha - peruvian roasted corn kernels doused in loads of the local product and head out to the salt beds and explore.

All this from one little stream?!. It is amazing how the Incas built these salt pools!You will be blown away when you see just how much salt is collected from such a small flow of water. Walk around the place and try some salt- its great!
An impressive view. We only stopped for a quick look around as part of an ATV tour but it was quite a sight to behold when it first came into view.
Ok. The place has se terraces made of salt, the structure is seems interesting but further than that, there's not much to see or to do in this area.
Breathtaking. When we arrived at the "look out" it was breathtaking to look down into the valley and observe pools of salt. All this coming from a stream from the mountain above. Very operational.
Spectacular hillside table salt pools. Above the Sacred Valley - table salt manufacturing facility from small hillside stream. Amazing site.

Best part of my trip to Pru. The salt mines were the most amazing this we saw in Peru. This includes going to Machu Pichu. The fact that these mines (which are not like any other you may have seen or read about) is still in operation after 1000 years was just extraordinary. This was an optional site on our tour and I am so glad we went.
Breathtaking. Very impressive site. I wandered around there for ever... Can also recommend to buy chocolate with the locally produced salt - super tasty!

Worth seeng Salinas de Maras. My husband and I had a guided tour of the Salinas de Maras, and were very impressed with the way these salt fields have helped the local population for centuries. It was hot when we got there, and we did not see hardly anyone work in the plots, but were still amazed by the beauty of the site. Intense Peru had arranged for a small van to pick us up. The tour was in both Spanish and English, very informative and a nice surprise to find salt in the Andes. Make sure you add this site if you stay five days in the Cuzco ara.
Golden light at sunset . Absolutely deserves to be visited! The best time is sunset as the surrounding mountains have this golden reflection on the white salt pits.

Very unique place to visit.. We hired a private driver to take us to Mara from Ollantaytambo. He was great. The drive out was stunning and we stopped in the countryside to take photos. The Salinas de Maras was most interesting and we were able to walk among the salt pods-could have fallen in but didn't. We also purchased quite of bit of salt, 3 different kinds. Later, traveling thru Peru, we saw the same salt for sale everywhere but for a much higher price, so buy some while you are there.

Fantastic photo opportunities. A complete change if you are all 'ruined' out. Privately run the entry is S. 10 per person - very reasonable. The attraction itself is must visit in my opinion and being able to sample the salt is a nice add-on.
Salineras. The place is nice even tough is not too big compare to Uyuni which is huge. Anyway, the guide was good and the service in general as well.
Amazing!. Not to miss this amazing pond of salt. Best time to see on sunny days. Wear good walking shoes, sunscreen, and hat.

Neat surprise for the adventurer. This was a really nice stop on our trip. We got to see different stages of the "mining" process. This is pretty much nature and gravity made. For me the highlight was to be able to walk thru the mines like a local. Remember that due to the altitude it can be a little tougher than normal so take you time to enjoy it and do not forget to bring you camera because you'll needed.If you need to use the restrooms bring some soles as they will charge a small fee to use them.
Very unique & great value . Definitely worth going to if you plan on seeing Moray. Also great value for only 10 Soles per person. Very unique and unlike anything I've ever seen.

Highlight of the Sacred Valley. This is one of the coolest things we did in the Sacred Valley. Such a unique and interesting experience that you will likely never experience anywhere else in the world. The way these work is kinda amazing. This natural spring runs through the mountain side, and has an extremely high salt content to it (the water is warm to the touch even on a very cool day). The water is fed and cascades down into these ponds, where is sits and allows the water to evaporate, leaving behind crystallized salt. The salt is then collected, dried out, and bagged for sale.

Very beautiful and unique place. Very beautiful place. Defenitely worth of 10 soles (entry). We just took a taxi from our hotel from Sacred Valley and have to admit that a visit with a guide would have been better. So recommendation to have a guide... And prepare to buy different kind of salts even though you didn't think of buying nearly anything at first... :)
Beautiful and interesting - go with a great guide. Make this part of a tour of the Sacred Valley -- a beautiful spot and interesting to see the families harvesting salt from their individual plots.

Beautiful view and fascinating back story. Visiting Maras was fascinating because its the way salt has been harvested here for many years. They let you get very close to the pools and you can see the crystals forming in the water. The view is beautiful, too.Tip: definitely wear sunglasses and sun block on sunny days here as the salt reflects the sun and makes everything really bright / burn easily.

Another must see.. I have never been to a salt mine before and this one really opened my eyes to the process, I dare say that in other mines are a little more modern, this place is primitive however owned by individuals for a little extra cash, so a lot more physical effort is required.The walk down the hill is ok, but remember you have to walk back UP hill.Amazing place to see.Note: if you are after some crystals, the little shops here are fabulous with a large variety and quite well priced.

Amazing!. A surprising stop on our long tour but truly amazing! Do not miss out, the drive down is hilarious and fun but the drivers are always safe and know what they are doing!Very interesting stop on your ways, its a quick stop but lots of fun visiting their small shops and make sure you take some salt home as its a great souvenir... The water itself is something to see as it turns to salt instantly on your fingers. The whole place is incredible to see, very different than what you would expect and what we see at home. Supporting the locals here was also part of it, our guide told us that some families own the salt pools and sell it/use it, we made sure to take some home with us!Very great place to appreciate in Peru. I would go again!
Very good. Reach this place is hard, but it's a beautiful place. The white terraces create a strange lunar effect.

A pretty cool sight in the sacred valley. You can visit this salt site in about 40 minutes. It is not so easy to get to. I was traveling by cab to a few sights but I guess you can rent a car or go on a tour. Pretty amazing to see the natural salt basins.

Fascinating! . Interesting place! To see the Salt water coming out of a well was for me impressive. Please read the history on Google (Wikipedia) before your visit. Always handy. The tour guides are always in a hurry. You have to walk to the Salinas be careful it can be slippery. I saw a tourist fell down and I also almost fell down myself.

Very interesting salt mines that have been around since the Incas. We took an ATV tour here. The surrounding country is breath taking and the salt mines are super interesting. You only need about a hour to visit but if you are visiting Moray, I definitely recommend making a stop here.

Amazing in scale. I did a quad bike activity and they brought us there. I was not expecting to find this but I was impressed by the scale of it and that something like this is still there after centuries and, also, still in use.

AMAZING!!!. This place is beyond beautiful! Tucked in the mountains if the sacred valley, 45 minute drive from Ollantaytambo, you will find this beauty! If you speak Spanish and are not a tour guide, you might get lucky and get to talk to the families that are working on their salt plot. Such a cool experience! Be adventurous and walk down between plots!
Salty!. Interesting source of the salty water from an underground spring. It has been like this for a very long time.

Salt Pans. This is a spot not to be missed on any tour. Our tour leader explained how all the salt is used by all the residents. It is tended to daily and is impressive to see how the locals tend to this very important site.
a tour you can do without. not nearly what was expected, just salt mines, with a touch of family market. it takes 2 hours to get there and the maximum time needed to visit is less than 20 minutes

These salt flats were unexpectedly beautiful. I had heard of these salt fields, but was totally unprepared for the beauty. We were lucky and were there during the dryer time so the flats were in various shades of white. You can walk among some of them, and they are worth the hike down and back. Do yourself a favor and see these when you are in Cusco.

Worth the detour!!!. Half way between Ollantaytambo and Cusco (one hour from each), Salinas de Maras are 100% worth the detour and/or stop over. I had never seen or experienced something like this before: A salt mine nested in the middle of the Andes mountains. Go check it out!!!!
With the visit. Go here! It's a stunning sight to see. We took a day trip by private car to Chinchero, moray, and salinas for $140s and it was well worth it. Highlight was the salt flats!

Maras Salt Ponds. Maras Salt ponds is in the Sacred Valley 40 miles from Cuzco.. Salt is collected in about 4000 separate ponds and supply from salty water from a local subterranean stream. The pond's keeper then closes the water-feeder notch and allows the pond to go dry and in a few days scrapes the dry salts for use. The surrounding souvenir shops market three grades of salts....brown (medicinal), pink (grilling) and white (house hold) as well as various nuts and peas flavoured with their salts. The collection of ponds and the various colors of the surrounding area makes this attraction memorable.

A unique landmark attraction. Situated in a fairly remote location this site is well worth a visit, particularly with a guide. Very different from the usual trips to see Inca ruins so it made a pleasant change. There are toilets on site and few stalls selling tourist merchandise but not much else so an hour is sufficient time to spend on a visit

Not in my dreams did I expect to see this. What an unusual site to see near the Sacred Valley of Peru. Out of a mountain is flowing a small stream that has a high content of salt. The water flows into sequered "pools" which are mined by letting evaporation take place. Really a must in my opinion as I have never seen anything like this before

Like this for millenia. We stopped here on the way back from Machu Picchu and were so impressed by the scale of the site but the simplicity of the salt collecting. Its been done this way for thousands of years and is fascinating to watch. Definitely worth the stop!

No distracting noise...... If you're looking for excitement, you're not likely to find it here.However, if you're interests lean toward historic, eco-friendly, resource extraction, you'll probably enjoy visiting Salinas de Maras.Water carrying dissolved salts flow down from the mountains to this location. Terraced ponds were created on the steep hills in Inca times. as the water flows down, it is diverted into various ponds. When they are filled, the water is diverted to others and the filled pond is left to evaporate the water, leaving the salt behind.The size and shape of the ponds vary greatly as do the width of the paths between them. Those are the ponds you walk on to negotiate your way through the field of ponds, as the locals go about their business of collecting the salt.Sometimes the paths are flat and wide enough to walk on with total comfort. sometimes they are quite narrow with high crowns, making walking a bit precarious. (Even though some of the members of our tour were into their seventies, none ever fell and, if they did, the ponds aren't deep enough to cause anything but embarrassment.Salinas de Maras, with its mosaic of pools, is an enchanting place, almost unearthly. As I descended the terraces I was entranced by the ever changing maze of the pools. Beautiful!
