Too much focus and drive for tourists. Too many shops and too expensive to enter.Nice and interesting place in the middle of nowhere very nice attraction
Interesting site.. Very beautiful colours. Thousands of pools. Worth the drive, if you are in the neighborhood... Photographers' paradise

Quite interesting. After visiting many historical sites, it was a nice change to see something else. We joined a tour and in order to get here, we drove through farm fields and were literally on the edge of the cliff. The salt fields can be difficult to walk across as the paths are narrow and slippery but the site was quite amazing. There are a few souvenir stores at the entrance if visitors wish to buy some salt for home.
Amazing Place. Just an amazing place hiding between 2 Hills arrived with quads to this beautiful Location definitly worth the 10 Dollars entry fee
Wow. Must see. Beautiful drive/side trip if going to Ollantaytambo. For the history, for the salt, for the experience.

Not my favorite tourist sight. I didn't enjoy a lot of the salinas de maras, mostly because the weather wasn't great that day and the road to get there (the final part) was a bit scary. It is a one lane road, with a cliff on the side that is used by buses going in and out of the Salinas de maras. Although the view is pretty once you get there and you get to buy salt among other things, it was my least favorite tourist sight in all my trip.

Nothing like it in the USA. This was a stop on our tour and it is an incredible site. The ingenuity of the Incas to create this place shows remarkable skills. A lot of walking if you choose to explore, but if not, you can enjoy the view without all of the steps required to walk among the salt "trays".

Astonishing sight. The salt-flats are impressive to see and walk through. Their white color is striking agains the brown-green hills. You can even see people working there, extracting the salt from the many pools. If you're in the are this is a must see.

Can only comment on the views. This is a beautiful part of Peru, and I visited on a quad bike which is a great way to see it. Can't comment on the technicalities, because I was put on a Spanish only tour when I don't speak Spanish - but the views alone, were worth it.
A place to visit. It's an interested place to go in your visit to Cusco. Nice views and you can buy different kind of salts

Walk along the top and really see the production. This is an unusual site where an underground salt spring feeds thousands of salt post owned by local "farmers" who harvest the salt after it is naturally sun dried. It is an amazing site to see from afar but more amazing to walk above/through it and see it close up. It is a little daunting if you are not sure footed or scared of heights. If all else fails, just get your feet wet and wade through the pot - if the edge is too treacherous for you. Truly an amazing site to see.

Spectacular Salt Mines in the Andes. I don't hike often, but this was so worth it. The views along the way are so stunning. It took about 20 minutes to reach from the base of the mountain. Who knew that 6,000 year old salt flats would be tucked away between the peaks? Maras salt is famous and you can buy it there or at the airport and throughout Peru.
Very touristy. It is unique, but then there are also lots of people visiting this site. Worth a detour if you also go to Moray.
Don't miss it.. I was ill at the time of this trip but didn't want to miss out after reading some reviews. It is a very different activity and very interesting.

interesting place . this place was interesting and made does some great photos. although it was a long bus ride to get there and we could have spent about half the time we did there. neat to see but not in my top 10 of cool things around cusco.

Fascinating place. Discovered millennia ago a constantly flowing saline spring gravity feeds the extensive salt pans of Salinas de Mara. The pans have been constructed on the terraced slopes of the valley. The salt produced here is harvested manually and claimed to be the world's best. A fascinating artisanal operation.

Salt of the earth. Worth seeing if you are in Peru. The stream coming from deep in the mountain is about 70% salinity according to our guide. I just had to stick my finger in the water, and can attest, it's really salty! Ride down to the salt pans is a little nerve wracking, full of hair pin turns on a narrow road with the occasional tour bus going up or down. Interesting look at salt production still done as it was hundreds of years ago.

Ancient pools of salt water built into the side of hill. The Salinas de Maras are impressive! To think that the Inkans built such a vast and interconnected number of pools is mind-blowing. The countless ancient pools of salt and saltwater are built into the side of a hill and are fed by a spring. The salt water from the spring is directed into intricate channels and trickles into the many pools where the salt accumulates as the water evaporates. There isn't much of a pathway between the pools so although the views of the pools are great, trying to get a photo of them without a bunch of other tourists in the way was nearly impossible. Also, navigating between the pools was challenging since there wasn't enough room for people to pass each other. On the drive down to the Salinas de Maras, there are a few places to stop where the view of the pools and the valley are truly amazing. A great place to visit if you're in the Sacred Valley.

Unique and surreal, but very interesting site!. On the way from Ollantaytambo to Urubamba we asked the driver of a collectivo (ca 1 sol) to drop us off for Salineras. He stopped on the main road, so we could walk to the site, which was a great short hike of ca 45 min. Entrance (10sol) is asked to pay in the small village before hiking up the mountain to one of the local ladies. You can walk into the salt beds area and there are always people working and willing to tell you more about their work. It's an interesting proces and worth a visit!

A must see. Salt mines from the mountain and not from see water. The water is very salty compare to ocean water. We purchased some pink salt for BBQ but I put in a mill and use it for everything. I also bought small packages for friends. Pink salt is not sun-bleached as much as the white salt.

Unique - on the "A" List. While Peru has so many wonderful attractions that might compete against anything in the world for "the best," I would say this place is a must-do for something so unique and beautiful. You could get right into the working "mines" where a very salty spring has fed individual garden-size plots for centuries. Many great photo ops!

Surreal landscape. More salt beds than you can count. Admission, which you pay for a little bit up the road before you get to the salt beds, was 10 soles per person in October 2015.When combined with Moray, the Maras salt beds are great as a side trip from Ollantaytambo or as a stop on the way from Ollantaytambo to Cusco.

Great outing!. We went there with a hired car. It was easy to find and we could get in by paying at the gate (unlike many other sites around Cusco - for most you need to buy an expensive multiple site entrance ticket).We got there before the big tourist buses arrived and enjoyed some minutes by ourselves.I suggest going early.
Well worth the Journey. Incredibly interesting to see and learn about how the Salinas came about. Was fascinating to see the farmers going about their business.
Amazing loved it . I'm not sure why we did not see this when we had made plans for Peru but we found it when we got here. This is amazing and well worth time and trip.

Absolutely stunning!. This was one of my favorite sights of all the places we saw during our Sacred Valley tour. Absolutely gorgeous views, the drive there is also stunning with lots of mountains, snow and Peruvian fields. The salt mines are extremely interesting and are definitely well worth it (especially if you like taking photos!)
Do not miss this!. We hired a private guide to take us here after doing a hiking tour in the Lares area. This is a must see site to visit. It is an amazing unique site.
Very Cool Site to see. We were super impressed with these Salt Mines. The water flowing through this area is very salty to taste. I would highly impressed with this activity.
Pre Inca salt mines still in use. Well deserved to be an Unesco heritage site, with over 5000 mines still in use today. Breathtaking place nested in the Sacred Valley.

Interesting. I never seen something like this in my life, is beautiful and interesting to see how they get the salt from the water running from the mountain. Is the perfect place to get your salt for you and your friends

Salt salt. The place is worth to see. Hidden among mountains so you will have to hire a tour taxi or a car (better and cheaper option tour taxi only for two people for example. We paid around 40eur for travelling around the sacred valley). Salinas are salt pits. You can have a walk through it. Salt is producing naturally and region is supplied by its production.It is something amazing to see.

Unique site. The salt pans are an amazing site. At a distance they appear white but closer they are very coloful. Pink salt is harvested here. It helps to have a local guide to give you the lowdown. An hour is plenty of time to visit for pictures, walking around, buying salt at gift shop. We even saw the burros leaving with huge bags of salt on their backs. It's a stunning view and a good short trip.
Incan Ingenuity in Industry. Take a small saline stream running from a mountain and create over 5,000 small plots producing salt. Have to hand it to the Incas ... again.
Unique place to see. Very interesting place,nice view. Wofth a visit when you visit the Sacret Valley.Took some good pictures, my kids like it.

Lovely, picturesque place loaded with history. This was one of my favorite stops in the Sacred Valley, as it's still a functional, living part of history. It was a gorgeous site, but get there as early as you can to avoid not only the heat, but the blinding sun being reflected off the salt ponds.
Nothing special. It's good to go have a look but there isn't anything special about Salinas apart form the view driving there and back. The mountain range is spectacular

Maras. What an amazing place. Way more interesting than we expected.To realise that the people rely so much on the salt pans to survive seems outdated but its such a traditional way of life. This is a must see place.
Really intersting. Very neat to see how they mine the salt. Was a nice hike through the mines. I loved see the locals tend to their salt ponds. I found it to be a unique experience.

It's Salt!. From a distance Salineras looks like snow or ice. It's a huge series of indentation filled with evaporating salt water. To get there requires going through a little market area where you can buy salt (and everything else!). Once you are there it's worth taking some time to wander around. It's a little slippery but it provides some unique views and a chance to see locals at work scraping away at their salt.

Horseback Ride through the Sacred Valley. We visited the Salinas at the first stop on our horseback tour of the Sacred Valley. Our guide knew everyone there, we were able to talk to some of the families who have a salt plot and of course taste the salt water. Salt is very cheap to purchase.
Fascinating insight. Arrived by quad bike for a brief 30 minute explore. It was good to be able to wander around at will and to observe work in progress

More steps!. We acclimated in Ollantaytambo and this along with Moray was our first day trip. The drive is worth it! We got a driver for 80 soles through our hostel. Bring a hat and jacket it can be windy and sunny! We didn't realize how many steps there would be from parking to the pans, bring your walking stick if you need one.

Unique Salty Stream in the Peruvian Andes. It's really surprising to see a little stream coming out of the inside of the mountain with water saltier than sea water. There are more than 1,400 small pools where the people "harvest" the salt.

A Sleeper!. Getting to this spot is not easy but do it anyway. You will be delighted! We were in awe of the Incan ability to even spot this opportunity much less the engineering required to create this gravity and sun driven salt extraction process. Just the sight is stunning. Make it a day with Moray and Ollantaytambo.
Wonderful hike and visit.. To see with your own eyes is amazing, and lean more about the culture, area and process made for a great day.
Good stop over in Moto tour. Great stop on the loop around sacred valley. It costs 10 soles pp but so worth it. Also good to know that the money goes towards keeping the locals employed to service it

Very interesting place to visit.. We visited this site as part of a several day Sacred Valley tour. It was very interesting to see the process and hard work involved by the families who own a section of this area that produces salt.

Plenty of Salt. We took a private tour of the Sacred Valley with Cusco Transport visting Maras. This was my main purpose for doing a tour of the Sacred Valley and I was not disappointed. A must see attraction. Best time to go would be during a sun set.

Incredibly cool. This is a bit out of the way but it is totally worth it. It is so interesting the way it has been laid out - very efficent and it is amazing that the area has been used for this purpose since the Incas. Definitely worth going in the afternoon when it is fairly quiet and you can have the place to yourself.

Wow!. You absolutely must visit here when planning your trip to Peru. We booked a tour with Llama Path but found that it was a bit too rushed for us. If I could do it again we'd probably hire a taxi or make sure our tour had plenty of time to explore. Definitely come here!

salt of the earth. This was a side trip for part of our day, while others in our group went on a guided tour for the day, someone in our group had the idea of organizing our own side trips to see Maras, as well as Moray, Pisac market & ruins, Ollantaytambo. We had such a unique experience, compared to the guided tour part of the group. Our driver knew the environs and helped us with purchase entry to the sites. We were able to spend as much time as we wanted at Maras, walk the pans, observe the families working the salt pans, look at the mountains...now words to fully convey this area, that has been giving the people salt for all this time....

Interesting salt ponds.. These rather unusual salt "mines" take the natural spring water, collect them in salt ponds, and then allow the sun to do its work of evaporation. Interesting to see but if I had not gone there would not have missed very much.

Unlike anything I've seen. Salinas de Maras is one of my favorite tourist attractions. Not only is the place unlike anything you will see, but to actually taste the water and the salt (which I've done many times without a problem) is a treat. I love buying the vendor's treats that go so well with the salt from this place. Very natural and excellent tasting.
Increíble!!!!. I couldn't believe this place.. Is managed by its own people .. 7000 wells of salt and the salty water runs deep inside the mountain.. Worth the trip

Unique. Definitely a unique part of any Peru trip. The mineral-rich mountain run-off deposits in these human-made pans and settles, which people scrape off to make salt. The journey to get here is an adventure in itself, with the winding narrow cliffside "Andean death road". It's quite the sight to see these salt pans, and the view of the Sacred Valley below is amazing, too. Include it in your trip!

Salinas de Maras--a Unique Site to See. A unique and amazing site. The Salinas de Maras was an unexpectedly interesting place to visit. The natural salt spring here has been used for over a thousand years.
one of the highlights of our visit to Peru. fascinating site. We saw the salt being collected from the pools. another example of the Inca design and ingenuity!

Very interesting and worth seeing. It was fascinating to see that these Inca salt pans are still currently in use. Each salt pan is owned by different families and are passed down to the different generations. Remember to walk slowly up and down the salt pans as it's easy to get out of breath due to the altitude. Keep to the path ways and do not step in the pans. Unfortunately, we were told by our guides that some tourists are ignorant and actually step into the salt pans for photo opportunities. There are gift shops that sell different types of salts and souvenirs.

Don't miss this very interesting site!. Spectacular Andean scenery surrounds the approach to this very interesting site. You won't be disappointed by these ancient salt mines, and best of all, you can walk around the evaporation ponds while you learn more from your guide about how a subterranean stream feeds the ponds. Before you leave, you can purchase salt from local vendors.
2,000 years old and still going!. A place that is still,to this day, working as over 2,000 years ago. A reminder of the extraordinary culture of the Incan and pre-Incan peoples.

Wow, I had no idea!. Salinas de Maras was a totally different experience then the ancient ruins we had been visiting during our trip. I had no idea how salt was harvested. Watching the people harvest the salt with crude implements and the backbreaking work involved as they broke up the salt, sifted it, and then sorted it was truly unique. Next, the salt was bagged into nearly 100 pound bags and carried up the hill to be weighed and shipped to the salt company for processing. The entire process from the flooding of the salt pools to the harvesting was fascinating.

Worth seeing. Sept 14The site is at the end of a long, gravel road. It was a bumpy ride to get there, but worth the effort. Our knowledgeable guide Jimmy told us that this site has over 10,000 salt pans owned and worked by different families.The process of farming and processing the salt was fascinating.Whatever you wore for the day will be lightened by the hot temperature of this site.Small bags of salt are sold at the gift shop, but beware that this souvenir may raise the attention of TSA baggage inspectors who suspect possible explosives. This actually happened to one of our group.
Tour a Salt Mine, Why Not?. Like a place you would expect to see in a Star Wars movie...more fun than I ever anticipated. We hiked from the top, to the bottom, and experienced some great views.

Unique and Rare Gem!. This is a truly unique place - a working salt harvesting facility in an Andean valley! Managed by local familes, this site has been harvesting salt from the mountain stream for hundreds of years with no change in the method used! Fascinating, closeup opportunity to see the entire process.

Salt pools from a small stream from a mountain to 3000 pools belonging to familites and coops. AWESOME. Much more amazing and surprisingly interesting than initially thought. Thousands of years of streaming from the side of a mountain to provide salt to millions of people.

A hidden gem. We had a private guide to this attraction, which we visited after having visited the Moray Site. You are able to walk around the salt mines along the very edges of the individual pools. There is a small gift shop selling some of the salt collected from the site. The prices are very competitive and the staff at the shop are really informative as to the benefits of the various salts they sell.

Must see while in Cusco. Very cool salt fields, amazing that 80% is original from Incan times and only 20% has been added since. Very cool to walk along the edge of the small slat fields, a photographers dream with the colour contrasts.

surreal place. I had a great time at Salinas de Maras, and definitely recommend it, you must visit it. This place is surreal, absolutely amazing and you can walk around, from salt pond to salt pond. It was interesting to know that each pond belongs to a different family that lives in the area.

Surprised by the huge number of salt ponds. It's interesting to see what they do to collect salt out of the hot salty water that comes out of the mountain. This area has been used since Inca time to collect salt. Make sure to understand the different levels of salt - they fill each pond 3 times to get three layers of salt - each more pure than the one before.

Salt. The Maras Salt flats were amazing to view. According to our guide, they believed need to individual families and can never be sold to corporatis, etc. Families tend their pools and use them to make a living from them. We did not walk all the way down, however, had a good view of the entire area.

Don't stare directly at the salt!. It can be blindingly bright on a sunny day! But what a cool feeling walking among the water pools crusted with white salt all around. Venture of the path and walk along the pools. It's a neat place for a panorama. They do sell small bags of the salt, which are great souvenirs. It doesn't take very long to walk around so definitely make the stop along the way!

A salty beautiful place!. I never expected to see this amount of salt and the beauty of the process. It was a very positive experience going to this place! Be aware that the way to go down there the path is very narrow, but the drivers have a lot of experience.

Salt Everywhere. The best thing that I can say about the Salt Flats of Maras is that the weather was beautiful that day. The road to this area was an unpaved one lane very winding road along the edge of a mountain. Upon arrival we had numerous steep steps to go down (and come back up) before we reached the salt flats. Along the way were also numerous tourist shops that one had to go through to reach the site.If one is squeamish about windy roads and dislikes tourist traps, this is not a place to visit.

So this is how it's made?! A nice introduction to the salt process. Fascinating to see how these families work together and create a nice income from the production of a natural resource. So great that a long-standing Inca tradition (as I understand it) is being continued. Much opportunity to buy chocolate, salt, and other fun things - at good prices... We also hiked down the hill / valley to the river. If you have time, it's well worth it...

Worth going!!!. The terraces were really impressive and the fact that we could walk everywhere, observe people collecting saltvwas amazing!!! We went there by taxi for 80 soles including going to Moray which was also amazing. And we had unlimited time so I would reccomend going by taxi. The entrance to Salinas is 10 soles.

Salt Pools. Interesting salt pools, about 1800 individual salt pools owned by several local families. Each family is responsible for the upkeep and harvest of salt.Not handicap assessable, many stairs to visit the pools.Nestled in the sacred Valley, beautiful views
Salt mines. It was interesting to see how the water enters into the 'ponds' and then slowly dries out to create 'salt'.

Really interesting!. If you are in the area, definitely visit this unusual attraction! We hiked to the site and approaching it from the distance, it looked like there was a "very out of place", long strip of snow nestled in the otherwise warm mountains! Getting closer, you could make out terrace areas. Be sure to get a tour of the salt ponds. The story of how they harvest the salt and empty/fill the ponds is very interesting. You can also walk around among the flats. It's pretty scenery. After your visit, take some time in their small market. You can purchase small bags of salt to take home, as well as some other nice items. The people were friendly. There is a clean bathroom for a small cost.

The Maras Salt Ponds!. "The salt evaporation pond at Maras.Maras is a town in the Sacred Valley of the Incas, 40 kilometers north of Cuzco, in the Cuzco Region of Peru."I ridemy motorcycles to the remote valley where the Inca salt holes are still in use after more than 700 years. There are 3000 individual pools all fed from a single source - a small stream of salty water. The water slowly evaporates, and then barefoot workers collect the salt. Perfect and simple. No machines, just barefoot human-labor, although you might look-out for a toenail next time you salt your eggs ; ) I searched the penny size shapes of the salt crystals (expecting hexagons like the salt flats of Bolivia) but nothing took a standard, geometric shape. Each one organic and different. Salt is more important than diamonds.On your way in by the windy, dusty mountain roads, be sure to stop off and talk to a friendly child selling trinkets. I met Flo, a girl who told said she dreams of going to school one day.

Salinas de Maras is a nice place to visit in Cusco. Very good, must see. Go with a guide so he/she can explain the significance. Taste the water - it is so salty! The shops around this place are also very nice.
Worth a visit. We came here during a tour around the Sacred Valley. Though you may not spend a lot of time here, it's definitely worth a visit. Cost is 10 soles per person.
Worth seeing. Beautiful and amazing. Ended up getting a bunch of salt as gifts. Great gifts to bring back if you don't have much more traveling left to do afterwards! Definitely worth checking out

check it out yourself. it is worth it.. you have to walk a little bit to get to the salt mines. once you get down there, you can take lots of cool pictures. they said they replace water every 90 days. they have clean bathroom where you pay 2 soles. there are lots of stores. pleasant.

Spectacular. It may be a bit off the beaten track but it is most definitely worth the effort. It is an amazing place tucked in the hills above Urubamba. All salt produced by hand family groups working to manage this site.
Interesting. Something you don't expect. Very interesting to see how does it work. A must see when around a Secret Valley.

Well worth a visit. Well worth a visit to view the salt pans in the mountains. The salty natural spring water flowing into the salt pans is controlled by simple means.There are many salt pans and the view is amazing with the mountains backdrop.
Unforgettable. Unforgetable views of a landscapes of salt, i recommend that you have to leave some natural pink salt, the flavor is so different.

Amazing place. If you are touring the Sacred Valley, then you have to visit here. The salt mines are absolutely fascinating, Just breathtaking to view and amazing to wonder around. There weren't too many tourists there when we visited, which allowed us to get some amazing pictures! Some of the ledges are very narrow and there is a steep fall down, so wear sensible footwear and take it slowly.Entrance is 10soles each. They don't take card nor USD and it isn't included as part of the tourist ticket.
Fascinating!. Very interesting to walk around - especially if you are lucky enough to encounter a family "making" salt. Fascinating!

Fascinating Attraction. This is worth a visit especially with a guide to explain the entire process of how this system works. A walk along the terraces makes one appreciate the work and effort and difficulty of making this system meet the needs of the local population.

Centuries of using the local resources. This is a great visit while in the Sacred Valley. Centuries of local inhabitants have used the naturally occurring salt spring to provide salt and income to their families. We did not stop at the shops, but walked down among the terraces and then followed the path to the restaurant at the bottom of the valley (about 11/2 hours...we were not fast, but stopped and looked at the views, vegetation, homes, along the way). We, too, had a guide named Freddie -from Adventure Life, but he works as free lancer for many different companies. He was very helpful in explaining all that we saw. Definitely, a spot worth visiting. Watching the men scrap the salt and carry it on their backs to the storage area helped us understand what difficult work this really was.This can either be a very short stop..look at the terraces and leave, or walk among them and watch the progression of evaporation from one plot to another.

Make sure to dip your hand in the water and then let the sun dry it. We signed up for a horseback riding tour that included Salinas, Maras and Marray. Salinas was amazing. I had never seen a site like it. It seemed like there was snow everywhere! The process was fascinating. The shops at the site were quite nice and we were able to buy a lot of salt in different packaging plus some dried corn and bananas. Yummy.

Mara Salt Terraces - Wow!. A must see if you are in the Sacred Valley or on your way to Machu Picchu. To think this occurs naturally, and the Inca's and now Peruvian locals learned how to harvest the salt. The terraces of salt pools is massive. You can wander for hours if you are not on a schedule. When I first saw the terraces from above my reaction was WOW!!!!! It's best to go out of the high tourist season (July to Aug) as it would not be as enjoyable if very crowded as there is not a lot of room to walk on the paths between the sale pools. We were there the 1st week of Sept. Weather was good.

Maras is Stunning. My family of four traveled to Maras and we loved it! So interesting to learn about salt production, the economy of the community and see it all in action.The area is beautiful with the white salt. So unexpected. Of all the stops we made with our boys (12 and 14) they loved this the most. We had a guide that made it all the better. Freddie from Enigma travel was well educated and informative. Plus he knows everyone so we were treated well and enjoyed meeting his friends and family. Everything was a bit better by having Freddie educate us.
worth seeing. very nice view, you can buy salt on place, very cheap & good quality, I still have some in my kitchen from last year !

Fun and quick!. Its so pretty to see all the salt mines, so cool and different! Balancing between the divisions of the mines is entertaining. This is a quick stop on the way to your hotel or next destination, 1-2 hours there is more than enough. Windy road on the way down, hold on tight. Totally worth it and you will get some awesome pics. Be sure to stop at the shop on your way out to get some salt goodies.

One of the highlights of our trip to the Sacred Valley. Visiting the salineras was one of the highlights of the time we spent in the Sacred Valley. Many visitors arrive to the salineras via larger bus tours, but we hiked to the site from our hotel in Urubamba. It was an easy 30 minute hike and we arrived at a section of the salt ponds that didn't have any other tourists. Various locals were working on their sections of the salt ponds, but other than that, we were the only ones there. It was an absolutely beautiful vista and definitely a unique site -- they have been harvesting salt in the same manner for centuries. Vendors were also selling salt near the parking lot.

Out of the ordinary. The panoramic view is awesome. Something really different from the others tours. We did it in a privet tour and it was nice. There are a lot of little stores selling souvenirs and salts.
A must see. An incredible site! EZ to get to from Cusco, just hire a taxi for the day. (cheap) You can visit other sites nearby as well, like Moray, etc.

Must see on the way to the Sacred Valley. The salt mines added an interesting and unique dimension to our trip into the Sacred Valley of the Incas. I'd never seen open salt mines before and really appreciated the view and the experience. Do not miss the stop.

Image will blow your mind. Salinas de Maras is located between the valleys around Cusco. Our driver took use there as part of the Sacred Valley tour. Once you get there, the image will blow your mind. The pallet of colors and layout of the salt farm is really unique. It looks nothing like its surrounding.

Pretty cool. Essential you have a decent guide (or guide book) that explains how Salinas de Maras came to be and how a group of local families own the mines and make a living from them. One thing to note is that these are working salt mines and its disrespectful to tread to far down into the mines - tourists are really supposed to stay to the upper rim. Regardless my mind was blown by this place. Buy the salt as a token reminder of your trip, but it didn't taste as good once we got it back home. Novelty worn off:)
Nice place. Amazing place. We saw some girls about 13 year old for this place. Hand, fingers, foot are all damage by salt.Children worked really hard for little money.

Exceeded our expectations. My family's initial thoughts were, "How much fun could this really be?" The truth is this was a great experience. My wife, young son, and I are all happy we went. We enjoyed learning, tasting, and seeing this site. (Make sure to sample the food and water.)

Must-Do in Cusco. It is crazy that all this is made by a small stream coming out of the mountain! When you put yuor hand in the water, it will become white from the salt. The terraces are all family-owned and the whole extraction is based on the natural process of humidification.
Great visit. A fascinating look at the salt extraction process in a small setting. Very much worth the bumpy road to get there.

One of the most beautiful places we have ever been. One of the most wonderful places we have ever visited, it even rivaled Machu Picchu. The salt flats were amazing, beautiful, historical, and still in use. The ponds fell down the mountain like a lovely quilt. We were amazed and awed.

A great surprise. It is very interesting to find a source of salted water at 3400 meters. The view is amazing and definitely worth the trip and you can buy pink salt and flor de sal at a very nice price!

THIS IS A MUST if you are visiting CUSCO!. I have been several times in many seasons around the year to Salineras and always it is new spectacle every single time!!Although some agencies offer this touristic place, mostly the big agencies as they have little time left, they dont show the travellers this amazing site...The comprehention of the Inca Empire and its core economy, goes through the knowledge that during Inca times and later when the Spaniards arrive, great amount of their whole economy was moved by the salt ponds extraction. Either way if you are someone who appreciate the culture, ecology, history, or just nature, not to say if you like photography....this place conveys so many aspects of the andean culture, you must experience... is just a must.... It is an amazing circuit that must be visited, special not in a big bus,,,, but , either by horse( I did it on the way up from pichingoto with an amazing company called "Cusco for You") and it was just something extraordinary... I felt I was in the spaniards times, and even thought about, what would have this guys felt once they arrive by horse to these amazing lands... I did it again in another year in a private tour, just for my husband and me..with "Valley and Life Cottages" where we stayed in one of their great houses in Urubamba, and where they offered us their private tours"... I went with them in a car and by my own pace, with their amazing local bilingual guide, "Octavio" who showed us and explained us, the stories and leyends of the place, the plants and name and uses, and we had enough time to take pictures and go by our own... Only 1 thing is important, do not rush ... take 1 day to be in this amazing plateau, where Maras (the spanish settlement city was established) and where the extra-ordinary Inca Lab of Moray is... the last part is where Salineras is a total of 40kms circuit in total, that will take you like 4 or 5 hrs by itself... or maybe more....We ended our day having our amazing lunch in Morays Parador, that was included in our tour itinerary, that sealed the moment in an amazing day... ( I will review also this place later).... So if you are coming to the Sacred Valley dont miss this circuit... and also do it with the best!!!...

Impressive! Fascinating!. We stopped here on a horseback tour of this area. We were able to walk among the salt pools and observe the families working there. It was a great place to pick up some salt at the little gift shop to bring back for friends and families. Just amazing to see the thousands of salt pools that the same families have been farming for generations!

Fascinating Place. Worth the Visit!. It's pretty rough terrain through narrow hilly paths to get to the salt pools and an experienced driver is necessary in my opinion. My husband and I went with a private tour guide and driver and the visit was well worth it. Before descending down the mountain toward Salinas de Maras, there's a nice view of the many salt pools with the majestic mountains behind them. This was a nice photo op. At the tour site, there's a bathroom at the entrance which will cost s/ 1 sole to use. There are also many souvenir stands lining the entrance which sells the actual white and pink salt the community members collect from the salt pools. This is a great place to buy the salt, as they are at bargain price. I later found this same salt (packaged much nicer of course) in airport and other shops for much higher costs. Bring good shoes with grip because you'll be allowed to traverse around the various pools, which could be a little bit dangerous as the paths are very narrow and uneven. The pools seem to go on for quite a distance. You'll be amazed at how people still make their way to the farthest pools to harvest and haul the salt back.

Impressive place!. And very unexpected too when you see these for the first time from the road. Then it's a long way down to the pits (wear good shoes). These 3,000 pits are still fully exploited today by courageous people. Don't forget to taste the water from the stream. You'll realise that it's much saltier than the sea!

Fun walk among the salt. Coming down the hill you get your first glimpse of the salt mines. It is truly awesome. My favorite part was walking among the salt pits. In the US they would never allow this because of the danger of falling but that adds to the thrill. I would highly recommend this tour.

Absolutely Amazing!. Salinas de Maras is beyond description. By far one of the best parts about my recent trip to Peru. I wasn't anticipating loving it so much, but it was just so amazing to walk through these pools. I went in March and the pools were mostly dried up, but it was easy to connect the dots of how the salt is formed. The area is not patrolled by guards and so you really get to explore. The various colors are astounding. Totally worth taking a half day to do this. When I planned our trip people mentioned that it was easy to walk here from the main road. It's a big trek and you have to go along some really scary switchbacks to reach Salinas. I recommend a car!
Golden Hour. Beautiful location, especially just before sunset when the light is reflecting perfectly off of the salt mine. Well worth the visit.
Must visit while in Sacred Valley. One thing is to see the pictures, the real deal is to visit yourself. Worth while the drive, just impressive!

It's just a salt producing site. For my opinion, this place has a low priority if you do have limited time near cusco area. This is just a salt producing site, not a Inca ruin. If you have limited time near cusco area to explore Inca archeologic ruins, Machu picchu, Sacsayhuaman, Pisaq, and ollantaytambo should be your priority. (Among places that I visited including Moray, Salinas de Maras, Qengo, Tambomachay, Puca Pucara, but I did not visit Tipon or Chinchero)
Visit to Salinas de Maras. This is an absolute must see. A very different experience which will show how salt is made. Do not forget to buy some salt as well. The taste is really good.

Salinas Salt Flats. This is the second time I have been to Salinas and the market just above it. The salt flats are increasing in number and it is fascinating to watch the local ladies collect the salt.

Spectacular views. This is an amazing salt production facility, in constant use since pre-Inca times. The 3,000 salt pans are laid out in the valley and provide a fascinating spectacle. It is very difficult to take photographs which do justice to this site.

Not easy to get there but a must. Quite difficult to arrange on your own. The best way to have a driver from Cuzco or olantaytambo. Or get the car on the junction with the Cinchero Urumaba road (many cars waiting). The place is amazing and worthwhile to take the effort to get there. Also the road to the place is interesting and offering wonderful views. Recommended to combine with Moray when on the way to Olantaytambo from cusco.

Nice ride. I went on tours bike ride from Chincheros to maras then to Salinas ,all is good road but the final to salinas i wont recomended is a down hill ride . need a lot experience on bike ride also tours busses are often on the road.

Different kins of tourist attraction. We're not so much into ruins and decided to visit the salt basins. We left our bikes at the entrance (10 soles pp) near Urubamba and then hiked up. People at the Salinas were just doing their job and not very involved with the tourists which is understandable. Would've been nice if they gave visitors a wee salt probe though but I hear there's apparently a shop nearby that sells their salt... Anyway, interesting to look at and walk around in.
Pink salt. Another beutiful atraction in cusco is the village of maras and the colonial church but the most beautiful was its salt mines where extract the valued product pink salt
Wow!. Amazing to see! You can walk a little bit in the salines. You do have to go through a lot of souvenirs stands ot get there though.

Amazing site in the middle of the mountains around the Sacred Valley.. Amazing site in the middle of the mountains around the Sacred Valley. There wasn't much happening when we were there but it is still amazing. You are free to walk around and explore by your own.

A special place. Seeing pictures doesn't prepare you for the stunning first view of this place in its highland valley - sometimes also called Salineras, we found. Make sure you find time to visit and wander around a little when you go to the Sacred ValleyThe best photos - and this place is incredibly photogenic - are from the road across the valley as you drive in and up close as you wander along the rims of the little salt pans. The lengthening shadows of morning and evening sunlight strengthen the definition of your pictures so do this at the start or end of your day - plus it's very hot and bright up there in the middle of the day!

Really Great. This was such a wonderful and interesting place. We hired a taxi from Ollantaytambo to drive us here and Moray (3 hrs total at the very least - this was with only 30mins or so in each location). For 3 hours our taxi was 80 soles. We walked around the Salt pans and picked up a few packages of salt for our friends and family at home.
That's a lot of salt!!!. This place is incredible! It's hard to believe that a very small stream fills all of these little pools. Watching the locals work gathering the salt is soo cool!
Worth it!. This is by far the most out of the way place. People still harvest the salt the old fashioned way and it is truly monumental in scope. You have to see it to believe it.

The Salt pans of ancient Inkas of Maras Valley. I traveled by car from Cusco, arranged by Kuoda travels , Jonathan Goldsmith arranged a beautiful trip. From far we saw white glimpse of something in between the mountains , when I went near I was surprised to see the ancient arrangements for making Rock salt . It was there from the times on Incas , they made rock salts this way , and still today the same process is going on, Saw a small steam is coming out from the mountain . I tasted the water, it was warm and salty, This water is collected in different pools of different sizes according to the landscape. . That is allowed to evaporate and form salt. Locals working there are collecting salt and making heaps, Some salt pools become very hard if not collected in time , Thar salt is used as bath salts by mixing aromas and color. I was really astonished at the site of the immense white areas with pools which are serving salt to mankind from the time of Incas, There are small shops where you can buy packets of rock salts and even bath salts . It is a surprising sight suddenly in the midst of green mountains .

I wasn't prepared for something like this.. I visited with 4 friends as part of a day tour through the sacred valley. I had seen some pictures online, but wasn't prepared for how large it was and the moderately difficult walk , if one is going to venture down into the various salt pools. I had on basic tennis shoes...something with traction is advised as you will be walking on 12 foot wide crusted salt walls with a 6 to 10 ft drop into one of the very shallow basins if you slip. It would likely result in a major sprain or fracture (I am an orthopedic surgeon), in a remote area where it would be difficult in the best of situations to get one out and to medical treatment. But do go and view them - that part isn't dangerous, except for the ride down, and back up, which is quite reminiscent of the ride up and down Machu Picchu!!
Inca Salt mines. Unusual attraction to see thousands of inca salt pools still being used today. Watch Local Inca families harvest the salts. Strangely beautiful site.

Great half-day trip from Urubamba. This is incredible to see and learn about the historical significance to the Inca people. The salt is excellent and available for purchase at very reasonable prices. We asked our hotel to arrange a taxi from Urubamba, and our driver gave us information like a tour guide. The views on the drive are beautiful

Beautiful- but a trek to get there. The Salinas are beautiful! I had never seen anything quite like it. However, you can only see the Salinas as part of a larger tour, visiting Maras and Moray. The sites are about an hour and a half away from Cusco and cost about $25 to get in without the tourist pass. Additionally, the tour is in very broken English and is a lot of driving to spend half an hour at each site- though the sites were very beautiful. We were looking for something to do in our last day of Cusco and we are glad we went, but we felt the tour itself was a whole to do and a big schlep wtih not so much time to tour the sites.

Really awesome place. One of the highlights of our trip, though might I add, flooded with tourists. However, if you are willing to walk away from the main entrance and deeper into the salt pans, its possible to get a few moments of seeming solitude. Just be careful not to fall off the narrow ledges and into the pans. Paths can be quite narrow and although not very high, I can see how some people would be scared.

Just Amazing Views. This is a must see. Ride to it is a bit long, but worth it...Amazing views. There is also a shop just before you get to your ride back even if you don't buy much make sure you bring the salt with spices. Your tummy will thank you!

Incredible place to visit - don't miss it out!. Incredible place to visit when you are in Cusco/Sacred Valley. We were a family of 4, so took a taxi for the day from Cusco and visited a number of sites, including Salinas. This is certainly not one to miss!
A medieval salt factory - in full use!. Never seen something like this before. Anywhere. Serious trip but worth it. Combine with a visit to Moray for example.

Fascinating!. This is the second time I've been to this site. It looks like something out of a fantasy book. I'm not sure if it is advertised, but this is completely run by the local community. Plots are assigned and taken care of by family. Not only is it quite interesting, but it has been tended for a long time. It wasn't just created for tourists. I've never seen anything like it anywhere else in the world.

Interesting salt-making by village people. You should not fly to Peru in order to see the salineras in Maras, but if you are anywhere in the Valle Sagrado it is an interesting stop. Apparently anyone living in the vicinity is allowed to make his or her own salt from drying up salty source water that fill up the little individual ponds. Differences in skill are obvious - the experts get snow white salt, the less experts, or the more lazy, get rather muddy stuff. You can buy salt for your own consumption in the stores on site. If you plan to move to Maras in the foreseeable future, think about negotiating a salt pond for yourself.

Salt of the Earth. The Salinas del Maras is a wonder of the world - literally. Flowing out of a mountain spring is water that is 300% more saline than the ocean. Mankind has been harvesting this salt for thousands of years, making the town of Maras the second most important city (behind Cuzco) in the Inca empire. You've got o see it to believe it. It is one of two places on earth where this phenomenon is present (the other is in the Himalayas. Combine it with the nearby terraces of Moray. 3-4 hours for $50 U.S.
Maras and Moray. I reccomend to everybody to do in mountain bike, this adventure sport in this way is really nice, highly reccomended

Amazing. Our guide took us here, place is huge, I saw different salinas, but nothing like this. Enormous place, with different levels, with salty water coming from - they don't know where, it is just coming. It was February so we missed condensed white salt in the pools, but anyway it was spectacular. After we bought flor de sal, very cheep and very good.

Alien landscape. We visited as part of a tour with our own guide. The coach came over the brow of a hill to reveal this remarkable sight of pools piled upon each other rising up the steep valley side. Moving among the salt pools showed how primitive technology works even today to produce salt for commerce. Fascinating place for taking remarkable photos.
Nothing like it!. I took my 17 year old daughter on an ATV ride to the Maras. We had a great time and enjoyed the unique experience of the flats.

A sight to see!. It's quite amazing to witness what has become of this place in the last 15-20 years. It is still a horrifying drive to get to Maras, and the salt terraces are the same and absolutely breathtaking, but the place has become tourist infested! And there is a market there where you can buy all the regular Peruvian souvenirs, in addition to bags and bags of Maras salt! Buy it here, it's cheap!

Amazing spectacle and also great example of Inca engineering. The Maras Salt terraces are an amazing example of simple but effective architecture used by the Incas. The were first used by them, before the arrival of the Spanish conquistadores, and they are still in use today. In fact, you can buy in the supermarkets salt from this amazing place.Worth the drive and the hike to see one amazing spectacle of dozens of salt covered pools in the sun, and walk among them.

surreal!. it feels surreal when you see the view of the saltpans from above. you are then able to actually walk between the salt pans and it's an amazing experience. nothing quite like this elsewhere.

Good little stop along the way. This was a nice location to visit, though if you are pressed for time, I would cut it out and go to sites like Moray and Chinchero instead. These salt flats are pretty unique. You get to walk around the maze of squares and take some pretty cool pictures. The markets and stores at Maras are also quite good. The friendly storeowners will give you free samples of roasted nuts.

AMAZING!!!!!!. Wow!! This place is truly amazing, it is so uniquely beautiful to see all the different salt pools at various shades due to the different times of development of the salt. You do have to walk down numerous steps but, there are several little shops where you can purchase drinks and snacks on the way down. You have to use your balance as you walk across some of the paths between the pools as they are quite narrow. Very interesting visit definely a must see.

A fine site to visit....if you are able, don't miss it!. The Incas began salt harvest here, collecting the salted water from a spring and drying to different kinds of salt. It is still in operation today, and brings good revenue to the town of Mara we understand. You can walk down to see the flats up close and sample the water--or you can just view the amazing site from above.

Surreal! Must visit!. This is an incredibly interesting and beautiful sight. Getting there is part of the adventure, being there is surreal. Make sure you walk through the ponds, and bring a camera. This is also the place to buy the Maras salt, will not find better prices anywhere else. Do read about it ahead of time.
Impressive. I wouldn't expect to find open salt mines away from the sea/ocean - this makes the Salinas unique. Definitely worth it, though they get quite crowded.

Man this place is HUGE. I can't believe how many salt mines are here, I mean this place is huge and you can walk around on them, climb on them, not a place for really small kids, elderly or disabled. You need some balance to walk around. However, you could see the whole thing up close pretty easily without walking around on it.
Amazing landscape. Very interesting landscape! We also noticed that there were some groups using quad-cycles to get there - it may be a different choice for those seeking a more adventurous approach.

Enjoy a hike around the salt pans in Maras. These salt pans have been worked since Pre-Inca times. Currently 240 families work these 3,000 pans handed down from generation to generation. This salt is three times saltier than sea salt. The red soil mixed with this salt makes a pink salt.

Amazing Salt Pans. These salt pans originated with the Incas and are operated to this day by families in the village of Maras, just above this location. If you go, buy some of their pink salt....delicious.
well worth the trip!. Really interesting, quite how the poor people who harvest the bottom pans get the salt back up the terraces beats me!

Beautiful place!!. Salinas are amazing! We mountain biked from maras which was really fun but I would only recommend it if you are an avid biker. The return trip is 6km straight uphill! We just explored them on our own and enjoyed the sunset. They have a small restaurant is you get hungry with sandwiches and pastries as well.

Incredible, must be seen. We visited this place and walked from the top to the Urubamba valley (in less than one hour). Incredibly true and historic. The incas used this "salinas" 5 centuries ago and it is still in operation

Unique and fascinating site in Cusco. What a unique site to visit! This was a beautiful place to see, and it was so interesting to see the steps in how salt is processed. It was also a good test of balance to walk between the individual salt pools....it's not recommended to do that walk if someone has poor balance. Overall, I'm so glad we visited Salinas de Maras!

Unbelievable Natural wonder. I had seen the photos but I was amazed at the clear saltwater running out of the hillside and the simplicity of the lakes. Definitely paid to come in the dry season to see the workers on pools at different stages of harvesting. lots of free food samples, gift shops to buy souvenirs, the restaurant served great food and the chicha for 1 soles was delicious.

Best if Sacred Valley area after Machu Pichu. These salt mines are so beautiful, it's a must see when you're in the sacred valley in the dry season. The only downside is that the infrastructure is not equipped for so many people in the high season, the road is narrow and it's a challenge with two way traffic. Once in the mine it's similar, the walking path is small and too many people. Nevertheless a must see.

Neat site. Scary drive on bus, but bus drivers are phenomenal in this country--probably greatly underpaid! This place is just a wonder.... make sure to purchase the sal rosada while you are there (best cooking salt there is!) a little goes a long way, need to let it cook into the food, but awesome!
Pictures don't do it justice. You really can't tell the size and scope of the enginering that went into this amazing place. You need to get down into it to really get it.

Totally more than expected!. My jaw dropped when we turned a corner and the massiveness of this blew my mind. It was a remarkable structure and was more than I expected. You must dip your hand in the water... you won't believe it!

Amazing place. Most beautiful place I've ever been to, a must if you are in cusco. Bring tons of water, sunscreen and make sure you have time to walk around. Try the chocolates with maras salt, soooo good.
Very cool place. This was a great stop during our visit. It was fascinating. It was amazing to see all of the pools and the little shopping area had great salt products very reasonably priced.
Just go.. One of the most unusual places ever. Go. You will not be disappointed. And for God's sake, buy something from the locals. They are nice and they pass out free Inka corn samples.
diferent, excelent. Is diferent... you can check as the salt in this diferents states. The people work similat hundreds of years. VERY VERY HOT. You can buy mara s salt. GOOD for foodies.

1000 years of continuous salt extraction - we were told. The first part of a 3 stop tour that comprised Maras Salt Pans, the Andean Village of Misminay and the Incan site at Moray.You have to visit this site to appreciate the extent of these salt pans, we were told that there had been continuous salt extraction here for 1000 years, that each pan was owned by a family who collects and sells the salt.The water from underground sources near the top of the mountain passes through salt rich rocks and is then diverted through these pans by simple damming of channels. By the time the water reaches the river below it has no salt left, as shown by the fresh water trout in the river.Interestingly you are allowed to walk around the pans on the narrow walls.There is of course a small retail outlet and it is interesting to see how many uses they have found for the local product.Well worth an hour or so of your time.

Stunning. You don't necessarily need to spend long here (many trips are combined with the fairly nearby Moray terraces), but don't think of missing it. Visually stunning, from above and from up close. Entrance is 10 soles (a snip over £2). Fascinating to think about how the Incas discovered this in the first place/conceived the idea, and to see people still working there today. Bit of a dicey road to get there!

I thought I was in Santorini for a moment. This was the last stop on a day of exploring the Inca Valley further afield from Cusco. We hired the same driver we had used two days earlier for this full day trip from Cusco, they hotel (Rmui Punku - see my review of this wonderful property in Cusco) arranged the driver and he was wonderful.Salinas de Maras is a large mineral hot spring that is drained into hundreds of small pools where the water evaporates and produces salt. As we drove up the narrow road and the site began to some into view Cara noted that it looked like Santorini, the small Greek Island we were married on. The white pools of salt resembled the whitewashed roofs of the houses that dot the top of the Caldera in the small town of Oia. Upon entrance to the site you are forced through a narrow walkway with lots of touristy stalls lining it selling all types of souvenirs, including the salt which is not for human consumption, take note of that. They also have food and drink available for sale and seating that overlooks the site so once you have gone through it you can relax with a Cusquena (local beer) and marvel at the pools of salt drying below.You can actually walk down into the area where the salt is drying for great photo ops and a chance to feel the warmth of the mineral water that creates the salt. We had the good fortune to see people working some of the pools and bagging up the salt.This was the end of another day of exploring the wonders of the Inca Valley and seeing first hand their ingenuity.

A visual dream. Sensational place, a visual feast. A simply magnificent visual impact on the eye. It's a very simple site, in a sense, just in the middle of "nowhere". But once you walk among the salt basins, being almost blinded by the reverberation of the sun on the white salt and seeing a few local working the place, it feels slightly surreal.

Must see. A true marvel to see and consider in terms of its importance to the Inkas and the ingenuity required to harvest the salt. I would not miss this place. Be prepared for steps just like most places in the area.
It is a must see.. It is a very nice and interesting site. We are glad that we did go there. The road to get there goes thru the high land of the mountains.

Amazing Salt Pans of Maras!. We had this incredible site to ourselves in April! The view is amazing! Hundreds of salt pans are harvested by families of Maras to produce some of the highest quality salt found anywhere. I highly recommend a visit here as it supports the local community and I promise your camera will not be disappointed. On a side note - this site is generally not accessible in the rainy season (Dec-Mar)

A favourite stop in the Sacred Valley. This is the kind of site that you will not see too many places in the world. It is truly unique and visually stunning. The fact that you can experience it first hand is also a bonus. The salt pools are small but brimming with attractive salt crystals along the edges and a wide pallet of subtle colours that it takes a while to see and appreciate. Initially it looks to be shades of white, beige and even brown but the more you explore it and as the lightly changes on a cloudy day you will find more and more interesting things to see. These are working salt pools where local people harvest salt for their own use and to sell in commercial markets. Samples of the salt which is world renowned for its flavours and use in cooking and even medicines, are available for sale in the gift shops that are at the entrance. You are permitted to walk along the paths that take you through the pools and if you are careful and respectful there is usually no objection to visitors walking along the edges of the pools to move out to more remote areas although this is not without risk. The pools are shallow and you will see workers walking in them to clean and maintain them so that they do not leak and then eventually to harvest and bag the salts. When I visited this time there was a professional photographer from Lima who was balancing on the edges of the pools and moving across some very sketchy areas. The drop from one level to another is not great for the most part but some of the spots can be precarious. I watched one woman in a tall white traditional felt hat working in one pool near a larger drop while what appeared to be her daughter repaired a pool above her. The drive in and out can be a thrill in itself as the road is narrow and twisty as you work your way down the valley. It is well worth the time and distance to get there and you will end up with some great pictures.

Amazing. Definitely worth your time to add this to your trip to Peru. Seeing it from the road above the whole set of ponds is amazing and then, when you get up close and hear about how the same families have been doing the same process for two thousand plus years, it's a daunting thought. A very fun place to see and so different than all of the terrace places you can visit.

Incredible 5,000 salt pools. If I hadn't seen it with my own eyes I'd find it hard to imagine. Even having now been there it's incredible to imagine how for so many years the local people work here collecting, refining and selling their salt products. It truly is an under-mountain salt lake supply water to these pools; we tasted it fresh from the small stream coming through the mountain and it was the saltiest I've ever tasted. Another tourist destination however well worth the drive and the view. There are 5,000 of these pools that are worked by local people. Need to have transportation as not an easy destination for walking .... long walk from anywhere.

Amazing. This large site is fed by very small salty stream. The locals (each building and maintaining their individual plots) divert the stream to fill their plot and wait for evaporation. Make sure to get a guided tour. This is a functioning "farm" so you will have an opportunity to observe the entire process. Bring good shoes, there are no walkways through the complex, and many of the borders that you must walk on are uneven with a steep drop to the next terrace.There are commercial enterprises at the entrance where you can purchase local wares. This is a must-see in the Sacred Valley.

Interesting side trip in a pretty part of the world.. Definitely worth seeing! Be sure to dip your finger in the water and have a taste. Remember, that this is a working salt mine, and families are still deriving income from the sale of the salt--don't walk across the pans or mess about with them. You should be sure footed if you're going to wander around among the salt pans. Otherwise, stick to the main path.

Amazing discovery. Thinking that the Inca already found this salty water spring and exploited it is amazing. And when you see the people working there bare feet and bare hands in the water, trry to touch it to understand how much salt there is. It is approximately the same as the Dead Sea...

One of my favorite sites!. This is a breathtaking salt mine! A group of us did an ATV tour to these salt mines. It included ATV-ing for hours around the country side and mountains. And then making our way to the salt mines. This was one of my highlights of my entire Peru backpacking trip! I would recommend taking an ATV rather than getting packed in a tour bus though. The views on the ATV on the mountains above the clouds were spectacular.
Highlight!. This place was completely beautiful! It's a lovely walk and a breathtakingly beautiful place. You don't need a long time here, but it's a great time.
Such an amazing place. Very beautifull place! Unlike anything i have ever seen. It is not a must ser i Cusco, but it is worth the visit if YOU have the time.

COTTAGE INDUSTRY DEFIES MARCH OF TIME. Individual families are assigned a plot to collect and harvest salt at this natural site uniquely perfect for mining salt fortified with minerals; i.e., cold nights below freezing, warm days, and a dry wind (caused by the venturi effect of the mountainous terrain). Adults and children work hours of hard labor to harvest the precious salt known for its fortified composition. Walking along the edge of the plots is confined to a narrow path that requires vigilance and balance. My group was fortunate to have a bus awaiting us at the bottom of the path thereby avoiding a return uphill hike.

Unique!!. After a tour of mountain roads one gets to the salt of Maras. Unique place, where is porduce salt in the same way that hundreds of years ago. Hidden within the slopes but magic in your environment.

See this place!!!. Maras salt mine is amazing especially for photographers. My guide took me there in the afternoon, less tourist and you can take good photos without too much distraction. If you want good lighting, afternoon is best time to visit. You can also get the pink salt that they harvest here as souvenirs. Must visit if your in the Sacred Valley area
Get there early. Different experience while in the Inka country. Kids love it. Be sure to arrive early as most stores close around 4PM and when we came back from the salt ponds everything was closed.
Very unique. Combined with Moray this is worth a trip. It's very unique. You can walk along the salt mine for some interesting views.

Something worth seeing if you're in the Sacred Valley of Peru. Fascinating salt drying "pans" in the hillside. I wrote a post about them so will link to it rather than write it again! http://blondebrunettetravel.com/inca-salt-pans-salineras-peru/

Salt beds. Interesting walk through salt beds that have been worked since 1,000 ad. Communally based, each bed is worked by a family; newer families to the effort get the beds at the bottom and work their way up as beds become available. A gritty tour of working reality.

Unusual place to see. This is a bit of an unusual site to behold in the mountains and a great area to buy some salt souvenirs. Take some time with your camera as the angles will vary as you walk to the side of the mountain. Don't be afraid as it is very easy and quite amazing.

Fascinating start to our journey through the Sacred Valley. We found ourselves with an addtional day in our Peru itineraty so we took the opportunity to see the Salinas de Maras at the start of our trip through the Sacred Valley. Seeing this fascinating site and learning about its history and current use by the local community gave us a great first insight into the marvels of Peru and Incan ingenuity. Well worth the visit.
Amazing, one of a kind. Well maybe not one of kind but for me the only one I have seen. the drive out with the grain fields and views are spectacular

Unique and interesting . After a slightly terrifying drive down a narrow dirt road, you arrive at the salt mines. They are very impressive. White and reflective, capturing the mountains and the sky. We overheard a tour guide saying that certain pools belong to certain families. They scoop out the salt, take it home, and put it on wooden planks to dry. There are several small shops along the stairs selling salt and other assorted items. There are several minutes of large, chunky, uneven stairs, so I wouldn't recommend this if you aren't steady on your feet.Of note- there are 2 bathrooms, both cost 1 sol to enter, and at least the one I used, provided toilet paper with your entry fee.

Salt pans. Salt has always been a highly needed item. This natural food item dates back 1000's of years and to have mother natural provide the water that flushes out the salt within the mountains into these pans is quite ingenious. A must see.

Surprising Little Gem. I wasn't sure I wanted to visit this site, but I am so glad I did. It was very interesting. The salt is delicious and they had other items for sale that we purchased. The salt was very cheap but we were told if you buy it any other place it would be several times the price. Great gift to bring home.

So interesting. You really don't expect a giant field of salt in the middle of the mountains, but there it is. It's fascinating to see the pools of salt and the channels of water feeding the pools. The entrance cost is minimal.

Worth the visit. While this is a little out of the way on a dusty track it should not be missed. These were originally started by the incas and are still in operation today. Very good value for money and the surrounding scenery is outstanding.

Unique experience for a stop along the way to/from Ollantaytambo. Our hotel arranged a driver for us to stop in Maras and Moray along the way to Ollantaytambo from Cusco. We had directly left after flying into Cusco and were experiencing some altitude issues (strong headache, dizziness) during the day. For as much as we enjoyed the salt mines, the visit may have been better if we'd felt differently.There's a large area for souvenirs you walk through to/from the salt mines. You are free to walk around the salt pools. It was interesting to see the different stages of the process.After the visit, we stopped at the cafe on site for a bit of lunch. We shared an amazing club sandwich with avocado. The cafe seemed to be run by a family or friends-- very welcoming and attentive. Prices were very reasonable considering it was on site of an attraction. I would recommend this stop on the way to/from or as a day tour in conjunction with other sites. It is a bit small if this was the only sight you were visiting for a day trip out of Cusco.

Fascinating site. This is one of the most interesting sites that I have ever visited in Peru. The salt pans have been used since before the Inca. The salt comes from an underground spring and it is fascinating to see how it lines the small canals before it eventually makes its way to the "pans." Not very far from Cusco; you could get a taxi there and have them wait for not much money. Don't miss it!

Loved the visit to this unique attraction!. The visit to Maras was meant to be a mere side-trip en route to Machu Picchu, but it became one of the highlights of our trip! The pre-Inca salt ponds are truly awe-inspiring in terms of their vastness, simplicity, and history. Our amazing guide through the sacred valley, Percy Salas Alfaro, was great at providing context about how the ponds started, how they work, and how they are managed today. Buy the salt at the stands nearby. Really good stuff!

Amazing place. Another incredible place to see in Peru. These 3,000+ salt ponds date back since pre-Inka time. Don't forget to take with you a wide-brimmed hat, sun block and sunglasses as the sun can be brutal.
great place. this place is surreal, i loved it, the best part is the souvenir area, great snacks and bath sea salt, just what you need when you go back to cusco
Salt Mines. This is an incredible place to visit in the Sacred Valley. It is a series of pools to harvest salt in production since the Incan empire.

Something different. What a sight to behold -- all these salt flats cascading down from the mountain! Our Gate 1 tour guide gave us quite interesting background of this place and the kinds of salt that are made here by the variou families that own these salt flats. Our group had fun walking through and balancing between the salt ponds and learning how they extract salt from them. A few days after our visit here, we unknowingly purchased a chocolate that had pink rock salt from here. How cool was that!

Nice Photo Op of a Natural Wonder. This is a site where salt is collected through evaporation of the salt water beds. The water comes from a natural salt water spring from the mountains. Though salt has been collected here for hundreds of years, this is more of a natural wonder rather than a historical site but nevertheless interesting. Since it is relatively close to the Moray circular terraces, it is on the tourist circuit.It is a bit of hike down to the pools and there an admission fee -- the Boleto is not valid here. The salt beds are a nice photo op!!

Very Cool Salt Flats. This was a really cool experience, and something we just kind of stumbled upon. I love how brilliant this ancient concept is and how they managed to create something that has lasted for ages. Super white. Very little hassle for a tourist site. I bought some really pretty earrings and a necklace from local vendors. There are toilets at this site, you have to pay but they give you toilet paper. A bonus! If you're in the neighbourhood, I would recommend a quick visit.

Unbelievable Innovation. The salt mines just below Maras are unbelievable. Somewhere in the Inca civilization's history they concluded that salt was an essential component of survival. At the salt mines they designed a means to collect salt. Apparently salt is present in this particular mountain in unusually large quantities. The Incas found a spring / stream flowing from the mountain and constructed scores of shallow pools, then began to route the steam to fill the pools which, clearly not coincidentally, were built on the sunniest side of the mountain. After the salt water has filled the pools it is allowed to evaporate, leaving the salt to be harvested. We spent half a day at the Incan Salt Pools. This is an amazing demonstration of the ingenuity of these people. Although this activity is a long ride from Cusco, viewing this activity which continues on today with few changes from the past is easily worth the time and energy. Those with balance issues might have trouble navigating because you have to walk along very narrow paths with little room for error. As expected, there are plenty of souvenirs to acquire at the entrance. There is a charge to use the facilities at the salt pools. The road down to the salt pools should be driven only by a professional driver.

thousands of salt flats. An impressive display of salt flats, hidden away in the valley next to a hot water spring. Hard to access with young children and slightly expensive to go in.Once you are in, there are many tourist shops to pick up souvenirs as you wind down the valley by foot. Almost inaccessible to disabled visitors. It took as a good 10mins to walk down from the entranceBe careful as altitude sickness can kick in here!

Don't miss. The salt pools are otherworldly and definitely worth the trip. Seeing how they manage to move the water from the little spring at the top down to through the pools is fascinating. Buy some salt to bring home.

worthwhile stop. We walked through on our way between Maras and the river.It was fascinating once we passed through the inevitable market at the entranceThe paths were a bit slippery so people with mobility or balance problems should view the site from near the entrance without walking through the paths. Definitely worth a stop to see it or if possible, walk through it.
Amazing place.. Couldn't believe my own eyes. Great place to see. The water is so salty, it almost burned my tong. Impressive view !!!!!!
very interesting. a nice place to go and take interesting pictures. I just wish I could have been able to stay until late
Salt mines. Such an interesting yet bizarre design for salt mines. Truly mind boggling to think that salt has been mined there for thousands of years.

Amazing Place off the Tourist Track. I hiked up to Salinas de Maras from the bottom, which I HIGHLY recommend! For a more detailed recount of the experience, check out my blog post on it! (http://www.travel-alchemy.com/inca-maras-salt/)Walking up on a cloudless day, the trail was steep, but not very long. You can see some ancient ruins in the cliffs to the left if you look closely. Soon, the white terraces of Maras appear in the distance.This is not just a tourist attraction- Maras is a functioning salt mine that has been active since the days of the Inca. Local families collectively own and maintain the mines, and get their income from the mineral-rich salt extracted from this place. A highly unique and authentic experience.

Salinas. Awesome place, we went with taxi because we were 10 of us and were trying to get a better rate so he brought us and gave us 45 minutes to visit, 1 hour would be ideal though. Not to miss!! So fascinating.

Unlike anything I have ever seen. This is well worth adding to your trip to the sacred valley. So much larger than it appears in photos and so very unique. Beautiful in a way something so unusual can be

Had to see it. I first saw it on the photo in one of the hotels I stayed and I just had to see it for myself. I was not disappointed. It's picturesque and interesting to learn how the salt is extracted from the salty steam coming from the mountains. Entry is only S10

What a site. On our way from Ollantaytambo to Cusco, we visited this place. It is quite interesting to see how salt is created naturally in about 28 days. We were able to walk around the area and experience some of the natural salt. There are lots of shops which will sell you samples of all kinds. Worth a visit.
