Worth a stop combined with Moray circles nearby. Worth a stop combined with Moray circles nearby, interesting and very photogenic with people working the salt pans. And a couple of shops if you want to buy the various salts produced. .

Worth a short visit. We visited this attraction which is in the Sacred Valley. It is worth a short visit to see a salt mine in use by the Inca's that is still in use. I found it fascinating to see how the exploited a natural spring and the salt pools they constructed. BTW we couldn't buy good pink salt here. (I suspect the best stuff is shipped off to be sold at better prices.)
amazing. great historical & geological site of how they harvest salt from the earth from the residual waters of an ancient sea. SO cool!

Worth the short visit. We travelled like the locals. The buses cost us between 5-10 soles per person per trip from/to Cuzco. Took a bus (minivan) from the center of Olly to Urubamba where we switched to a bus to Cuzco. We got off at Maras and took a taxi to Salinas Salt Flats. We we given 40 minutes to walk around while our taxi waited.That cost us 30 soles. The taxi also stopped along the way so I could take photos of the beautiful valley and snow capped mountains before retiurning us to the bus top we we hopped on another local bus back to Cuzco.

Seems like another planet!. One of the best things about the Salt Mines is that you don't know they are there until you are almost upon them and then - WOW. Depending on the time of year you go, they seem different as they can be really white or a bit brown and muddy during and after the rainy season but they are amazing and should not be missed if time allows. The first time I went was in 1984 or so when I was living in Urubamba. I had no idea what I was headed for. We hiked in from Urubamba which is steep at parts but not too long (couple of hours maybe). The views back into the valley were fantastic and suddenly you come upon this crazy place. The history of it is interesting and I will leave that to your guide but the place still functions the same as when it began. Since then I have been there so many times both hiking, horse trekking, and by car and it is always interesting. If you have the opportunity to see it once, I highly recommend it and if you don't have a lot of time, it can be done on the way back from the Sacred Valley and on the way to Cusco. I personally would not recommend it upon arrival to Cusco area because it is a bit higher and there is up and down which can take your breath away if you have not yet acclimated.

Out of the way but worth it. We paid a driver for a day to take us around the ruins in the sacred valley. He suggested going to see the salt flats and we are so glad we did. They have been collecting salt from these springs since pre-Incan times and it is an amazing sight to see. It is our understanding that each family harvests their own section and you can buy many flavored salts from the on site vendors. The drive out there , thru rolling hills and farmland is beautiful.

not to be missed. a fascinating place! parking space direct a the entrance. costs some soles but they are worth it. use the time to stroll around the salinas despite it is hot and watch salt cristals and the geometric structures of the salinas itself - very photogenic!

.Beautiful and unique. Dont miss it take a tour from cusco. it should cost no more than 25 us dollars per person. there are many tourist agents so check the price before you order.the view is special. the view is special and you can watch the miners during their work

Such an interesting place!. Underground salt water stream at over 8000 feet? What??? This private property has been the source of salt for people in this area since pre-Incan time. Because it is private, you have to pay 10 Soles to enter. You can actually taste the saltiness of the running water directly from the stream. If you want to buy some salt crystals to take home as souvenir before you leave, then the cheaper prices are at the stalls just before you get to the parking lot. Even though rows of stalls are basically selling the same items(and there are many!!!), the ones at the end of the row charge almost 50 percent less than the first shop you come to when you first start your climb back up to the top of the hill where the parking lot is located.

Interesting Salt Evaporation Pools and Views. Maras is a town located about 40 kilometers north of Cusco in the Sacred Valley of the Incas. It is known for it’s salt evaporation ponds that are still in use from the ancient pre-Inca times, and are accessible, by a paved road. Salt is obtained by evaporating salty water from a local subterranean stream. All ponds are shaped into polygons with water control carefully monitored each day by workers. The sun evaporates the water and the pools become supersaturated with salt. The pools are then drained and the salt crystals collected which vary in color from white to a reddish brown. The harvesters of the salt must be members of the local community who work in an informal cooperative.

Rock salt formation. It's interesting to observe how terraces were built, canals built to pan salt from the salty river which flows out of the mountains. Most buses stop at the main gate which means u got to walk down a steep slime to reach these pans. We were in a smaller car and got permission to go right down and had to navigate very few steps. The salt is pink in colour and a delightful taste. At the site u can purchase salt and a array of sweet eats like dried corn, beans, bananas all flavoured with this pink salt. The native Maray community maintain this working monument till date.

Interesting Site. The Salt mines are pretty amazing. I've never seen anything like that before. I always thought the salt mines where underground but these are above ground. The water from the mountains accumulates in these areas that creates the salt mines above ground. It is worth a visit to see something different. The pictures are pretty awesome also.
Amazing. Beautiful and interesting! So glad we visited this site. It wasn't part of the typical tour from our travel agency Escaped to Peru, but was added with Moray, both of which are well worth it!

Magic place. Everything here is so strange and different, 3000 years ago the incas created this place and it is still producing salt. Hired Maras Adventure for an Atv tour and getting there was an adventure too.

Fascinating Salt Mines. Still in operation by local residents. You can visit the salt pans and also watch the salt pan owners working on their particular pan. There are many vendors selling the local salt as well as delicious salted corn to snack on.
Beautiful at sunset. The reflections in the salt pools at sunset were gorgeous for photos. The drive in and out of the salt pools was perilous however well worth it.

Like something out of a dream!. This place is enchanting, like nothing I had ever seen before. The terraces have been in use since Inca times and cover the whole mountainside. Fed from an underground salt spring which has been directed via small channels to cascade down the ponds. So picturesque and surreal. Quiet except for the occasional pounding of a dry pond by the workers.

Amazing. It definitely is one of a kind experience to visit this place. You get to see such vivid landscape and pools of salts spread around this stretch. In the perfect time, you could see the people at work. Visiting these stretches is not going to be easy on your legs but is worth for an experience. Round off the whole trip with purchasing an authentic pack of salt from the shops around here.
Amazing. It was very interesting and picturesque to see the cultivation of salt. We hiked after the tour to Urubamba, Great hike.

Something different to visit in Sacred valley/Cuzco. Quite an interesting & unique site to spend a couple of hours if you have a full day or more in the Sacred valley area. A break from the usual Inca stones & terraces !This is a working salt 'mine', fed by a single narrow stream that carries salt & minerals from the cliffs and is included in your typical 1-day Sacred valley tour itinerary.Highly recommended if you have a full day (or more) to spend in the sacred valley region. We were there recently and enjoyed the visit. Can be very sunny, so bring sunscreen and a hat. Expect to spend 1 - 2 hrs. Mild walking.
Weird and wonderful - well worth the effort. I've seen nothing quite like this place - quirky and historical but still a functioning 'salt factory'

A MUST!. If you can make it here do it!! It is scenic, interesting and only about $8 U.S. Dollars. We took a 4 wheeling tour here and this was one of the stops. You can actually taste the salt and step on the salt pools.

Unique experience!. The Maras salt mines have been in operation for 2 thousand years and still works the same. A stream brings out salt and minerals from the Andes. After 1-2 weeks the salt can be harvested and provides a living for this community of farmers. This area used to be under water millions of years ago. Fossils can be found/seen in the walls as you walk down to the salt mines. The landscape is just phenomenal with the varying colors from the salt pods mixed in with the green valley and glaciers in the background. It was quite an unique experience learning and witnessing an ancient way to mine salt.Take it slow as you ascend the stairs on the way back. Air is thinner here. Bring a hat and sunscreen with you because the sun can be scorching hot. There are also many little shops along the way if you need a break or do a little shopping.

An ancient way to harvest salt. When were were first approaching this I could not figure out what was down the cliff. There were hundreds of what looked like white ponds. It turns out this is an ancient way to harvest salt. There is a geothermal spring that comes out of the mountain and it is extremely salty. The water is diverted to these and then it dries and is then scraped and sold. very interesting but not an easy walk down if you have any issues with knees.

A great day tour with good shopping at the little shops .. This was a beautiful place to visit . The mines are mindblowing. To be able to watch the people at work in there pools of salt was just so beautiful . There are also great little shops to by salt and other gifts right there. Do not miss if in the area.

Different. Nice for a 45 minute stop on way back to Cusco. Very different, never seen anything like these salt plots owned for years by the same families. Too early for harvest as that happens July/August. Bought salt for souvenirs from the Sacred Valley.
Maras Salt Mines. fantastic experience of age old salt mining done in the highlands. the views were unbelievable of the glaciers, townships and landscape.

What an interesting place!. The ride down the cliffside to reach the salt pans is certainly harrowing, but the view is beautiful from the road as well as at the entrance to the walking area of the salt pans. We had a private driver take us there and I think it cost something like $7 to get into the area. Make sure to wear sneakers and be careful walking around this area. It is also on a cliffside and there are no traditional walkways . You must walk on the narrow stones between the salt pans... and they can be slippery. We watched the workers there collecting salt from various pans and carrying it up the hill. There are many gift shop vendors here selling all sorts of Peruvian trinkets /art and lots of salt. Surprise! :)

Most amazing place!. Llama Path Tours provided this trip. If you go, it will be something that you have never seen before in your life. It was an incredible sight and it was so interesting to learn about the "salt farming."

Salt terraces. During an "uncomfortable" drive down a precipitous dirt track, you get an incredible view of the salt pans that evaporate the naturally salty spring water to provide many tonnes of non-sodium salts that are used in cooking, bath salts and even chocolate, and it's all done by hand. Well worth the scary drive.

Spectacular Salt Mines. These ponds are amazing. Make sure you stop before you get there to take photos. And if you taste the water don't take a mouthful! The people who work these ponds work seriously hard, especially those with ponds down low. Certainly worth a visit.

Illusions of Mother of Pearl made from salt pools..... What an adventure getting there! First, stunningly beautiful plains and farmland to be followed by a curvy, winding drive. Yes, there are steep drops-offs as you approach the site, hairpin turns and yes... you must trust your driver (which we did). As with most sites in SV, access can be a challenge due to altitude, stairs, paths. While I had limited challenges descending - going back to the top was a bit challenging due to change in altitude (7ft above sea-level to 11,000+ ft. above sea-level) but I took my time had plenty of water with me and made it just fine. While you can see the beauty of the salt pools from above, by making the trip down you actually get to see the salinization of the spring that feeds along channels into these pools. You also can see a bit better how the salt is harvested. We were fortunate to have Cusco Local Friend guide, Percy, with us - he knew the right time of day to visit the site in order to avoid crowds -- we arrived later in the day on a Sunday. Well worth the drive and the climb!

Worth a stop for a few pictures. The sheer size of the area of salt pools is very impressive. The drive to reach the parking lot is "sketchy" to say the least, hopefully you trust your driver! There are some very steep dropoffs and if this will bother you, it might not be worth it. We stayed for less than an hour and just took a few pictures, but we were on our way to our hotel after 24 hours of traveling and layovers, so maybe we were just too tired to fully enjoy it.

Fascinating history, scary drive there. Do you want to see a fascinating site of historical salt mining? It is worth the long drive there and back on hairy switchbacks with plunging roadside cliffs. The experience can't be expressed in words, you just have to see it. The drive itself thru the Guat highlands is stunning. If you are walking challenged or disabled, this is not for you. I did the hike from the bus parking lot to the salt ponds and back up, seriously vertical paths without railings, on a broken ankle with a cane. Groups of American teenagers were fiercely angry with me for holding them up. Other than that, prepare for no stairs but uneven earthen steps at irregular intervals. Down in the salt flats you will be balancing on 4 inch wide inter pond walls. No place for kids, toddlers, babies, disabilities, or depth perception challenged. There is an entrance fee whether you descend from the parking lot or not. It is worth the visit just to see the site. But if you have any kind of walking infirmity, do not even attempt it.

Stunning spectacle and fascinating site. This site is quite stunning and beautiful, with it's patchwork quilt of salt terraces, dating back to Inca times but still actively in use today.The story of how the salt is harvested though the age old evaporation method is quite fascinating, as it is to see the local farmers working the terraces as you walk though them.The journey through the Sacred Valley to get there also passes some stunning scenery.

Larger than expected. We weren't sure about going to visit los saleniras. But once we got there, it was worth it. It is warm there so bring lots of water. There is a source that comes out of the mountain and it is warm waters and it is also very salty. Very intriguing how this can happen.

Salinas de Maras. Impressive to see how the Incas "made" salt using an evaporation method. It was estimated about 2,000 square areas of perhaps 20 feet by 20 feet of land on a hillside were used to accumulate a salt slurry from the mines. The heat and sun evaporated the water and the salt was remaining. Salt in the days of the Incas was a valued commodity, as well as still an export for Peru, today. A lot of walking up and down. The access road to the salt mine area was a single lane road.
Very interesting site!. Besides the salineras, you can enjoy the road until there through the andes valley. Book the morning trip to salineras and moray for approx. 15 soles.

Enjoyable Visit !. I enjoyed my trip here with my tour group (My wife was not feeling well due to the altitude) mid april of 2015.I felt it was a good value at only 10 soles per person. It also was quite interesting how the water was diverted into each pool and then cut off to allow the drying process. I tasted the water and it is quite salty. It is a bit of a hike though so bring plenty of water and wear comfortable shoes. You may also want to bring something for the headache you might have due to the altitude. The cocoa leaves I was told would help BUT the headache was there the entire six night stay in peru. Ibuprofen seemed to do the most good. Make sure to pick up a Jesus statue that is made from the salt here. It was comforting to have him with me.

Remarkable scale. The size and scale of the salt mines is quite impressive. Small family plots of land capture the natural salt flowing out of the mountain. Well worth the trip to see, pick up some different flavored salts and enjoy a beautiful drive.

Very interesting site. One of my favorite sites. Our guide David (www.privatetoursperu.com) explained how they "mine" for the salt. The process is unique and intriguing and seeing it live is even better. This is not a part of the Boleto Touristico but the cost isn't too bad (10 soles per person). Recommend to include as a part of your Sacred Valley tour.

Interesting salt pans - but beware the altitude!. We've just arrived in Peru and so haven't quite acclimatised. This became evident when we tried to visit these quirky salt pans. We made it half way down and took some quick snaps. If you are a keen landscape photographer then I think you'd spend more time. The trek back up the steps had our hearts racing - clearly we've not adjusted to the altitude yet. Worth a quick stop but not much more.

Salty. We had a great time stopping off at the salt mines. We recommend that you have a guide so that they can explain how it all works. We were there in April and it was not crowded but it was not that white either. You have to go in the summer months if you want to see it at the peak.
Sooo beautiful!. Loved the trip through the Cuzco highlands to this unusual spot. Just like the pictures. Also the salt makes great gifts for everyone back home.

Time of Year and Weather is Key. We visited in April, which is just coming out of their heavy, rainy months. The Salt Pools was on my must-see list, but our tour guide said that there was a strong chance we would not be able to go because of the wet, road conditions. Fortunately, the weather held and we were able to see them and we were so glad! Personally, I believe that seeing them at that time of year was quite possibly the best time. Yes, the roads were rough and I can see how it would be much worse (and frightfully scary) if the roads were muddier and wetter. However, because we went this time of year the salt pools weren't crowded at all. There were no busloads of tourists on our heels, or slowing us down in front of us. Also, during high season, when the salt pools are drying and turning white, our guide said it can be unbearably hot. The small trails leading down to the salt pools are also narrow and I can only imagine how difficult it would be if there were tons of tourists about. Nobody stopped us as we walked down the many trails leading to the lower pools! Our guide said that this location has become so popular that they are in the process of building a better walkway or balcony, however, it will restrict people from getting as up close to the pools as we did, so we felt incredibly fortunate. Other fun factoids:-- According to our guide, Peruvians don't buy or use the salt from this area. Most of the salt there is exported to Asian countries that believe this salt is better because of the natural minerals coming from the mountain. -- According to our guide, there are 5,000 pools. Each family in town is given 40 pools to tend to. Pity the families with the pools at the very bottom of this huge mountainside!-- According to our guide, the large pool closest to the stores belongs to the local priest. However, he rarely ever has to harvest his own salt because the locals do it for him.Other things to be aware of...not handicap friendly. It's a bit of a walk down and that's the easy part. The hard part is walking back up with the altitude. Take your time and go slow. You can use the toilets for 1 sols.

Much more impressive than I imagined. I had seen the pictures of this place, but nothing really prepared me for the actual size of it. I had no idea how cool it would be. Stopped on the road overlooking the mines as we were driving in just to gape at the expanse of the mountainside. It was sunny but super windy (bring a jacket!). You can walk around the pools, just be careful because the paths are narrow. This was one of the highlights of the Sacred Valley tour.

One of my favorite places. This place is one of my favourite places in the Sacred Valley. It is so different from the ruins and definitely something you don't get to see often or anywhere in the world. It has a separate fee of 10 soles to enter (not included in the boleto ticket). It is definitely worth paying for it.You get to explore the salt mines and our tour guide said there about 4000 of them! It was fun to try your balance and walk around. It is hidden on the side of a mountain. The bus ride to get there provides amazing views. You can buy salt from the vendors for very cheap!

WOW. I have never seen a place so different! There are small pools of salt water owned by 4000 families. These stay in the families for generations as they can not be sold. The salt is taken off the tops and graded for different purposes.

Impressive!. This was my second time in Maras. Both times were amazing. This time I drove an ATV down the mountain and when I got there there were 2 rainbows around the sun (locals said rainbows happen frequently over there). I really recommend doing the ATV trip, it is exciting and very safe and the views are just breathtaking. Maras is beautiful. There are hundreds of salt pools in the process of crystalization in the middle of the mountains. Throughout the area there are little markets around that sell salt-made things. My favorites are the bath salts and the blocks of salt. A must see!
And now for something (almost) completely different!. There are still terraces, but this makes a nice change of pace from the surrounding Inca archaeological sites. Quite fascinating.

Overrated, the salt mines of Zipaquira in Colombia are more interesting. Had we paid 10 soles for this attraction, we would have felt RIPPED OFF.That is because we were able to hike from our hotel in Urubamba and hike into the park from the North side for free.We hiked in from the Camino De Maras, which can be accessed from the Urubamba River over a quaint wooden footbridge. The hiking distance is 2.5 km over a steep and moderately strenuous trail that is over 1000 years old. You won´t see any tourists on this trail, only indigenous local people.

Go by yourself. We arrived to the salinas by foot, from Moray (3.5 hours). We had a lot of time on the site to see what we wanted, and were not hurried by the tour guides yelling "vamos!" all the time.The site is nice, I think it depends on which season you are visiting, not all ponds are white.You can walk through the entire site until the end (no tourists anymore), and if you continue down (45 minutes) you arrive in Tarabamba (nice village near the river), and you can catch a collectivo for either Ollantaytambo or Urubamba.
Incredible. Very good half day tour to see the beauty of Salinas...I reccomend this different tour that is used yet.

Nice half day trip. Took a collective for s6 each to the Maras junction on the Cusco-Urumbumba road. From their took a taxi (there are plenty hanging around) to Moray and then Salinas and down into Urumbumba for s80 (for 5 of us). Salinas far more interesting than Moray and the mountain scenery is awesome!

scenic stop. This scenic stop in the Sacred Valley makes for great pictures and it is interesting to learn how the community cooperates to run the salt pans. There are little shops selling salt and corn snacks too.
Go if you have a few hours to spare. Worth the detour. A bit off the beaten path, but nice, its not spectacular but beautiful. I am glad we went .
Cool place. I thought this was such a cool place. It was amazing how many pools there were and very interesting to learn how they harvest the salt. It's a short stop but well worth it.

Interesting but better during dry season. You have to imagine quite a bit if come after the rains have come and dirtied all of the white salt. Still it is interesting and gives you another insight into the life of the Inca. Worth a short visit.

Worth the trip. If you go on your own, take a bit of time to get there. Once here you can hire a local taxi. I recommend this, because the driver gives you about 45 minutes or so to visit the area.You can arrange this through a travel agency, but unless you book it as a private tour, you will not have enough time to see the area or take pictures.

Be aware of the products sold here. Its a very interesting place and the way they continue to produce the salt. But please do not eat any of the plantain chips, dry lima beans or corn people offer you with the different salt flavors! My husband and my daughter got sick after eating this, they both ended with an stomach infection. We had to call the doctor that night. Some friends that were here before had the same problem!

Something different. We were surprised how interesting this attraction turned out. On the side of a hill salt is produced. The hill is terraced with small ponds which contain salt water, the water evaporates until the intense summer sun leaving salt to be harvested, quite amazing. This is only a short drive from Moray and well worth a visit.
Interesting, but a bit touristy. Certainly worth a visit, as they are quite interesting, but once you have sen them and satisfied your curiosity, the rest is just a 'tourist experience'.

Well worth a visit on the way from Cusco to the Sacred Valley. In a car, this site adds about 30-45 minutes to the drive from Cusco to the towns of the Sacred Valley. The setting is a canyon in the plain high above the Sacred Valley, so just driving to the Salinas adds something to the experience as you see a different view. The salt pools themselves are both beautiful and interesting. You can clearly see how the system works without a guide. There is a small market place between the parking lot where you can buy salt (of course) as well as chocolate and various other local crafts.

Peruvian Pink salts and Andes. It's an hour away from Urubamba, we paid around 100 soles for the taxi+guide. The best part is the journey itself, with beautiful landscapes and breathtaking views of Andes.
Salted corn at Salinas de Maras was mouth watering
very nice. and incredible intresting place to visit, is very important to know this is a cooperativa , from the times of the Incas , and they do an excellent job

Hard to put into words. You would think that salt harvesting could only be so interesting...and you'd be wrong!This entire site is breathtaking. From the rapid descent down to the pits, to the ability to explore, to the grand view of the mountains, the Salinas de Maras has been a highlight of our trip thus far. The ingenuity displayed by the developers of this site is incredible. One small stream feeds a massive complex of salt pools through carefully managed channels.Walking on the narrow paths to the end of the complex affords you an unobstructed view of one of the most beautiful parts of Peru. This is a must-see.

Sublime.. My husband and I spent quite a while trying to come up with an adequate word to describe the beauty of the Sacred Valley and the area around the Salt Mines (Maras, Moray) and we finally settled on sublime, as awesome and spectacular weren't strong enough. We paid our excellent taxi driver (Raul) a little extra to detour through this area on our way from Cusco to Ollantaytambo and it was a highlight of our trip. DON'T MISS SEEING THIS AREA!!

Well worth a visit. Kind of brownish in the winter months (December-February) due to the rainy season, but very well worth a visit. One can get directly in the fields, taste the water and salt and enjoy awesome views! Go there!
Very fascinatibng place. Salt mines in the Andes Mountains!?! Probably from a mysterious salt water cache formed during the formation of the mountains. The salt is worth bring home too.

Breath taking views. I did not get to spend a lot of time in Cuzco but this was high on my list of things to see and it did not disappoint. The views were stunning and how the salt was extradited was very interesting. I wish our tour spent more time here then the whirlwind visit we had but I am glad I got to spend time here and it will be an everlasting memory for sure.

100's if not 1000's of salt pools!. Worth a trip to see (and taste) these pools. Amazing to think that they have been there since before the Incas! We did it on a day trip to Moray and it was well worth it!

Dive into a millenarium landscape. The Salt Ponds of Maras are not only an incredible landscape, the images are just marvelous. Before the Incas colonised this area the local dwellers already used the salty spring water coming out of the mountains to fill the ponds in summer time (dry season between May and October) and evaporate the water to collect salt. It is managed by the salt group of farmers from Maras. In Cusco you can buy the salt, which is not tainted with additives, at market stalls near San Pedro market. If you can walk, get to the Salinas and walk through the whole landscape and down to the sacred Urubamba Valley and cross over to Ollantaytambo, from there you can catch transport back to Cusco.

Incredible landscape. Beautiful and impressive engineering; we went in February (low season) so the salt ponds weren't actually being used as the rains make them muddy. It was quiet and aside from a sprinkling of other tourists we could wander at ease. It's a little stroll down and you are able to walk around the narrow canals that separate each group of ponds. Really picturesque surroundings. We visited with a private driver (ask your hotel if they can arrange one, as sometimes it can be much cheaper than a guide) and also stopped at Chinchero. I wouldn't make this a day trip as you may be let down, but if you can do a couple of places as well, I would definitely include this in your itinerary.Note that there are only stairs down to the main ponds, so it's not wheelchair friendly. You may also have to pay a small fee to enter (s./5-10 at most).

amazing. located not far from cuzco by bus, you have to drive on a quite scary road to reach them
the view from high is amazing, it reminds of a bit the conceries in fez, morocco. you have to pay an entry fee but the visit is really interesting

Very interesting. Worth the trip.. It's only 6 miles down a dirt road off the main road to Ollyantambo. Well worth it. Stick your finger in the water coming from the spring from the mountain and taste the salinity of the water. The chocolate with pink salt added is amazingly delicious. We also purchased to bbq flavored salt. Caution, the bags are 1 pound (and half pound) -- consider in regard to weight limits with airline...plus, you have to tote the weight where ever you go.

Salinas de Maras was alright. Salinas de Maras was alright for a day trip. I booked it with the Moray trip for an extra day since I had already paid for the 2 day Sacred Valley ticket for $23. I had to pay an extra $4 for Maras. It was an inexpensive way to spend an extra day if your time allows. It only cost about $10 for the transportation. It was about number 3 on the archeological day tours you can take from Cuzco. #1 Machu Picchu, #2 Sacred Valley, #3 Moray and Maras. The bus trip was comfortable but they stopped in Chinchero to try to sell you things at the end of the trip just like they did on the Sacred Valley Tour. If you are trying to pack in everything in a short time it may be advantageous to go to Bolivia instead.

Don't miss it!. We visited Salinas de Maras as part of a horseback tour which we booked through Adventurespecialists.org. Arriving in this fashion allowed our curiosity to grow as we slowly approached the valley holding the many salt pans. It was difficult to gauge the scale of how large it was until we actually arrived. Our horses were taken around to the far side of the valley, which allowed us the opportunity to walk through the pans for a first-hand look. Being from the cold white north, we couldn't imagine how we would negotiate the narrow white paths along the sides of the shallow pans of water evaporating to leave the salt behind. Our minds kept telling us it must be slippery, being hard and white like ice. Of course we were completely wrong, the salt gave us lots of traction for walking, and within a few steps we forgot our anxiety about how narrow the paths were. It was really great to get up close and see the various stages of the whole process. There was opportunity to purchase salt as souvenirs too. Don't miss it!
Would visit again. Very beautiful to look at and has a rich history. Great for photos and salts from the mines make great gifts. Lots of climbing so be prepared!

Exceptional tour. We didn't know what to expect and this was a last minute decision but we were so glad we went. Driving round a steep road we suddenly saw the salt mines below and we were both quite speechless. Descending into the valley we were told how they were built and mined. They are still the income for this area and those people do work hard - it was hot and the sun on the salt was blinding. We came just before the rainy season when they are flooded and can't produce the fine salt that is sold around the world. A fascinating insight into this resourceful culture.

A good day out. Salinas de Maras was one of the stops on a day tour which included Chinchero and Moray. We went on a warm day in the wet season, the Salinas was interesting as part of this guided tour and of course you could buy some salt there as souvenirs. If you have already done the City Tour and the Sacred Valley tour and are looking for something else to do then this is good, but don't choose this if you haven't been on the others first.

Amazing mines. I loved seeing this sight. It was off the beaten path but my tour company included it on their sacred valley tour. The views are incredible and the mines are fascinating. Well worth the extra time to get there.

Intriguing natural phenomenon. Beautiful natural phenomenon which local families have turned into business opportunity. The colors, shapes, and positioning of the salt "plots" are photogenic and look like organized chaos. The local salt "farmers" mix with the tourists among the plots adding an interesting dynamic to the experience.
very scenic. Got amazing pictures, very intriguing and cute souvenir shops in the area. I bought some adorable lil llama key chains and a cute knapsack for my sister. A must go if in the area.
different Inca terraces than other places. these terracing Inca systems are perfect, there are 3 big ones, but one it the most astonishing, there are complete perfect round.

Nice to see, changing from the ruins. The road to visit the Salinas is worth the trip to see them. The Salinas are in a valley, and the view from the road above is great. The organization of the Salinas is interesting to see. It is a good way to discover the region with a visit of Moray site before going to pick the train to the Machu Picchu in Ollantaytambo
Nice stop on the way to Ollantaytambo.. The salineras are a nice place. So you see where these people get different kinds of salt. The ones you can puchase after the visit.

Salt at 10,000+ feet. Interesting to see how salt has been produced by channeling a small stream for hundreds of years by the local peoples. Hard to imagine at this elevation that part of this was a great sea. You walk right along the evaporation ponds, can put your hand in the stream and when your hand dries it will be white with a fine salt powdery covering. The series of channels and small dams used to divert and fill the ponds is fascinating----very simple but effective. This is off the beaten path a bit but well worth it. Plenty of opportunities to buy various salts and plenty of local "food snacks"----try the popcorn or roasted corn nuts.

An interesting place to visit and walk around.. My trip into Salinas de Maras was at the recommendation of a friend who had been there before. As we were on motorcycles, the ride into the site was fun and the scenery was beautiful.The salt pools are interesting and the hike around the area allowed me to experience the sights and smells of the pools.If you're heading into the Sacred Valley, this is a fun stop to make.

Unique side trip. Since pre-Inca times, salt has been obtained here by evaporating salty water from a local subterranean stream. The flow is directed into an intricate system of tiny channels constructed so that the water runs gradually down onto the several hundred ancient terraced ponds. The cooperative system that was established during the time of the Incas, if not earlier, is still used by the families who pass ownership down from one generation to the next. Some climbing involved. Washrooms pretty primitive. Worth a look if you're touring the high plateau.

Beautiful and Interesting. Hundreds of Salt pools on a mountain side overseeing Urubamba. It's a little ways out of the town of Maras, but can easily get there with a tour, taxis in Cusco or private transportation, biking or even walking. You walk around these awesome salt pools and get to taste, touch, see, smell, and just indulge in the process of processing salt from natural salt springs. It is very rustic as there are no clear paths or roads to walk on, or clear signs everywhere for visitors to know where to go. But that adds on to the experience. You walk alongside salt pools and see the different stages of the process of retrieving salt. They also sell beautiful salt figures at low prices and there's a restaurant in the entrance.
salty mines. if you like places where the nature is unique , this place is for you because, not many tourist goes there, the place is amazing.
Unique landscape. Very unique landscape and easly accessible. Never seen salt production in the mountains cliffs, very picturesque

Primo Peruvian Pink. Whoever knew that pink salt is the premium salt from the Andes? That's just one of the tidbits you'll pick up during a tour of the Maras salt mines (which aren't really mines, but surface evaporation pools). These pools are ancient, and it is fascinating to observe the tiny manmade canals (some only inches wide) that shoot off of the main stream to feed the hundreds of separate pools at Maras. You won't need more than an hour, you can (of course) buy salt on site, and it's a great side trip to combine with a visit to the agricultural terraces at Moray.

80% salinity. The trip to the Salinas de Maras is a good side trip when you visit Moray. It's a nice experience to taste the 80% salinity of the water coming out from the ground. There are many sole pool were you can take nice pictures. The short side trip is worth to be done.

Mindblowing!. We had never heard of Salineras, but on recommendation of our travelagent Fairtravel4u we included this visit in our a private tour through the Sacred Valley. It was very impressive to see the bright Andean sunlight reflecting in these white pools of salt from the Maras people!

Salt collection pans at Maras. We visited the salt pans in January on our way to pick up the train to Machu Picchu. Not the best time to see them as this was the rainy season and there was mud in the pans. Even so it was interesting to learn about this cooperative and about how the individual families tend their own salt pan. They kindly opened the gates and allowed our car to get to a closer point, due to my walking problem. It was a nice break from the many ruins we had been to. I bought salt to take home for cooking.

Wow!!!. Our adult daughter really wanted to visit this site, so she arranged a cab to drive us there through our hotel at a very reasonable price.It definitely was one of the highlights of our trip to Peru...unlike anything we had ever seen before. Lots of photo ops!Our cab stopped at a vista on the way down to the entrance so that we could take an overall shot. We arrived by 9:30, and we pretty much had the place to ourselves.We bought some of the different salts as gifts to bring back home. The salt was also for sale in the airport, just 20 times the price!Highly recommended attraction.
Just do it. This place is worth a visit. Take a tour. Hop on the bus and enjoy. Beautiful pictures and nice, culinary gifts to take home.
Impressive. Amazing site! Still using the technology and tools developed by the Incas to extact salt from the mountains there

Worth to see. I like the scale of this object and its location, but I spent there 10 minutes only, because it is one of this places where you only go to take some pictures. I rode there on a quad and it was a great feeling to see such beautiful place after a long trip. You should deifinitely go there. The entrance fee is 10 sol.

Fun stop. We weren't really expecting much here, but this was definitely a new experience for us. We touched the stream, and you will get salt EVERYWHERE. Plus, great chance to get some useful souvenirs for family and friends! We also tried chicha de jora with strawberry juice in it from one of the stalls. Probably not the smartest thing to do, but we were fine and it was awesome! Great drive too, with lots to look at the whole time. Wear good shoes if you want to walk around.

Worth visiting as part of a wider day out. As others have said, the Salinas are around 1.5 hours from Cusco, and plenty of agencies in Cusco offer an excursion offering Salinas, Moray and Chinchero (and the fantastic views of the Sacred Valley during the journey). We went with Expediciones Waynapicchu (based just left around the top end corner of Av. del Sol above a shop) and their service was pretty good, with an informative guide, and putting in a stop at a weavers in Chinchero all for S/30 head. The Salinas are very interesting, consisting of around 3,000 salt pans built into a steep valley below a salt spring. There are quite a few gift shops and if you want to try the salt it is worth buying here as it is half the price of it in Cusco, and about a 10th of the airport price! Most of the shops also offer samples of fried/salted maize and plantain snacks.We had around 45 minutes here, which was just enough (the other sites require a bit more time, and we picked a 9.00am to 3pm Cusco-Chinchero-Salinas-Moray-Cusco trip.

Worthwhile side-trip in Sacred Valley. Maras is about a 15-minute taxi ride from Urubamba in the Sacred Valley; we arranged a taxi through our hotel. (See Note re hiking at bottom). There is a booth located on the road at which you will pay an entrance fee; the booth is a few minutes before the road turns and descends to the salt pans. The entrance fee is not included as part of the Boleto Touristico. As others have reported, the drive down to the entrance of the salt pans is a bit hair-raising: more so since there are buses and taxi drivers descending and ascending what is really only a single-lane road. The stairs back up from the salt pans are steep at times and difficult and, on the day we went, in spite of it being rainy season, they were crowded. In spite of the poor weather (rain) we felt it was worthwhile because the views of the tiered salt pans are so unusual. Note: it is possible to hike from Maras to Moray and recommended in some travel guides; I regret that time prevented us from doing this hike. If you are a hiker, I highly recommend that you research this (it would likely take the better part of a day to/from if you are taking your time and looking around at both places).

Must visit while in Cusco. We hired a taxi for 150 soles or $50. We paid in dollars. It is 1.5 hours away from Plaza de Armas in Cusco. On the way there, our taxi driver stopped by 3 miradors or look out points for us to take pictures. It is a very scenic drive. It is also on the way to Mach Picchu. When we got to the salt pans of Mara, we took pictures and bought some bath salt.
Great part of the tour. Certainly a testament to the native industry. The thought and effort involved in making this project work is impressive. Also colorful to view.

Needs to be on your list of must visits. The Salinas salt pans were one of the highlights of our trip to Peru, and should be added to your list of things to do when in the Cusco area. I won't go into detail about the attraction itself (if you're reading about it here, you already know what it is). But I will describe our trip out there so you can get a sense of how to plan for the trip yourself.The salt pans are a 1.5ish hour trip out from Cusco in the direction of Ollaytaytambo. We took our trip as part of our journey to Ollaytaytambo, and the private taxi that we hired in Cusco cost 150 soles for the entire trip. The trip included pickup at our Cusco hotel, drive to the salt pans, a wait for 30 minutes as we explored, and continue on to Ollaytaytambo train station. The salt pans cost 10 soles per person for admission, and are absolutely spectacular. Budget about 30-45 minutes of time for exploring, and 5 minutes on the way back up to buy yourself some salt as a souvenir.In case your taxi driver has no clue where to go (like ours), note that there are no clear signs once you turn off the main highway, so you would be advised to ensure your driver knows where he is going. Ours eventually stumbled to the destination, but it took us an extra 20 minutes to arrive.

incan ingenuity. beautiful sight... we hired a taxi directly with Marco by email; on nov 28th, he picked us up at cusco airport at 6.30am and drove thru Moray, Maras and these salineras before dropping us at Ollantaytambo.Salineras are some 3000 small pools with an average area of 5 m² (53.8 ft²), constructed in a slope of the "Qaqawiñay" mountain.People fill up or "irrigate" the pools during the dry season every 3 days, with salty water emanating from a natural spring located on the top of the complex, when water evaporates the salt contained in it solidifies.That process is carried out for one month until a considerable volume of solid salt is obtained; about 10 cms. (4 inches) high from the floor. That solid salt is beaten, granulated, then packed in plastic sacks and sent to the region's markets.

Total the worth the steep stairs. When planning my trip to Machu Picchu, this was on my list of things to see. It did not disappoint, even though I went with a terrible tour operator. They are only farmed during certain months and I was there during off season. During farming time, the pools are white. When I went (December), the pools were brown. But, still, what a sight to see.The way down is down A LOT of stairs. So, if you've got problems going up and down stairs, take note. There are also vendors selling all sorts of wares all along the path/stairway down. Some items, I didn't see anywhere else.It's impossible to get bad shots of the place and you can also buy the famous pink salt there (although it's 4 times the price than at the San Pedro market in Cusco where I got 10 bags for 10 nuevo soles).Truly one of the places I'll remember forever. So beautiful.

Salt ponds amazing, road down hair raising. I was very thankful to get to these ponds because the road is steep, narrow and sheer drop. But the ponds themselves are very interesting - a photographers delight. Lots of hawkers selling their wares on the paths to the ponds, but we got some salt which was for sale and it was great. Well worth a stop when travelling between Cusco to sacred valley.

Blinding beauty. Salineras de Maras is the site of the incredible salt pans hugging the side of a mountain near Maras in the Sacred Valley. Even more interesting is the fact that salt has been harvested from this site since Inca or maybe even pre-Inca times. It's an amazing place and when the sun shines make sure you have your sun glasses on as is blinding. From the parking lot you walk through a bit of a gauntlet of shops selling bags of salt (reasonably priced I must say) and other touristy items. There are also cold drinks and snacks to purchase. There are quite a few stairs down to the salt pans which you are free to walk along as your balance allows. If you are not of good balance, there are a few spots to just sit and contemplate the scenery not too far from the shops. Salineras is a must see site when visiting the Sacred Valley. We accessed this site independently with a car & driver hired for transportation between Ollantaytambo and Cusco, and extended the day to include sightseeing. Salineras is NOT included on the multi-site Boleta Turistica del Cusco but admission is a very reasonable 10 sol / person (no need to pay for your guide or driver). And BTW the other day we just opened the pink salt we bought here to use on a bbq steak and have to say the salt was quite nice and tasty, especially for the price.
Exciting experience. We're so happy, we got a chance to see them and walk through. So amazing what one, tiny stream can do. Water is so salty. It was fun to be there.

So Salty!. This place is really cool. Our guide took us there and showed us the spring from which the salty water comes into the pools and explained how the salt is harvested. The people here have been harvesting 3 types of salt from the pools in the same way that the Incas did for hundreds of years. There's almost no technology that goes into this place: the water comes from the spring, gets channeled to the pans and the sun dries them. The place is huge and you can walk around to your heart's content. I must admit that when I saw pictures of this place, I thought they were painted white, but that's actually years of salt accumulation. It was really cool. Be sure to pick up some of their Corn-Nut type stuff, it's really tasty and 3 bags for 5 soles.

Fascinating and heart-breaking at the same time. The view from the top of the hill looking down on the multiple levels of the salt mine was quite powerful. However once you get near and see the locals sifting through the salt with their bare hands for almost no profit is quite heart-breaking. Well worth the visit.

Fascinating. The ride to Maras salt mines is a pleasant one and one should take a 1/2 hour to stop in the colonial town of Maras itself with its cobblestone streets, quaint plaza, and beautiful colonial doorways. The salt mines reminded us of the area of the tanneries of Fez, Morocco except that here you are out in the countryside. The process of gathering the salt is fascinating and we enjoyed purchasing some bags of Andean pink salt as souvenirs. We were glad we made the short trip as part of our tour of the Scared Valley.

Fantastic!!!. I went to the Salt mine as a part of my acclimatization hike to Moray-Maras the day before the INCA trail. My tour guide Mario took me very close to the salt pools and we walked between each pool, while he talked about the salt making process. If you have an afternoon to spare, go to Maras town, have lunch there and then walk to the Salt mine. You can walk down to nearest town and then take the bus back to Cusco. If you have a full day then hike to Moray to Maras and to Salt mine.

Incredible labour for salt. En route to the sacred valley, we made a stop at the Salinas de Maras. What a sight seen from high above it . The road is not for the faint of hearth. The site is out of this world. Imagine a very small stream exiting from underground where it has picked up a salinity of 70% and has been running for ages. The salinas is made of 3000 baths; each belonging to a family from Maras. They are no all in production but still belong to the same families. (no stranger can own a bath) It takes 15 days to evaporate the water (summer period only) and there are 3 different products: fleur de sel; regular table salt; and salt for cows (with impurities). It is a very tough labour: no gloves and no facial protection. A site to see with a guide as he will give you all the info needed.

Very impressive - a must see. This is an amazing place to see, very unique. It is not only interesting but also quite impressive. It is too bad that we did not have a sunny day for good photos. It is a bit far to go there but certainly worth the trip. Anybody visiting the Sacred Valley must see this.

Salt is graa. We visited this sight but it started raining when we get there. Our guide explains how the salt forms and the different layers of salt. It is a beautiful sight to see. They sell the salt of maras which is really fantastic with meat. I recommend to try it tasted fantastic and cheap.

Get closer. We were on an organized tour, and only saw this from the road above, but even then it was pretty amazing. The indigenous people were ingenious as the salt production continues to the present.

A Site to See. It is impressive to see how hard people work to get the salt. We stood for quite awhile watching the process. This give one an appreciation of the hard work it takes to obtain the salt. We were told that the salt is top quality and I can understand why from being there. This was worth seeing. I would not want to have missed this. This is a site you will not see in the states.
Very interesting place. We loved this site! It had so much history and I would get a guide so you learn all about the salt lakes.

Very unusual place to visit. We visited the salt mines as part of a day through the sacred valley where we hired a car and driver. A lot of people say they can pass on this site - but it was actually one of my favorites. It was just so different. I can say I have NEVER seen anything like it. First the drive is pretty crazy! The road is long, high and full of curves, single lane roads and cars/trucks coming at you. These drivers are super skilled! They have to be. The drive alone is not for the faint of heart! The actual salt pools are really neat. There were a few people working when we were there. I found it fascinating. We are both foodies and bought some salt on our way out. Would recommend it and do it again.

So interesting...glad we made the effort!. We toured the salt mines as part of our tour of the cusco area and just after visiting Moroy. Except for the hair-raising drive down into the area (I have a fear of heights), we highly recommend this attraction. It is absolutely fascinating to see how generations of families have worked the salt mines. Do not miss this. We also thought that driving in the Maras area (where Salineras is located) gave an interesting view of life in the highlands.

Fantastic trip to salt mines. We took the trip via Maras by ATV and the landscape and farmland was worth the trip itself. The mines are impressive and huge but seen in 30 min. So plan the trip on horses or ATV then you will enjoy. Our kids loved the trip and the mines.

The most stunning place outside Cusco. The salt pans of Maras are best visited in the late afternoon, when the setting sun paints the rocks dark red, and the salt reflects bright white. This is really a fantastic site not to be missed.

Must see. Included with our day trip to Moray de Maras, but we were so glad to have shown this unique spot. The road in is crazy scary and just screams "litigation" to us Americans, but well worth it to brave through.

Inka culture. Along with Moray, this was a fascinating visit to a site showing the ingenuity of Inka culture. We had a private guide and had a beautiful drive through the area.
Try a sample of the fried fava beans and banana chips with the different flavored salts.

great to mix-in with ruins in sacred valley tour. Instead of doing one of the tourist buses' tours of the Sacred Valley we hired a private car through our hostel & formed our own tour at our own pace (highly recommended, divided 3 ways I think we spent $20 for the day total). Included the Salinas de Maras in the agenda - highly recommended. Beautiful, fascinating, & a great way to break up seeing ruins all day. We spent about an hour there which was enough. We bought some salt, ate lunch, & were able to hike among the different salt pools & take pictures.

WOW! What an Amazing Site!. DUring a brief sidetrip (during a recent trip to PERU) we were fortunate enough to stop at the salt fields of PERU. It was extremely interesting to see hundreds of "pools" of water, neatly carved out of the hillside. These terraced pools are tended to by just a few familieis. But the treasure these pools hold is unique in the world.World famouns PINK ANDEAN salt comes from these pools. The salt collects in the water, and water onstantly flows from top to bottom of the hill, washing over the salt. The purest salt is then "filtered", checked and processed into table salt. Apparently the salt is healthier for you than US table salt; there are much more minerals in the PERUVIAN salt. And the salt has a very pale pink color.This was a very interesting site to see - all of the salt out in the open, under the sun, drying. If you will be in this portion of the country, this is defintely worth a stop.

Really cool place. This was a real surprise. The landscape is amazing. While it may not take you too long to see and walk around this place, it's a one of a kind experience. We were really glad to have seen it. If you do go, walk down through the salt ponds. The change of colors is really amazing. If you are lucky to see them mining the salt, you'll see how hard it is. We were glad to have come and taken this side trip.Just be careful, the walk around can be slippery.

cheapest DIY trip to Salinas from Ollantaytambo. In the sacred valley, most of the sites are ruins from the Inca Empire.This salinas serves as a good escape from it if you are tired of the ruins.Below are two cheapest ways to go there if you are staying in Ollantaytambo.It takes more than half day if you do it slowly.Method one (this is how I did it)From Ollantaytambo, take a collectivo to Urubamba (Soles 1.5), takes around 30-40 mins.From Urubamba, take a bus (or collectivo) to a place called Ramal (Soles 2 if taking a bus). This is just a drop-off point along the highway. Takes around another 30 mins.From Ramal, wait for any cars or taxi which will happily take you to Salinas directly. Costs around Soles 10-20 depending on your negotiation skills. Takes just 10-15 mins to get to Salinas.Tickets for Salinas is Soles 7.You can walk around Salinas freely inside and take the same way back to Ollantaytambo with the above arrangement.Or you can walk around Salinas and go in one direction (NOT going back to the entrance) then there is a hill road all the way down the mountain. It takes just around 30 mins by walking and then you will arrive a little village.From the village continues following the path for another 10 mins (need to cross a bridge) and you will arrive the main road in between Urubamba and Ollantaytambo.From there, simply catch a collectivo back to Ollantaytambo (20 mins) or to Urubamba (10 mins) as you wish.Method TwoThis is even cheaper and quicker than Method One. I did not do it this way because I "discovered" this method only after doing the Method One.From Ollantaytambo, take the same collectivo to Urubamba, but tell the driver to get off at Arco Iris Del Puente (pictured attached). It takes around 20 mins and you will get off before arriving at Urubamba.Walk towards the Puente (bridge) and cross it.Continue walking past the small village.Then there is a hiking route go up the mountain (on your left).Follow the route and this will lead you to the salinas. The hike should take less than one hour. Not difficult. (this route is indeed the one that I said in Method One that leads down)You will soon arrive the salinas.After visiting, simply walk back the same way.By doing Method One, you need a few transport changes but no need to walk / hike at all to the salinas.By doing Method Two, you only need ONE transport and no one check for tickets (this is what I observed while I was there). But need to hike up (easy one) for more or less 1 hour.Hope this helps!
Interesting to see, but I could live without. Did this on our way back from Machu Picchu. Was OK, it is on the road, but the focus is on selling stuff.

A taste of the traditional ways.... We visited Salinas de Maras on our tour of the Sacred Valley. It was very interesting to see how the Quechua have been harvesting salt for hundreds of years. It appears to be very difficult labor and I'm glad that it's not me that has to do this work!

Visually Interesting. We took a taxi from Urubamba to Salinas. Beautiful ride. We arrived after 2pm when the sun is just perfect and walked around. There were a few people working the salt mines (about which I have mixed feelings.) There are incredible pictures to be taken here but it was uncomfortable watching the women and children doing such back breaking work.

Amazing place on the hillside. Well worth the visit. Nowhere in Europe or N. America would you be allowed to wander along the narrow walkways between the salt pools (not for the faint hearted). Fantastic to be able to get right up close to a real working salt mine.
Magic place. Must see when in the scared valley. You can combine this with the small town Maras and the Morray ruins as a day trip.

One of the wonders of Peru. This place was a huge surprise and anywhere else would be a principal attraction..walking through the salt pools was truly lunar and really has to be seen to be appreciated.

Very informative and interesting tour. We visited this site with a local tour guide. This location is a bit remote but it's fascinating to see how the salt is mined. You are able to walk amongst the evaporation chambers and really see how the salt is collected. Very recommended.

Amazing salt mines. This site is quite remote but it's very great to visit and see how the salt is mined in this area. You get to go right into the salt mines and walk amongst the sections. It's a great place to visit if you're in the area.

Impressive!. Impressive site were (since the Inca period) the salt is extracted from the salty water coming from the mountain. The ability to create all this is incredible,with thousands of basins of different colours,what a suggestive atmosphere..
Definitely worth a visit. This series of salt panes that hug the side if a mountain and are still mined by hand are well worth the visit.

Salt terrasses. A very interesting site, that we visited in october 2014. In the entrance are a lot of touristic shops, where you can buy all sorts of salt that is produced in this place. You can visit the site on your own or have a guide for more information on how the salt is produced.

one of the most unique sight. was not aware of this place until been reading about it from lonely planet on the taxi on the way to sacred valley.
luckily the taxi driver agree t stop over at salinas de maras on the way.
one of the highlight of the sacred valley trip.

Incredible!. The Maras salt mines are an incredible site to visit! It’s quite a drive to get in and there’s an amazing view of the salt mines. When you’re there it’s amazing to think how the Peruvian families get down to their plots on the bottom of the mountain. If it were me, I’d definitely fall into some of the pools! From what I learned there also, the best shops are immediately in front of the mines, and they are. Great deals and some from snacks to nibble on and try all of the salts available.

Salt will never look the same again.. I never knew that salt was harvested this way (or at least it is here) and it is very neat.You do need to hire a driver from Cusco (or a tour bus) in order to get here since it is not close to the city (probably a 30 minute drive). It costs 7 soles when I went in September 2014, so that may change but it isn't a lot of money and the site itself is very interesting.You get to enjoy a majority of the site with a small portion being sectioned off (I'm not sure what for). There are thousands of squares for harvesting salt here and when you look at it from above, it is just very neat to see.The salt comes from water from the mountains. It sits in the pools with the sun beating on it until the water evaporates and you are left with salt. There is a machine used to separate the salt from the sand and the whole process I was told takes about a month.Very neat site, worth visiting if you are on a tour or driving around since this is one of the sites you will likely see along with the Moray and Sacred Valley areas.
Salt mines. the salt mines were very interesting, many families own and operate this as their business. Again the most knowledgeable guides provided the best information

Worth a side trip. If you are traveling through the Sacred Valley, this is definitely worth a visit. The history is interesting, and quite an interesting site to behold. You are allowed to wonder around as you please. There are various stalls that also sell salts for you to bring back.

Really original!. The salinas shows how the peruvian people of this community, make a good use of what mother nature provides. Each family of the community belongs a pond, where they evaporate the water of a salty natural fountain. Then they collect the salt and sell it. It's amazing to se how many people life from this place!

Hairy scary road to extraordinary salt pans. A very scary road leads to this very surprising area of salt pans right in the middle of the Andes. One can buy the salt products produced here, and the scenery is very beautiful.
Modern Art. We got to Maras as the sun was setting and the colors reflected in the saltpools looked like modern art. It took our breath away.

Not just for pictures. Many reviews talk about the great photo ops, which there certainly are, but this site is also just a very cool place to see. We have nothing like this where I'm from (Vancouver). It's a neat departure from the many ancient Incan sites (stone structures) you will see.
Must be seen to be believed!. Salt pans in the mountains and still being used by local people to harvest fresh salt. This is a must visit place from Cusco.

Breathtaking Experience. This is a must-visit and has to be seen. Although there is not much to do once you get there, the views are amazing and you can purchase salt and other goods from the little shops.
Salt terraces. These salt terraces are certainly worth a visit. You can walk through the terraces, wich is a little of an adventure.
Impressive. Do not hesitate to walk all the way down to town after. Few thousands spots of salt for ´fleur de seĺ´ and pink salt and more.

Amazing Site. This natural Salt Mine hidden in the Peruvian Andes has been dated to pre-Inca time. Till this day, everything is done by hand. You don't spend a whole lot of time there, but it's just something everyone should see if staying in the area.

Surprisingly cool. We stopped here on our bike ride. Very cool stop. Interesting to learn about these salt ponds and how they 'farm' the salt. These salt ponds have been in operation since pre-Inca times. The ponds were terraced on the side of the mountain and fed by a natural spring. Make sure to take some salt home with you; it's available for purchase.
Unique attraction. The salt flats are amazing to see and it is great to be able to walk around them with no restraint. We combined this visit with Moray and Sacsayhuaman and were gone all day.

This is a "can't miss" attraction. I have traveled quite a bit and the salinas de Maras are one of the most interesting things I've ever seen. 3,000+ salt pools carved into the side of a mountain fed by a natural underground stream that is 8 inches wide. It is an interesting, picturesque, experience that is unmatched.

I was surprised that I like this. I had not heard of this and it was suggested that since we had time we should look at it. It was fascinating. Somewhere underground there must be a huge salt deposit and as the water passes over it, the salt is dissolved and appears as a salt spring. For thousands of years, it has been evaporated, and used by people. It is collected now much like it was in antiquity. The water is manually diverted into small ponds and the sun does the work. People break up and flatten the ponds with their feet and when full, they are allowed to dry and are then bagged and carried up the hill on a persons back. It really is interesting.
You should visit this place. Salinas de Maras is a very nice place to visit if you love salt and photography ;) There is a huge opportunity for interesting photos here.

Salt Salt Salt!. If Ifugao in Philippines has rice terrace, this village boasts their Salt Terraces. It's just amazing to think that this is in the middle of the mountain ranges, and just surprisingly to find a salt production area.Just a little touristic when we arrived there. Wandering around the salt terraces may be a little difficult due to the limited space to walk on. But it's an experience worth to try.

Ancient food preservation. These were a series of small pools, owned by individual families to obtain salt to sell for consumption of bath salts. The colors of the ponds were various colors from white, cream, tan, and pink. I had some difficulty walking down to them because I was older and had problems from altitude sickness. Next time I would take the altitude sickness pill and purchase a small $10 canister of oxygen from their local drug store. That would have been a lifesaver. The road to the site was narrow, and could barely accommodate 2 buses to pass, but we had excellent drivers. The road in the country too us through grain fields where we saw small children working in the fields watching as their sheep grazed. Little shepherds with dogs.
Amazing. A bonus location suggested by a guide, absolutely worth the visit. Stunning views and interesting to see, definitely worth the trip.
Amazing engineering. It was incredible to see how the Incas built these salt ponds. These are still in use today, in fact, you can buy salt from various vendors right here.

Did not know what to expect. We were driven here by taxi. The drive itself was an experience since it was on the edge of a mountain. Very scenic. Then when you get here you walk through the gift shops and out onto the ledge of the salt area. This area is still being used to collect salt. Has been used this way for hundreds of years. You are allowed to walk all over the area and explore. This was very much worth the trip. The total time at the site will be an hour or two. Don't let this fool you...it is very much worth it. Hot springs bring the salt to drying pounds....a trip back in town.

etched in my memory forever. I first laid eyes on this site on Pinterest and really wanted to see it. Thank god I did, it was beautiful and will go down as one of my greatest memories of my lifetime. The only place of its kind on this huge planet of ours. And it only costs $7 soles.

Walk amongst the salt terraces. Our modern word "salary" derives from the work salt. This was not lost on the Incans. Hot salt spring with a series of drying ponds. Local people toiling the area. On the way out had some freshly toasted corn with the salt. Delicious.
Amazing. This site came out of nowhere. The amazing colors and techniques made looking at salt a thrill. One of Peru's hidden secrets.
Great trip. We traveled with our 10 year old son and he loved this. It was fascinating to see and to know these are pre-inca time.
Interesting and beautiful to look at. Interesting and beautiful to look at - all those saline squares and how they extract salt. Little Market by it where you can buy all sort of local salty snacks.
A step back in time!. The tapping of the underground salt deposits with naturally heated water and the evaporation salt pans work as they did 2,000 years ago. It was like stepping back in time!

Salinas de Maras, Peru. I absolutely loved the salt pans in Salinas de Maras! Looking at the thousands of individual "pans" spilling down the hillside was quite a sight! These "pans" or divided sections of the property have been granted to individual families since past the Inca times, and are worked by these same families now. My book group had just finished reading a book named, "Salt", so seeing an active site was quite impressive. We were there on a gorgeous, blue, sun-filled day, which made the salt pans glisten in the sun. Definitely take a side trip to Maras, preferably going to Moray on the way for a little somthing extra in your Peruvian adventures!

Nice Hike to the Salt Flats. I did the hour walk up to the salt flats after being dropped off in Maras by the collectivo on the side of the road. It was well worth the hike, and it afforded me great views of and a nice walk on the trails of the salt flats.

Visually stunning, great products, and educational/interesting. Went to this on cusco for you tour. Amazing to stick your fingers in the water stream and see them quickly have salt deposited on them. Great local snacks from the corns, salt, chocolate, bananas, etc. Also cool that you can buy salt to take back home or as a gift and for inexpensive. Good piece of ongoing history and pretty on the eyes
Stunning. Wonderful, wonderful place to visit. Prepare to be blown around and perhaps cold, but it is an amazing sight

Salt ponds. Our guide took ua To Salinas salt pools. What a site! it is a real ride to get there and the terraces are like nothing I have ever seen. There were people working in the pools and the water is exceptionally warm. Worth a visit

Wonderful Place to Visit. I was very tired of ruins, and this beautiful place was a wonderful sight for sore eyes. The process of mining salt is incredible, and be sure to lick the rocks. You won't regret it. Some of the best salt I've ever had,

Interesting, but best seen BEFORE MP. I first visited Peru in June/July of 2013, the winter season in Peru. Here are my thoughts:PROs:- winter in Peru is the dry season and better for climbing (see via ferrata adventure and Putucusi Ladder) and hiking (during the day)- the salt mines are interesting and I enjoyed walking among the mineral pools and watching a local mine one for the salt- It's cool if you enjoy history or viewing natural processes- when sunny, the weather is warm enough to enjoy with a light coat or heavy sweaterCONs:- this site isn't awe-inspiring nor is there much to see; it's a salt mine. I think we spent 20...30 minutes there. Don't go out of your way to see this only. Spend a day to see this and surrounding sites; otherwise, it's not worth the time. - It's far from lodging and other attractions (45+ minutes)- very cold at night; after sundown around 5:00, the temp plummets and it's miserable - don't plan to view anything after 5pmRecommendations: 1. Stay in the valley at least one night. It's absolutely gorgeous. 2. See these sites and any others of interest BEFORE you climb Machu Picchu; otherwise, everything else in the area is anti-climactic. 3. There are tours that combine this and Moray, the agricultural tertiary system. I recommend doing one of those, or do what we did: hire a taxi for the day for about 120 soles and go to both Moray and Moras/Salinas and another site in the valley. We went to 3, all about an hour apart. We originally wanted to do the bike tour, but couldn't due to failure to meet a minimum number of participants (I think it's 5), but the taxi worked out better since I was sick as a dog and slept between sites. For itinerary and transportation advice from Cuzco to Machu Picchu, see my review on the Peru Rail/Expedition train to Machu Picchu. Thank you to all who have posted and helped me enjoy truly awesome vacations.Hope this helps return the favor! Happy traveling!

Beautiful!. This little place was so interesting and beautiful! I'm so glad we took the side trip here with our guide, Oscar. We actually bought the little Peruvian bags with Maras salt here, to give as souvenirs to our friends.

Anniversary Trip. This was incredible to see after visiting the salt cathedral outside Bogota. The terraces built to harvest salt have been in use since before the Inca empire. Definitely worth seeing during a trip to the sacred valley

Amazing experience. The view was incredible and our guide was superb explaining the whole process of extracting the salt. We took some salt home after the visit and it has beed a treat in our dishes. I would LOVE to go back and see the salt platforms again. Incredible.
Impressive salinas. The salinas at Maras are worth a detour. Impressive how they created over 3000 salt bowls with a very small water source.

Salt mines on horseback. Recently rode here on horseback with Cusco For You tours. It was really interesting to see these 4000 + salt ponds that have been here for centuries. There is a good selection of salt products, and additional souvenir shopping.
Must See!. At 3300m above sea a spring of salty water fills the terraces where water evaporates, crystallizes and creates a site like out of this world. Visit this site during dry season.

So beautiful. Easy to get to from Cuzco, well worth the side trip. So amazing that there is this salt hot spring that has been used for hundreds of years. Very interesting how this salt is harvested. Beautiful setting.

Tremendous. One of the highlights of our trip. Go on a nice day, pack your own drink and lunch...find a dry salt area and eat lunch in the middle of an incredible topography. Very hard to explain that 10x12ft salt pools could be so beautiful, however they really are. I don't suggest you dip your hands in the water (the source of all the salt), as your hands will be constantly dry for days. Dead Sea was the coolest, however this is a close second.

Thousands of salt ponds. These are owed by the people of the town and once you see how many, you'll wonder just how someone can remember which ponds belong to them. It's an amazing site and very interesting to learn how they mine the ponds. During rainy season they just look like puddles of mud, because they do not tend to them. There is a shop where you can purchase packets of mined salt. Some all white (salt collected from the very top) and then some with sediment built in (mined closer to the bottom of the pond). The color has all to do with exactly where it was mined within the pond. Highly recommended. It's built right into the mountain sides.

Beautiful and surreal. Great terraced salt flats on the cliffs and canyons above the Sacred Valley. Great photo opportunities, and you can even sample a little of the salt off the walls. About 15 minutes by taxi from Urubamba, or 40 minute hike from Maras. Good to combine with a tour of Moray.
A unique experience. We enjoyed our visit here - a unique experience! I'd recommend going with a guide who can explain the process and history to you.

nice place to visit for a day. This place was the lab of the Incas full of terraces and salt minethe tour you can contract in any agency around the main square of Cusso , go to visit this place with your mates
