Do Not Miss. AMAZING place... I loved this almost if not more than Machu Picchu. It really is worth the time... have someone else drive you to the site.. its quite the crazy road out to the salt mines.

Get salty!. On our first day in Cusco we took a day trip to Maras and Moray. If I had to choose between the two, I think the salt mines at Maras were more interesting to see, just because of how bizarre they look. We came with a guide, who explained how the salt mines work, and then led us through them, precariously walking amongst the different plots into the valley. The scenery is really unique and colorful, and you feel like you are in the middle of nowhere (which you kind of are). It's a solid way to spend an afternoon as you are hanging in Cusco to acclimate to the altitude, but I wouldn't go entirely out of my way to see it.

TOTALLY UNIQUE, INCREDIBLE SITE IN CUZCO'S SACRED VALLEY. Walking around the salt pools is an extraordinary experience, very unique and visually exciting. we saw a family gathering the salt and a Young man carrying heavy sacks of salt that are later purified on the site. It's like stepping back in time. totally recommended on your way to Moray

simply fantastic. We decided to take this tour instead of going to the markets with some others on our tour and we were so glad we did, we have never seen anything like these salt pans and some the people of Maras were working their own pan that day. Not to be missed.

Something Different. If you are tired of Inca ruins, the salt pools of Maras make a nice change of pace. The entry fee was S/7.00 when I visited and there are variety of companies offering day trips from Cusco (generally combined with Moray). I recommend a tour instead of driving yourself, as not only is parking rather tight (small lot + lots of tour buses), the road down is mostly one lane with a steep drop off so it is not for the faint of heart.The salt pools are quite impressive and (surprisingly) you can walk among them. There were great views and testing the salt stream coming from the mountain is allowed. After taking your photos, you can buy salt (of course), trinkets made out of salt, and a variety of snacks at a small market which you must walk through to enter or leave the site.

Worth the trip. We visited the salt mines as a side trip from Ollantaymabo. In about 30 minutes you can see the workers extracting the salt and you can walk around the site. It is worth the trip just to see the landscape covered in salt.

Trip to the past. In the modern world its rare to see productions places that got stuck in the past and keep all their traditions. I was in Maras salt mines last week and it kept the charm it had 20 years back when i visited for the first time. This time i went with my 6 and 4 years old girls and it was an easy enjoyable experience for them.

one of my favourite places in peru. we walked down through he salt pans, a bit narrow & steep in places but well worth it. there were very few people there, just some locals collecting salt. Beautiful views. wonderful for photographs. A really stunning place.

Ancient Inca Salt Mining High in the Andes. Don't miss it!. This is a cooperative community for mining salt. It is said to exist before the Incas arrived. Each small pool belongs to a family and has been passed down through the generations. Yet, there are enough for new families in the community to obtain for free, as part of the cooperative. I hired a private taxi and the drive was breathtaking through mountainous farmland and snow capped peaks in the distance! The drive alone was worth the trip. The final road is a narrow dirt road and the driver must take care. Upon the approach, you can look down on the mine fields from very high above. Once you wind down the road and park, there are a few restaurants and quite a few craft stands to buy various qualities of salt and other hand made textiles. You must walk through the maze of shops to access the path ascending down to the pools of salt. This is the point where a closer view of the many pools will astound you! There are a few workers and owners gathering the salt and you can watch how they work. The pools are various shades of white, pink, and brown. In late August it was very hot to walk around. Once you get to the pools you are allowed to walk anywhere, but the footing in very precarious as you are walking on the lip of each pool. Wear boots that won't mind stepping into the salty water if you loose your footing! Aside from the natural beauty of the man made pools and the contrast of the white salt against the earth, the panoramic view of thousands of pools ascending down the mountainside below you and the mountains shooting up in the background will take your breath away! Because of the heat and the limited ability to walk far, you can visit the Moray ruins, right up the road. This is one of the highlights of my trip, because of its ancient roots and incredible beauty.

Great Salty Experience. Although it is a day trip, is well worth it it can be combined with Chinchero and Moray the same day. Something very different as these people take water from the mountain, which believe it or not is salty (I tried it!) and put it in man made containers in the side of the hill to then "harvest" it. You can actually buy the salt there some of which is used specifically for meat to be cooked in the barbecue.

Amazing drive and worth going to see. Definitely worth visiting. Amazing for photography. The local children are so lovely and genuinely charming. We brought lots of little gifts for our children to give to them (penicls, crayons etc). My children were surprised to receive gifts back!

Great trip to combine with Moray terraces. The view of the salineras coming from the mountain road is great. Walking around the pools and watching the workers 'collect' the salt is very interesting.Great for taking picture too.
Neat place to visit. Well worth a short visit if visiting Moray as well. You can view the salt areas and purchase salt products.
Worth a visit . Pretty cool scenery and photo opp with the sale mines. It's best to visit this plus the nearby Maras Incan site together en route to Ollantayambo from Cusco. Or vice versa.

Like driving to the end of the World.. Here is the place where few dare visit. Its a long drive up over 13500 feet at some spots, but when you get there its well worth the effort.The salt mines have been in operation for over a thousand years. Not only is this a site to see from ground zero, but the view at 13000 feet about this is incredible.Don't be shy. Taste the waters. It will surprise you.

Incredible, looks like a Modigliani painting, but livelihood of many a family..... An other worldly experience.... Our pictures look as if we're in a ski resort, but it's a salt farm....watching the locals carrying their loads, walking carefully on the dividers, washing their feet in the fresh water, and contemplating the twists of fate that alot each plot to whichever family over the generations.... priceless....Understand it is small potatoes compared to one in Bolivia, but what an experience....Don't miss this....There are snacks to purchase, alpaca, leather and other things to buy, but the real experience here is threading your way through the salt plots, eyes open....Our guide was the same one we had for 7 days, and his insights were invaluable... but however you do it, get here, and get someone to interpret the terrain for hyou....

Another unexpected surprise. After reading other reviews on things to do in the sacred valley (we had 3 days before going to MP) this was on our list to visit, but what we saw when we got there was surprising. We hired a taxi for the day to take 4 people here and to Pisac markets and ruins. About 300 Soles (or $100) for all day. Well worth it as he just took is there and let us roam around and meet us at a time we picked. The ride from Urubamba was, well, exciting, as the road are all dirt, and windy, and a little scary. There is a slight fee to get in, about 7 soles each i think (3 soles is around a dollar). Once in your are free to wander about at your leisure. We climbed around and followed the paths between the flats. Tasted the water (very salty) and even geocached. Pre-reading about the history was very helpful to know what is (and was) going on. Still farmed today for salt that you can buy at the tourist stand. I think this shoudl be a definite stop if you have a few days in the Valley.
Very nice place to Visit. Very nice place to visit, glad I went there, the display of the Salinas look great.The different things they sell are great for a souvenir

salt mines with brilliant views. Tucked in a valley these salt mines are definitely worth a visit while in Cusco area. They are huge, being produced from a tiny stream through the rocks. A must visit.

Very Interesting!. While this tour is not a common one for visitors to Cusco to take, we went with Alpaca Expeditions and were very happy we did. We had no idea there would be a place in the mountains where salt would be produced, rather than in the sea. The site has shops and even a stand to try the fermented corn drink, which we loved! If you have a spare half day in cusco, consider visiting this picturesque place.

A must see. Went there only because it was part of another tour and wasn't expecting very much. Quite an unbelievable sight. I have never seen anything like it. The guide was very informative. Well worth making the effort.

Plenty of salt...no pepper. Ive been to the Salinas a number of times.The view as you wind down the dusty road can be quite impressive.But..depending on the time of year that view can change considerably.At best its a brilliant white and at worst its a mixture of whites and muddy browns.A leisurely stroll around the salinas can give you some great photo shoots if you are imaginative.The location of the site is stunning and certainly beats that of a typical salina by the sea. Taste a drop of the water in the small river up above and you will know where the salt comes from.

Great photos, great food. We ate lunch at their cafe, and walked around on the walls of the pools. We even talked with some workers who told us how they mine the salt, how long it takes, how they all are owners and work for the collective. Very impressive.

it looks fake but when you get closer WOW. as soon as we saw it we coudn believe it was real, it looks like nothing ive seen before, i still dont understand where all that salty water comes from but nice place to visit in cusco

A unique place (in the mountains). This is a must-see place. At the beginning it was not in our plans but fortunately we added it to fill our spare time after our visit to the Ollantaytambo fortress (from Ollantaytambo it takes around 50 minutes to get there).We went a bit late (at sunset around 5 pm) and we found the pools of a beautiful pink-orange color.

Salt in the middle of nowhere. When you turn the bend on the windy, narrow road that barely allows two cars to pass each other, you look down from way up and see blocks of white. The salt mines are a spectacular site -- from up on the hill and from close up. We learned the history of this natural salt mine that was used during the Inkan empire, and tasted the warm water, salty water that flows from an old volcanic mountain into the salt mine. A fun experience on a day of visiting ruins

A must see !. This is an unique occasion to see how Inca created this place to exploit salt from a little salty river. All is still in place since Inca time and is very impressive and science fiction images. You can also buy salt there, they have three qualities but the pink one seems to be the best for our health. We bought one kg !
Do not miss this. Absolutely stunning. Amazing the Incas did this, beautiful and a must see. Where you hiking boots and a lot of sunscreen.

Interesting salt pools.. It's worth visiting the main way that Peru get it salt from.In this place you can see how they collect their salt and if you wish buy local handicraft.The salt come from a single water font that fill all the salt polls.The fee to visit is around 7 soles.

nice place. As it isn't a popular place to go in Peru, I found a little bit difficult to find agencies to take us there, most people get there by car.I didn't regret to know Salinas de Maras and I strongly recommend if you have a free day in Cusco.
Fantastic place. Well worth the effort to reach there. Great history and excellent from a photography point of view, if that is what you like.
Worth the long drive. Very cute little place which brought us home with owes some pics. Loved it. As usual when going to any place in peru have your TP and soap with you.

Amazing. I had never seen anything like this before - getting to these salt flats was via a rather bumpy gravel road, but worth the time. It doesn't take long to see everything there but it is a very interesting place and there is, of course, the opportunity to buy some of the product before you leave. Makes a good trip incorporated with Mara and Pisac area

Worth a visit. These inca salt mines are indeed worth the visit. Your guide will be able to explain all the "engineering" ways the incas instituted to harvest the salt. The farming co-ops in the area still use these inca techniques these days, and it is a supplement to their income during the summer months. There are also a few "souvenir" stores at this site. Make sure you taste the saltiness of the water that has been running down the hill slopes for centuries."

Unique Experience. Well worth hiking to Salinas to experience the lay of the land. What a sight to behold as you round the corner and see the collecting pools that have been in use since Inca times to collect salt. A sight indeed if you are in the Sacred Valley, especially if staying in Urubamba.
Impressive. Slightly scary taxi drive to get there - look at the tyres before you get in! This site is definitely worth a visit.

Quite unique after all the ruins. After so many churches, cathedrals and ruins, it was great to have a change of scenery. It wasn't that far away from Urubamba where we were staying, nor from Ollantaytambo, so it is an easy trip. Worth the diversion.

Incredible!. Amazing place and even more so when realizing that people nowadays still make a living from the salt they harvest here. Apart from that it is a beautiful place to visit with its geometrically shaped salt pans.

Ride to it to truly appreciate. Visited this interesting site on a mountain bike tour and it was the crowning glory at the end of a long and thrilling downhill section. It's really an amazing thing to be able to walk right out and around the various pits and pools of salt in various stages. Nice tasters of salty corn, plantain, and beans with reasonable prices on those packaged as well as various grades of salt from the mines. I say "Go see this one" - on a bike! Or bus...car...
interresting visit. very interresting visit but such a scarry road to get there!!bring lots of water and sunscreen!!wish we visit during the 'ON' season!

amazing. The combo Moray + Salinas can easily be done on your own on your way back from Machu Picchu and is a fantastic addition to your travel itinerary.Have no fear of an Inca overload here because the sights are absolutely amazing.And the best part is you don't need to pay a ridiculously high entrance fee to see this. (If you include all costs Machu Picchu is pretty darn expensive and I'm not even talking about this boleto turistico...)Indepent travellers have no excuse. Unmissable!

Nice vista must visit on your way to Moray. Most people will visit the salinas & Moray as part of the same tour anyway. If you're an independent traveler the salinas view is worth the detour on the road to Maras. We didn't do the walk through the salinas, but enjoyed the view from the gravel road on the oposite hill.

Incredible. Never imagined something like that, must see! To get there, the landscape is incredible, we went in a bike trail and I loved but I think in a bus would be just as good landscape! Once you get there, it seems small but it is more than 3000 salt pools explored by families and you start thinking "where this water comes from?" and "salt tastes different?"...I thought it was different than everything else I have seen before.

Salt. Maya Angelou said, “Perhaps travel cannot prevent bigotry, but by demonstrating that all people cry, laugh, eat, worry, and die, it can introduce the idea that if we try and understand each other, we may even become friends.” We went to Salinas de Maras the day after Maya Angelou died. From a distance, the salt mines are pure spectacle; each pan has its own color, deep golden, rich caramel, creamy white. Each pan yields salt with its own distinct character, hundreds of varieties. Although it’s backbreaking work in the hot sun, the workers are cheerful and proud of what they produce. And so I think the mines are beautiful because of the spectacle of the scene and the spirit of the people.
Interesting Place. This place vista it's amazing. Just be aware that some tour guides will explain the origins of salt water based more on folk tales than on factual information.
unique. This was something i had not seen before. You can walk inbetween the salinas and taste the salty water. You can also see how they collect the salt. I liked it.

Impressive !!!. My goodness this place as farrrrrr from cusco city, but it's worth a visit. You will regret, if you won't come. It's amazing in how ancient people know how to make salt mine, especially very huge one.

No less than mind boggling. We didn't quite know what to expect, but the view was absolutely mind boggling. We took a taxi driver from Urubamba bus terminal to take us there. A very friendly and informative guy called Victor, who took us first there and then to Moray (the circular terraces). Well worth the visit. When you pay for entrance know that this money is going to the people of Maras, which is a pretty poor village. The salt, sold in 25 kg bags, is cheap and while the company which markets it may get more money, the people of Maras, who own the salt mines don't get much, so feel free to spend.
Fascinating!. We almost skipped Maras and we are quite happy we didn't. It was really interesting. Amazing spring fed salt pans. Great spot for photos!

Places that make you go "Huh". This is a National Geographic type of place and may not interest everyone. Culturally and historically interesting, its included in a half day tour with one other site. 2-3000 salt pans, spring fed, and human ingenuity. If on your own, allow 30-60 minutes.

other worldly. Man there are some strange things on this planet and this is one of it. It's only a quick visit, as much time spent buying souvenirs as being in awe at what the Incans did. But see it. Combine it with a trip to Moray and you'll have one heck of a morning/early afternoon outside of Cusco. Seeing a site that is still in use after hundreds of years, it's awe inspiring, and just unbelievably clever how the Incans, and now modern day 'farmers' harvest salt. Doesn't even smell bad!!
Age old salt pans. Used from inca times to collect salt to mummify the dead, it is very interesting to see the salt pans are still in use, using the same method.
Best experience in Cusco. After Machu Picchu this was the most interesting experience from Cusco...part of the boleto turistico...can be reached by very affordable tours (S 30) arranged from Cusco

Salt mining mmm.... This was my husbands choice, but I found it very interesting. Our guide explained how mining is done and the way the water is channeled to all of the terrains, how family's mine the area. We got to walk all through the mines for close up feel. Surprisingly interesting!
Amazing!. What a fascinating place! We were able to walk along the edges of the salt pools and see how the salt is harvested.

Beautiful. A very interesting pit stop. Great spot to take pictures! You are able to walk around on the edges of the salt flats which is quite amazing.BUY SALT. I bought a few bags and am SO HAPPY. My mum thought she would be able to pick some up later on our trip, perhaps at the Pisac Market, but we couldn't find it anywhere. BUY SALT - YOU WON'T REGRET IT. Great souvenir, and take photos to show people where it came from.

interesting place. You get to this place via the Maras-Moray route tour, which takes 6 or 7 hours.The place is beautiful so you will take great pictures and you will find yummy salty food available for purchase and also souvenirs made out of salt.Apart from the salineras there is not much to see. But if you go by mountain bike, motorcycle or ATV you will have a lot more fun since the terrain is great for dirt sports and the scenery from Cusco to Maras is amazing. Just ask around the tour vendors around the plaza for an ATV or a bike and eventually you will find one.

A Very Cool Place !. Totally forth it if you go towards Machu Picchu. From different angles you can get a an awesome pictures! Besides now you'll know how they get salt! Cause people are actually working there! :)
Incredible. One of my favorite stops in the Cusco area. Breathtaking when you first see the massive salt mines. A little tough to get to, and would recommend hiring a guide/driver for a few hours.

A picture does not say a 1,000 words. This is one place where seeing is believing. All of the photos that I saw of the Salinas de Maras did not compare with the actual site. If you have the time and opportunity, this is a place you may wish to add to your Itinerary.To imagine the community has been mining salt in the same place in the same manner for hundreds of years is mind-boggling. Their techniques respect their environment and does not promote pollution.Our sadness on seeing how foreign visitors felt their need to leave their names/marks in the salt. A true sign of disrespect for other's property.

Nice to see... but not a must-see. If you have little time aroud Cusco this is an attraction you could pass. There are other better highlights. It's ohotogenic and the trip to it has nice views (but then Moray is more interesting in my opinion, and beware that when it is the rainy season it is definitely less interesting to go to.
Very cool...have never seen these many salt ponds!. Very interesting to find out the process of how salt was harvested from the ponds! This place was very unusual to me.

Beautiful place in the Sacred Valley. It is a magical place, it looks like a postcard or a painting by the best Artist in the world. You can walk places intended for tourists or venture and climb down to where the "farmers" or "miners" who are local people which pour the supersalted water into flat pools which and dried under the sun, leaving a salty crust, day after day. This people are drying and harvesting the extracted salt.They are using the ancestral Inca technique, and a plus is that this salt is the BEST for barbecuing.I highly recommend it, is a MUST in your trip to the Sacred Valley. You will not regret.

One of the neatest things I've seen!. We thought this place was amazing. It was about 21 soles for 4 of us to get in-cheap. We wandered around about an hour, but you could see it in less time. After driving down a dirt road, you'll park and see some little stores selling handicrafts and salts. Then, walk down some stairs and wander around the 3,000 pools. You can walk around the pools and see up close what a marvel this place is. These salt pools have been in production since pre-Incan times. They are passed down from one generation to the next. The warm, salty water comes from an underground stream. The flow is diverted every which way to get water to the farthest reaches. You'll likely see workers cleaning and harvesting the salt. Stop and buy some salt before you leave. Great place for photos!

Quite a unique place that's worth a visit. If you are planning to do the moray ruins, you should definitely go here too - the place has a very special atmosphere and makes for some amazing pictures. Getting there is easy and very affordable by public transport and to the salineras and moray I recommend taking a cab/collectivo. Definitely haggle about the price and try to get them to drive you down to the Urubamba bus station when you're done!
Salty. It is a salt plant, I suppose since Inka days. Novel. Bought some flavored salt for gifts and a sweater for my daughter.
Nice change of pace. Great change of scenery from the ruins. After a while, all of the ruins start to look the same and they all pale in comparison to Macchu Picchu.

shining pools. We visited the Salinas and Moray on the same afternoon. Our hosts at La Capilla Lodge in Urubamba arranged a taxi to drive us to both sites. It was a nice afternoon activity. Entrance fee is 7 soles pp. We spent 30-40 minutes there. Watching the workers, admiring the landscape and taking some nice pictures.

Fascinating salt ponds. Review with a lot of photos: http://shrimp2.pixnet.net/blog/post/105374345Maras, a town in the Sacred Valley, is well known for its salt evaporation ponds.Smart Inca people obtained salt by evaporation salty water since pre-Inca times. It'a really interesting to take closer look to this salt mines.For me, it's very incredible how they build the salt ponds in remote mountains.In Taiwan, we have Chiku Yanshan which is the largest sun-driedfiled for sea salts in Taiwan southwest coast.You could climb the salt mountain and have salty ice creamStrongly recommend that join tour instead taking taxi to Maras.The road to Maras is only by poorly dirt road.
Very unique place! Worth to visit it!. Very unique place! Very close to Moray and OllantaytamboBring money with you to buy flavored salt and bath salts

Worth the stop!. I was very impressed by these salt terraces. They are massive and there are plenty of great perspectives to help appreciate the sheer size of the area. You are also able to see the workers mine the salt, block and redirect the source saltwater. Don't forget to buy some salt for cooking and salt for your bath at home. The vendors also have a wide variety of salted corn and lima beans. grab some for a snack.
This was really worth a visit. I have never seen anything like this. It is near Morey, which is also worth a visit but I don't see it on the list here.

Impressive. An amazing site, which is a real change from all the Inca sites you've been visiting around. We visited it during lunch time, so the Salinas were empty ; it was good for taking pictures, but we did not see people working. Maybe if we had spent more time there, but we were hungry and eager to arrive in Ollantaytambo, since we visited Maras as a stop on our way between Cusco and Ollantaytambo (100 soles from Cusco to Ollantaytambo, visiting Moray and Maras on the way).

Interesting watch. Go if you have not had a look at a salt mine before. Atmospheric views of the valley nearby and also the cute little shops selling salts, spices and other curios (although those can be gotten anywhere near Cusco). If you do have the 3 - 4 hours you could go to the Salt mines but the suggestion is to do them after you have done Pisac, Ollantaytambo, Urubamba, Chinchero as these are of significant cultural and historical value.

Something Different. If you crave something beyond hiking and ruins, this is the place. It's beautiful and another way for the community to sustain a living and it's been in continuos use since the Incas, add this to your Andean Adventure.

Beautiful and amazing!. If you can try to make time to take a taxi ride out here. You won't need a guide really and a taxi is cheaper. The salt flats are absolutely stunning and it's great to see how the local people flood the flats with warm, natural spring water and harvest the salt. Don't forget your camera!

Well worth the stop. Having never seen Salt Flats before this was worth the stop. It was very interesting to hear how each section is worked by different families, and they are inherited not bought. We got to see some people working the sections digging out the clay, to get ready for more salt water. A must see if in Cusco or Sacred Valley
Unique. Spendid salinas along the slope of the mountain. One can walkd down the Salinas to the main road and go back to Olentaytambo by taxi or public transport. Very nice wall late in the afternoon.

Nice Break from Inca Ruins. I really enjoyed the Salineras. By the time we got here, I was a little tired of seeing Inca ruins and it was nice to have a little break. We showed up just before the dry season, so there were not too many people working, but the guide said that in a couple of weeks people would come and work. A family could own a couple of plots. Each plot is filled with salt water from a near by spring and in about two weeks they could collect the salt. There are also opportunities to buy the salt for a good price. As many people have stated, the Salineras are not included in the Boleto Turistico, but it is definitely worth visiting, especially if you are looking for something different.

Super interesting. Guide explained how this is a community effort, and it harvests several types of salt, all with mineral benefits. Of course, you get a chance to buy some. We'll see if we can taste the difference.
A must see. We went up the Salinas in horse ride. a unique place used by the Incas and still working. Views of the mountain surrounding are incredible

Mountain Biking to the salt pans. This was a big surprise to us on our recent trip. Our travel agent talked us into taking a mountain biking excursion ( with a guide) to the salt pans. I don't care to bike but my husband convinced my I should go. I was not enthusiastic but in the interest of being a good sport went along with it. We had a great time. I had no idea what the salt pans were but we found them wildly interesting. This may be because we had a wonderful guide who told us the history of the area and also explained how the local people use the salt pans now. After biking from Maras to the salt pans , we walked through the area and then hiked down to the valley. Most people seemed to just look at the area and then leave. I doubt we would have enjoyed it as much without a guide explaining what we were looking at.

Amazing!. From the initial view from the vista as you drive the single lane road to the site to the point when you are standing by the salt pans themselves, you will be quite amazed! Not only is the site unique in terms of what you see (salt pans in various stages of evaporation and salt crystallization) but also because about the unique nature of the water source that allows this to happen since Pre Inka times. The site costs 7 nuevo soles and requires you to walk down several sets of stair cases to view the pans themselves. The site required no more than 1 hour and there were several places to stop along the way down (and up) to rest, have a drink or buy some salt. We thoroughly recommend visiting.

Salt,salt and more salt. I had never seen river salt so this place was nice.The view of the salt trenches from the top of the mountain is amazing.The salt itself tastes a lot better than the sea salt.

half day tour from cusco. we took a half day tour which included these salt pools and the moray ruins, through the travel agent at ecopackers. it was interesting and worthwhile if you have limited time and want to see some of the local ruins/culture. we were not a fan of the restaurant at the top of the salt mines, the chicken pasty seemed stale and left a tummy ache.

Unique.. The attraction costs 7 soles per person but it is worth it. Very different from the usual salt mines we have visited in that it is terraced and owned/farmed by nearly 200 families. There are shops, rest rooms and snack bars in the parking lot area. If you'd like, you can hike down to the ponds and get a close up look. The salt is also sold at the shops in varying degrees of quality - some are used as a condiment, other types are used as bath salts. Your driver may stop in Maras' main plaza for some photos which showcases a statue/sculpture the town's ties to the salt mining industry.
Fascinating. Worth a visit to see the hundreds of salt pans owned by different families and learn about the process of evaporation to get the salt. Great photo opportunities.
u have to see it in person...pics do this place no justice. Amazing place....hundreds of salt mines, never seen something like this...so cool and unique. And then you can buy salt....hell yeah!!!

Definately include on your Itinerary! ( Taxi cost included in review ). This, and the neighboring Moray are very much worth a few hours of precious itinerary time. You've seen the pictures, but to see the site firsthand is really very cool. I have seen salt flats in the Caribbean before, where they flood a huge diked field and then once evaporated move the massive amounts of salt with a bulldozer, but this site was even more spectacular due to the immense amount of individual pools, all hand worked, terraced on a hillside. Here they sit on the side of a mountain, deep in a ravine, and the +/- 4500 pools ( numbers vary; Eyewitness guide book says 3000 but our driver told us 4500 ) cascading down the steep hill is quite impressive. The drive there will take you past some incredible scenery, sprawling, rolling fields which end in snow capped majestic, high mountains. Then there's the one lane dirt decent road that takes you down to the entrance on the edge of a cliff with several blinds corners:)So what we did was hire a taxi from the plaza in Olly to take us to Salinas, Moray, and Chinchero, waiting at the sites, and then delivering us to check in to our hotel in Cusco. We had no trouble finding a willing driver, and the price paid was 150 soles. It could have been bargained down further, but we thought this a fair price for what was going to be 6 full hours of traveling time ( not including his return trip home ), which turned out to be exactly what it was. He stopped for us to take photos along the way, and spoke decent enough English. He also pointed out relevant facts and highlights along the way which was nice.
Magic. Thoses 5000 Little lakes are amazing! It is a really pretty place that you cant miss if you are in that área. Also, tour for that place are not long so you just need half of a day.

Brilliant day trip. We visited Maras along with Moray one afternoon from Cusco. Very interesting to see the salt mines which are owned by 180 families - the better quality salt coming from the top ponds. There are also little stalls selling salt and things made from the salt and other cute souvenirs. The mountain scenery is spectacular. Lots of photo opportunities.

Really spectacular. Admittedly, there's not a whole lot to do here, but it's still worth a trip just to see the salt pans. There are hundreds of them. It's really impressive to see. Walking out to see the pans, the path is very narrow, so it's best to go when it's least busy. We visited first thing in the morning, which seemed like the right time. As we were leaving, a large tour bus had just arrived.Speaking of tours, we did not take one, but there are many tours that combine visits to Moray with las Salineras. keep in mind that Moray is included on the boleto truistico, but the Salineras are not.This is also a good place to buy gifts that your friends and family will actually use. They sell all kinds of salts and it is very cheap. The fried plantains are also a delicious snack.

fascinating. We stopped at these salt mines as part of our biking trip while in peru,the cost was 7sol and our bike guild gave us a quick talk about the mines and the region. The mines are owned by family's which each owns between 5 and 10 of these pods,the salt is then sold to a co-op.We did see some people working these mines and it looks very hard work.

We found these salt ponds fascinating. Although we have visited other salt ponds and mines, these are of particular interest because of having been started by the Incas using the warm spring water running out from the subterranean remains of the ancient oceans.

Great day trip from Cusco. I visited Salinas in conjunction with Moray and this was by far the better of the two sites. It's simply amazing how extensive this place is and because it's out of the way you're unlikely to see many tourists here. It's almost like a cross between Pamukale in Turkey and the tanning baths in Morocco which I've visited several years ago. A visit to the site should take about 30 minutes and is well worth the journey there from Cusco. Entry to the site is 7 soles. There are two ways to get there: The first is by taxi, which should cost between 20 an 25 soles including waiting time from the turnoff to Maras; The second is to go it on foot which should take the best part of an hour and a half each way from the turnoff, though I wouldn't recommend it as the scenery isn't very interesting on the way there. There are tours from Cusco that visit the Salinas, Maras and Moray for a reasonable price (can't recall how much they cost). However, it's very easy to visit Moray and the Salinas by yourself and it will work out cheaper than the tours if you go in a group. All you have to do is take a collective bound for Ollantaytambo from Avenida Pavitos (5 minutes from Plaza de Armas) for between 5 - 10 Soles and ask to be dropped off at the "ramal" to Maras. There will be colectivos available to take you to Maras, which is 4km away, for 1 Sol or you can negotiate a trip taking in Moray and Maras for about 40-45 Soles which will include waiting time (whole trip is about 2.5 hours). I you're really hardy then you could walk from the Ramal to Moray (about 10km) and then to the Salinas (the turnoff is about 2km from the ramal), though this would take all day as it's about 30km all up.

Visit to the salt evaporation ponds. These salt ponds date back to Pre Columbian times. The naturally salty water is moved into evaporation ponds. The water evaporates, leaving the salt to be bagged and sold.Given the large numbers of ponds, it provides an interesting photo opportunity. Restroom facilities are well maintained

Cool place. We got there in an organized day trip from Cusco that includes the salinas and the Morray. Was really nice to change an atmosphere after all the ruins on every other tour. This place is real gem and you can buy great different souvenirs in it
Worth a visit. It's a huge salt mine all over the mountain. I never saw a saline like that. They did a big work on the mountains. Amazing.

Just jump in the van and enjoy. It was amazing sites, I jump in the van from Cusco and in 1h30 I open my eyes in front of these sites and really was spectacular.You have in front one of the best site of the sacred valley and around you the mountain with snow at the top just beautifulIf you have a camera bring it and take all the picture you can have :)

Must See!. We visited both Maras Moray and Salinas on a half day tour. Pick up from Square Regico at 9am, and returned to the city around 3:30pm. This would be a great thing to schedule if you have just landed and looking to take it easy while adjusting to the altitude.IMO, I would recommend this over the sacred valley IF and ONLY IF you are doing the Inca Trails. As on the trails you pass by a few Inca Ruins which are similar to what you would see in the Sacred Valley. Where as Maras Moray and Salinas are very different!7 Soles to enter as of March 2014. Remember that this is where they dry the salt so it does get quite hot so don't forget sun protection/stay hydrated.Great experience!

Beautiful Pictures! Worth the visit.. 7 Soles to enterHad a great time at the Salt Mines. It's really a interesting place. Run by the people who live in the local town, Maras is a real experience. Each person is responsible for a couple of pools. They fill them with water and when it evaporates the salt is left. Make sure to buy some salt on the way out. Really cheap! I brought way too much salt home. Put your hand and the stream that fills the pools. It's interesting how much salt is in the water.Cheers!
hard to find. and a long hike uphill which was not mentionned in our Lonely Planet guide ... we were disappointed. We could have done that hike but we did not have enough time.

Great way to get fit for walking. We walked from the bottom of the hill near Urubamba. A one and a half hour up hill walk to the salt flats of Maras. There were fascinating and rather beautiful. They are apparently owned by individual families and the salt is sold to a co-op. You can go by bus or car as well.If you keep walking you will reach the moras amphitheatre.

Fascinating!. Who knew we'd find something to shop for at Salt Pans! This is an amazing place with salt mining passed down through generations of families. Truly interesting. And, to top it off, our joke was we could find something to shop for anywhere! This was no exception. Brought home some great cooking salts. :)

Like a little Machu Pichu in salt.... Had a great guide and in addition the whole process of the fabrication of salt is of great interest to me. Fascinating history and culture and very lovely to take in.

Pretty amazing place of business. It is a tourist attraction but is actually being worked by families in the area, local Peruvians own 2-4 (or more) pools and harvest the salt for profit for their family. Great view into the local culture. Great views!

Incas are ingenious. Be prepared for a hike down steep unlevel steps and be rewarded by seeing incan ingenuity at its best. The locals give you free tastings of salted products. All extremely tasty and moreish. There are numerous stalls to buy things. I found the middle section stall to be the cheapest for the same products.Clean toilets, lots of places to rest as you trek back up the winding path. The dirt road us narrow and yiu feel like you're in an episode of Deadly Roads when another bus passes. But one adrenalin rush a day can't be too unhealthy!!

Simply Amaizing. I can not believe how the Inca civilization were able to engineer such a place! The view from the opposite mountain is just breathtaking. The place is pristinely kept and the actual salt pool are just a marvel to see. We were able to actually walk to the pools and touch and experience the salt gathering process. It is really a place to visit while in the area.

Very Interesting. We recently visited this site. It is not active during this season. During the high season (dry season) is when the salt harvesting occurs. It was still interesting to see the salt pans and purchase some salt. Our guide explained the process to us.
Great stop en route to Machu Pichu!. Maras salt works are amazing to see. Very tasty offerings for sale. Great alternate route from Cusco to Machu Pichu.

Spectacular. Must do and see!. Next best for me after Machu Picchu. This place was really mind boggaling and to think it was built so many years ago and is still in operation today. We took quadbikes from Cusco to Moray and Maras and seeing the salt mines while you quadbike down to the entrance is amazing. Loved it.

Very interesting. This site is huge! What is amazing is to see the small springs coming out of the rocks and know that this is the source of all of the salt harvested from the various terraces. Very neat.

Enormous - what a site!. It is worth the small detour is you are staying in Urubamaba - Beautiful salt mines that stretch over the face of a mountain. the stores make it very touristy and the (paying) bathroom are quite gross --- that said - I think i would go back and I certainly would recommend it

And you thought that the Dead Sea was Salty!. From a small spring-like stream coming out of the hillside, hundreds of salt pools capture and contain this precious source of commercial salt. The water is then evaporated by the sun resulting in a salt residue that is harvested by the owners, bagged and sold or used for their own purposes. Operated as a village commune, each salt pool is allocated to a community family to be tended as a source of income. The collective pools are controlled and maintained by the collective and the result is a fascinating scene of salt, salt crystals and pools in various states of evaporation. This creates the colour variations that make this into a kind of crazy quilt of colours. There is a gift shop with crystals, fossils, local crafts and refreshments. It is an easy cab ride from Cusco and consider spending some time exploring the historic architecture in nearby towns influenced by the Spanish.
Salt pans. We did a great hike with the South American Explorers club from Urubamba to Maras. It was gorgeous! Matt and Andy were great guides.
Great experience. Got a taxi here from Ollantytambo. Really good mpprning out. Amazing place. Lots of local salt to buy

interesting!. Easy to visit in a day trip to Moray. Its very interesting, the salt quarters have been exploited for over a century belonging to the same families. Its a cool sight, doesn't take too long to see.
Interesting. This was a very interesting site. Doesn't require a lot of time but interesting how the salt is mined.

Worth all the switchbacks. We came here during our trip to the Sacred Valley. It's a truly amazing sight to behold. We watched a man flattening of the salt ponds to prepare for another harvest. Great place for photos.

Interesting. This doesn't need alot of time but is well worth the stop. The salt water comes from underground and is directed to the pans via small channels. It is allowed to dry and then harvested. They get $18 for a 50kg bag. The work is done the same as it was by the Inca and looks back breaking. It is only done during the dry months as rain will ruin the process.

Great diversion from Inca ruins. The drive to this location is not for all. But it does afford great views of the terraces. Take the drive up - BUT hike down thru the salt ponds to the river for a much better experience. See how they are still keeping the salt ponds active - but now make more on tourist than on the salt.

Red and White marvel. A short and easy taxi drive from our hotel in Urubamba prior to hiking the Inca Trail, the Salinas were definitely worth the few hours we spent there. Walking across the multiple salt basins was fun and allowed great photos. You can buy salt to the several vendors after the visit - make great small gifts to bring back home.

It was fun seeing the Salinas and the salt being sold at the local Cuscu market. We climbed the back way to the Salineras and shared the trail with local salineras workers as well as burros. The pools look so beautiful but seeing the pinkish salt being sold at the San Pedro market the next day was a hoot.

What a magnificent place. On your way to the Sacred Valley do not miss the opportunity to visit Maras, a lovely place where the local produce gourmet salt in a natural way in an spectacular place, right on the mountain cliff
Everybody seemed to enjoy the way salt is extracted from the little ponds, and besides, the view is really something not to miss
Fascinating. I rode above them and they were beautiful and unreal. Every shade or red and clay, some with crystals. They stretched forever up the canyon. A real marvel.
Unexpected and beautiful!. So beautiful! We were taken here by taxi and the we hiked down to Tunupu restaurant after, Well worth it! The views are incredible and the hiking spectacular!

a very interesting experience. On the way to the Sacred Valley, I was recommended to visit the Salinas de Maras. I loved it. It is a very interesting attractions, souvenirs are sold at reasonable prices and you can even taste the salt of the Salinas. I am sure that this visit will become a MUST in the future when visiting Cusco.
Worth the visit. even if we you have already visited Salines, these are worth the visit. Our teens were really into the adventure.

Picturesque Salineras. The visit of the salineras near Moray is a must when you are in the Sacred Valley. Hundreds of small pools, each producing 200kg of salt every month since more than 500 years.
Very picturesque place!

One of my favorite sites. I loved experiencing the salt mines during my stay in Cusco! This was one of the most interesting sites for me, maybe because it was so different that the other sites...and I love salt! I was able to buy several bags of salt for very reasonable prices to bring back to the states. I would recommend this excursion to anyone visiting Cusco, it is included with the partial admission ticket to the Sacred Valley but is a separate adventure...take advantage of it!

A welcome change from Inca ruins. It’s quite a spectacular sight, and makes a change from looking at rocks, although we are told that thee salt flats have been farmed since pre Inca times. The salt deposits on the rock walls make for same nice abstract photo compositions (see my pictures).

Just beautiful!. It's one of the most amazing sights I had in my trip to Peru. To see that white mountain, in the midle of the brown valley is really impressive. You can buy gourmet sault for a very low price.

A Unique and Interesting Place to Visit. If you are in the area, I highly recommend a brief stop here to get a few photos of this very unusual place. I was impressed that the locals have been drying the warm salty water that comes out of a spring here for centuries in hundreds of shallow evaporating pans cascading down a valley. These pans have been continually in use since Inca times. The best time to visit is in the dry season when there are more of the salt pans that are white from the drying salt. I was there in the rainy season so not as much white, but it was still impressive and photogenic. There is a small entrance fee for visitors. You can see the place where the warm salt waters comes out of the ground, and dip you hand into the water and give it a taste - really salty. The water flows by gravity through a series of channels and is let into the pans. During the dry season it takes about 20 days before the salt can be harvested. There are a few shops where you cab inexpensively purchase bags of the salt to take home as great gifts. Plan to spend no more than an hour.
Interesting site. We had a great guide in Fernando Chara who made our trip very enjoyable with lots of insight into the past and present use of these salt pans

Amazon Andean salt ponds. Great views on the way to this place. Beautiful effects of the salt ponds. Worth a visit. .... I am now just making up words to reach the desired fifty characters for this review.

Fascinating!. There are so many things to see in the Cusco area, but this is different from the traditional Incan ruins, and worth the trip, I think. If you take a half-day tour from Cusco, Maras is usually packaged with a trip to Moray, which is also very interesting. The unique thing about this is that the water that rises from the ground & fills the pans IS ALREADY salt water -- in the middle of the Andes! Historically and visually, it's quite stunning.
Not to be missed!. A most dramatic Incan construct to capture salty water, dry it in terraced pools and harvest it. Amazing to consider and to see!

Interesting, unique place to see. We hiked up to it from where we stayed in Urubamba. A bit of a trek but worth it for the sites of everyday life of these still very primitive people along the way. The salt mines themselves are very unique, never seen anything like it. Not much to do once you are there but views are great. Wish they provided tours or information about the mines, how they work, etc and we would have gotten a bit more out of it.

On our cab ride from Ollyantaytambo to Cusco on Sept. 2012. My friend and I were visiting Peru to make our four day trek on the Inca Trail. On our way back after we have visited Machu Picchu, we decided to spend the night in Ollyantaytambo. After our tour of the town that morning, we paid $80 to take a cab from Ollyantaytambo to Cusco. We made arrangements with the cab driver to make stops at Moray and Salinas de Maras. Our last stop was Salinas de Maras which was a naturally terraced salt mine. We spent about an hour there taking pictures, buying salt and souvenirs from local vendors, and eating lunch (sandwiches we bought earlier in the day). I thought it was worth the visit.
There are a lot more to see in the area. After Salar de Uyuini nothing special.The view from nearest mountain is nice. We spent 30 min there and it's max which you should spent for it.

Ok to visit in the rainy months. The tour book says it's difficult to visit in the rainy season but we did just fine. We walked on the edges of the terraces which can be very physically challenging, especially going down the train, really just a stream bed, on the other side opposite the entrance. I felt it was well worth the walk.

Interesting salt mine. This place is good to combine with a visit to Moray. The salt mines are naturally terraced into the hill side and supplied with salt from a small stream of salt water that comes out of the mountain. You can easily walk around and see how the salt cultivation takes place and buy some Maras salt from local vendors. A great educational experience.
amazing landscape. You get to see an amazing landscape, there are shops where you can buy pink salt. Normally tours also include the visit to moray. I think it is worthy.
Salt. My friend and I hired a cab to take us here. It is interesting how they excavate the salt. We walked in this skinny pathways...make sure you know how to balance yourself.
salt mines. find this kind of landscape in the andes is unpredictable, and know that the local people use it to obtain money for education of their kids is very nice!!!

Interesting. We visited the Salinas in combination with the terraces of Moray. The scenery is impressive as everywhere in the Sacred Valley. To see the salt flats and watch how the salt is excavated is very interesting. Walking around the various pools is treacherous but worth the effort. I wouldn't make the trip from Cusco just for this, but in combination with other areas in the valley, it is a nice add on.

Good stop, Interesting story. A good stop on the way to Moray. It is not included in your Boleto Turistico, but a 7 soles entry it is worthwhile. Consisting of various salt ponds that are fed from a salt water spring, the hill side is covered in drying ponds. We went in the summer (January) and the pools were a bit wet and muddy because of the rain. During the winter (July) it might be better since you will see more white salt drying.

You can believe time has stopped!. Well there is definitely nothing like this in Europe (at least not that we've discovered). It seems to be at least 500 years old, and probably goes back before that. But you get the impression that just about nothing has changed, apart from the presence of the gift shop.We visited as part of a half-day 'two site' trip from Cusco (the other site was Moray Maras). Our mini-bus took us through the outskirts of Cusco to the hills and plains overlooking the Sacred Valley. The two sites were interesting, but as interesting was the opportunity to get an impression of more everyday life in this part of Peru and away from the World Heritage atmosphere of Cusco. Our trip included a stop at a small museum of weaving where a local womens' co-op used traditional methods to make a variet of textiles. We felt a lot happier buying here than at one of the commercial outlets in the city centre.Top tip: you can find yourself signing up for a full-day trip to four or more sites like Moray Maras and the Salinas, but we were happy to take the pressure off with half-day visits to a smaller number of sites.

What a blend of Colors!!! Must see. This was absolutely one of the best naturally color coordinated sites on my trip to Peru. The drive up there was awesome, it seemed like we were on a dirt road leading to nowhere. Great place for picture shots.

Nice to See. If you have the time and are not afraid of the most unsafe drive I have ever seen, this site is worth a visit. The road leading to the salt pans is single lane, no railing and a sheer cliff. There is no way this would be allowed in the USA. That being said, anyone with the time and a fearless attitude should visit. There is a great view of the salt pans from up high and seeing them up close is impressive.

Strange place. looks like anothe planet, is very rare and unique place, you must to visit and buy salt, you can pay for that 4 soles for gourmet package. also you can eat frite bananas, cancha...in my opinion the locals need to improve the place and make it better.

Sacred Valley Gem. After seeing so many Incan ruins, the Salinas was a refreshingly different stop. The salt ponds are an amazing site to see from the road above. They spill over the side of the mountain and are all fed from one small, warm salt water stream. The stream is diverted to run into the ponds, which have been in use since pre-Incan times. Check out the mountain bike tours which go here and nearby Moray.

Interesting but not as interesting as other Sacred Valley sites. Interesting but not as interesting as other Sacred Valley sites. Bit off the beaten path. The Moray agricultural site and Olantaytambo were much more interesting to me.

Ancient salt fields worth a visit. Under a near bye mountain lies a huge natural bed of solidified salt, through which runs a small spring of water. Once this water leaves the mountain, it has become " brine ", or salt saturated. The Inca's found this and built small salt evaporation pans, as salt water is evaporated in shallow pans over a month to leave a thin crust of salt. These salt pans have been enlarged today and support many local families, who sell it. They produce a beautiful pink salt that is popular in many restaurants. Worth a visit to see this marvel. Make sure you hire a guide and safe car as the descent into the pans is steep in places
Salt!. These salt pools are quite incredible, their irrigation designed by the Inca. It is a way down the valley to get there but worth the trip!

Interesting. It's quite close to the town of Urubamba. It's interesting to see the terraced salt ponds in Maras which existed pre Inca days. Getting down the salt pans has it's own adventure here.The salt water springs out of a nearby stream, natural outlets are provided to over 3000 salt polygons managed by many families of a community.

Salinas interesting if visiting Moray. Salinas is not part of your Cusco Tourist ticket, you must pay 10 soles to enter. This money helps the locals who manage the bathrooms and keep the site productive. My suggestion is to combine this stop with a stop to Moray, not far and a different piece of scenery. Taste the water which comes right out of the mountain in a steady spring. We walked and talked to locals on how the salt is processed. They are still refining the salt like the Inca's of old. Make sure it is a dry day, as you must walk very narrow dirt paths between all the pools of salt mud.

Salinas de Maras - Salt Ponds. If you are staying in Urubamba or somewhere close in the Sacred Valley and driving around, this is worth a quick stop. Young children will especially enjoy looking at the way salt is collected in the ponds. My son came home pretty excited about his salt rock. It is NOT a "must see," but worth it if you are in the area anyway. And it does look interesting in pictures.

cool & surreal site. We came here as part of our visit to both Moray (the concentric circles of Inca agricultural laboratory terraces) and Salineras de Maras. There is a little town nearby called Maras but we just drove through it and there's nothing much to see there. The salt mine is what everyone comes to see. We decided to come by ourselves as oppose to going with a tour as we did not manage to book one in time. And I wanted to try in this last full day in Cuzco if I could travel like a real local / smart tourist. Based on my research I thought we would try to get a local bus to Urubamba (only costs like 3 Soles I think) and followed a city map to where the bus station is. However, we never found the station but in the same area there were lots of "combis" (carpool taxis) accosting passersby to take their transportation. One of these combis in an alley way off the street offered to take us at 7 soles each if the car fills up to their full capacity of 4 people. There were 2 of us. At first I wondered how long it would be to find 2 other people who happen to want to go to Urubamba as well but that was no trouble at all. Within a few minutes 2 locals showed up and jumped in the car with us. To go to Maras & Moray one has to travel towards Urubamba and then ask the taxi or bus to drop you off at the junction where the the road to Maras & Moray meets the main road to Urubamba. Based on the description in the travel advice I found, this was easy to spot. There is a bus stop at this junction and there are a bunch of taxis waiting around to take tourists to Moray & Maras. Once we got dropped off a taxi drive came up to us immediately to offer his services. My travel guide said that to hire a taxi for 3 hrs should cost around 50 Soles. Although our taxi driver agreed to this price, I think that that in hindsight we could have probably gotten it down to 40 Soles. 50 Soles is a lot of money in Peru. We were taken to Moray first which is the furthest site of the 2 from the junction. If you didn't get the Boleto Turistico for the Sacred Valley sites (70 Soles for entrance into Ollantaytambo, Pisac, Moray, & another site combined), it's just 10 Soles to enter Moray. After Moray we went to Salineras. Salineras is tucked into a deep but narrow valley / ravine that cannot really be seen until you're right on top of it. Entry into this site is only 7 Soles. The site is beautifully eerie and reminds me of one of those futuristic movies where there is some prison camp mine. If you've never seen a salt mine up close this place is worthwhile to visit. 3 hrs to visit Moray & Salineras together is perfectly sufficient and you can head over from Cuzco and be back within about 4-5 hrs. We left around 9:30am and was back in Cuzco by around 2pm. It's only 30 km away from Cuzco and the scenery you will be treated to is worth it on it's own. You can get a great view of the surrounding mountains around the Sacred Valley very well. An Australian lady we met at Moray asked to share our hired taxi to go to Salineras and back to the junction. We thought that since we were hiring the taxi by time, that she can just chip into the total cost. But our taxi driver would not agree to this and insisted in charging us more for the extra person. In the end he agreed to take her on for an extra 15 Soles. Keep this in mind: All negotiated transactions must be agreed upon upfront. New terms cannot be accommodated later. Once we got back to the junction at the main road, we thought we would try to get on a local bus or combi which ever was available and cost efficient. A very full bus came by first but we decided not to get on. We thought we'd wait for the next bus that supposedly came by quite often, but an empty combi taxi came by and offered to take us all the way back to Cuzco for 5 Soles each!! Wow!! The 3 of us jumped in and soon after another lady was picked up. After almost 2 weeks in the Cuzco area we finally were paying for taxis at the local rate. Lesson learned. All in all Moray & Maras is a perfect half day excursion out of Cuzco. Would highly recommend. Just look up some travel guides either online or in a book for more detailed explanations of the sites. You don't need to go with a tour.

Interesting mining marvel, low effort to see. The Maras salt ponds are an interesting place to visit, and probably worth it because of how easy it is to see if you have just spent time at Moray. It probably does not rise to some place you would drive a couple of hours to just on its own, but you are likely already stopping at the crop terraces in Moray, so swing by Maras directly afterward.Basically, it is a giant salt mine that has been built into the side of a mountain. Salt-rich volcanic water comes down into the salt area where they have built small channels to direct it to one of the hundreds of ponds that are built below. When one pond fills, they close the channel there and direct water elsewhere until all the ponds are filled. What you see is a stunning set of ponds that are of varying colors depending on where in the process that pond is. If you go in June or July, the ponds will all be pristine. If you go in October or November, the ponds might have different colors as the rains will bring mud into some of the ponds.There is a tourist shopping area built around the attraction. The same tourist stuff that can be had elsewhere is all there. We did not really shop, so I cannot comment on prices. They do offer tastes of salted food for free, and they sell that food. The roasted corn, banana, and some other stuff was pretty tasty. We grabbed the bananas as a ride-along treat to our next destination. As driving can be long, this is not a bad idea. And grabbing water is never a bad idea.The site itself features some walking with some stairs. Overall, it is not very difficult, but people with particularly bad knees might find the walk a little bit tough on the way back up. But other than the fairly injured, everyone should be able to enjoy the site.Make sure you get a photo at the pull-off site on the way down to the mines. It offers the most complete photo opportunity.And be aware that if you dip your hands into the ponds, they will be salty. If you are careful about water, you will need to have a bottle of water to wash your hands with before eating other things.There was a small fee at the gate. I believe it was 7 soles per person, guide excluded.

Marasal, Chincheros, Maras & Moray - Great day trip. We hired a car to take us from Cusco to Urubamba, our next destination, and thoroughly enjoyed the stops on the way -- Chincheros weaving market (we weren't there on the main day, Sunday, but still enjoyed a touristy, but still very genuine demo of the weaving), the Incan "agricultural research laboratory" at Moray, near the town of Maras, and finally a stop at the salt ponds at Marasal. The fees for entry at Moray and Marasal are very modest. We arranged the trip through the very excellent husband and wife team at Peruvian Travel y Turismo near Plaza de Armas in Cusco, Luz Marina and Enrique, at www.peruviantravelyturismo.com. Very reasonable cost, very knowledgeable and kind. Highly recommended as an alternative to booking through a hotel. Would work well also if you were returning to Cusco as an intermediate day before or after Machu Picchu. They also organize Inca Trail tours that sounded great and also at a reasonable cost.

Interesting. Well worth visiting if exploring the Cusco / Sacred Valley area. Usually combined with a visit to the Inca site of Moray, the salt pans of Maras make for a fascinating visit. Better in the drier months (May-November) as the salt is a much more stunningly white. A cheap day trip can be organised from any agency around the Plaza de Armas in Cusco. The high-quality salt is also sold in many supermarkets and food stores around Peru.
Breathtaking. Colours are just a party! Maras is natural art and it's worth the visit! Besides the salt they produce is of the finest quality.

A must see!. Amazing place. Definitively a must see when in cusco! The view of the salt pools is incredible.We had a day trip that included Moray anda Maras, and Maras was my favorite! everything is so interesting and so diferent from the rest of the world. If you are travelling for culture, Peru is the right place for you, and so is Maras!You can buy the salt in the market next to the pools, and also salty chocolate. It is worth a try!

There's a lot of salt here.. The salt pans of Maras are not to be missed. First, it's a long drive from the Sacred Valley to get there. Then, it’s a considerable hike to get down to the salt pans. But there are hundreds of salt pools where they produce a delicious salt. And the salty water comes from a natural spring somewhere inside the mountain; and it is warm. A very unusual natural wonder. Simply collecting the salt into bags and hauling them up the hill is a task for the people running this. After taking all of this in, it’s the hike back up that will get your attention as it is somewhere around 12,000 feet

One of the highlights of my Sacred Valley tour. A quite extraordinary place - it's a bit like being on the set of a sci-fi film. The scale is amazing, the basic concept so simple, and seeing the different pools at different stages was really informative.If you want to go deep into it the paths get very narrow and a bit slippery - at one point I had to perch on a small rock while an entire coach-load of Japanese tourists filed slowly past along the narrow path - but if you're nervous about this you can still get a good impression from the higher ground where the paths are much wider and less slippery

Salinas de Maras. We visited the Salinas on horseback on the way to Moray. They are a spectacular demonstration of how traditional methods (of salt mining) are as perfect for their purpose now as hundreds of years ago. You can even go and touch the salt pools. Entry costs s/10 and there's also a large tourist restaurant with a really good menu.

A Must see in Cusco!!!. We spent 2 days in Sacred Valley with one day doing: Chinchero + Moray + SalinerasDefinitely must see this salt mine as it was just amazing!! Walk it through and you will be amazed how they actually build it, the spring was diverted into the layers and layers of pans with the little hand made channels. Different colours of salt and the view of this is just breathtaking! I wondered why it was not ranked higher up in the attraction list~

Excellent experience. We visited the salt terraces as part of a tour arranged through our hotel which included Chincherro, Moray and Salinas de Maras.Tour took us through some awesome landscapes and to be able to walk amongst the terraces and find out more about how they are operated was fascinating and a great experience.Loved it and can't beleive our tour was a bargain 20 USD each leaving at 8.45am from Cusco hotel and returning to main square area at 2.30pm. Really interesting.

Very Salty Place to Visit!. In my opinion the salt mine is an excellent side trip if traveling to Machu Picchu. The salt mines are owned by the local residents of Maras. Family's own a couple small plots, which they work the salt to sell in many forms: for cooking, to mix with other spices, for the table, and therapeutic to name a few. The mine is beautiful with mountains in the background. There are vendors at the site, so you can buy some of the salt products. You might want to negotiate prices. Also, there is a very small church on site, which is neat to see. To get to the site I would suggest hiring a taxi driver who will take you there and wait for you and then take you back to your hotel. Ask about pricing at your hotel.Enjoy the salt!

Tip Toeing Among the Salt Terraces of Maras, Peru. About half an hour drive from the Sacred Valley of the Incas in the town of Urubamba are the interesting salt terraces of Maras. Underground springs passing through subterranean salt mines (thereby extracting salt minerals) spill over the top of a hill and unto ditches that are directed to a coutless number of terraces where the briny water collect, settles, and evaporate leaving salt deposits and crystals. The salt terraces are owned and maintained by a cooperative union comprising of about 200 local families. The salt comes in two grades, the white premium grade and the salmon colored "roseadas" which contain traces of clay. One can tiptoe or walk carefully and slowly among the many terraces. At times, one can see workers harvesting up to 80 kilograms of salt per sack and carried to a nearby storage building. An interesting activity is to have a taste of the briny water trickling down on the terraces. It is a fascinating site to see. If one has some time available at the Urubamba area of the Sacred Valley, this is something worthwhile visiting and seeing.

Unique experience. How many places can you see such a thing? We loved the uniqueness of this place. The fact that the pools are handed down for generations of families. The women are the tenders of the pools. The way the water glows down from the mountain.
Rose Salt. Ancient techniques of separating salt is still used in this place. The Rose Salt is highly valued world-wide and can be bought for a couple of dollars.

Salt Terraces. The history and mystery of this place is worth the difficult drive to get there. Watching the hard work involved is impressive. There are various kinds of salts to buy...cooking, bath, etc. I found the cooking salt at Duty Free.
Its just ok.. Its a salt production pools, nothing spectacular or that I feel is a must see, there are better places more worthwhile.

Simply impressive. We went to Salinas as part of our day trip around the Sacred valley and this was one of the highlights. You don't need much time when you're there, but it's worth seeing the view with your own eyes and from up close. It was getting late when we arrived and our taxi driver asked us if we wanted to just view Salinas from up top or to drive down. I'm so glad that we took the time to really see it. It's nothing like I had ever seen before and seeing it up close gives such a different impression than seeing it from up on the hill. Amazing photo op.If you get to Salinas from Moray, you also get the advantage of a stunning view as you go up a mountain road with many switchbacks. That said, I'm glad that we were in a hired taxi with a responsible driver to get us to Moray and Salinas because the road is fairly steep.The price was 7 soles per person to enter the site. Absolutely worth visiting.

Brilliant. Did a tour of Peru and this was a surprise visit for me.Wasn't aware that salt can be made in this way.Even more surprising that no one knows where the salty water is coming from in the mountains.Definitely worth having a look.On the way there is a chance to try all the lovely edible snacks.

So much more than a photo shows. This was an add on to our tour and was so worth the $40 for the taxi drive. The drive thru the high mountains is fantastic which allows you to see the people farming and living. The site is fantastic. Huge and impressive.
Breathtaking. Words just cannot describe the beauty of this place. The red rock juxtaposed against the white salt. Unbelievable.

Another very interesting site. One more intresting site to visit and l appriciate the knowledge of the Inkas and learn about the way of life of rural communities in Peru. Be sure to have a good guide who will take tell you beyond of what you see.

Loved it. This really was one of the surprising sites of our trip to South America. It can be a place that you just stop and look but you should really spend some time here. We stopped for about an hour and walked through the mines and learned what the workers were doing etc. We actually found it much more interesting than the salt flats in Bolivia and Chile. Definitely worth it if you have some time.

amazing. we took a taxi to get from Cusco to Ollantaytambo and Salinas was one of our stops. Amazing place. You can see it first from the top of the sourrounding hills and then from very close. A magic place. don't miss it !

Interesting to see. The drive down the mountain to get there is quite scary but definitely worth it. The view down the Salinas from the road on top is awesome! And visiting the Salinas is a nice experience. Buy some good salt while you're at it (but shop around, the prices are VERY different from one seller to the other).
Kewl Site!. Easy walk through. Unique geology. Never be allowed in lawyer mad United States. INclude in your day from Ollantaytomba back to Cusco!

Another amazing site. When I first saw these pools from up above, I thought, "oh, look, a local industry.". Then I heard the story of how long these pools had been mined for their salt deposits. The pools are visually stunning, and the length of time that they'be been in use is incredible. The walk down wasn't too bad, but the walk up was a little more strenuous. Fortunately we had to stop along the way to buy our salt souvenir.

In business since 1100s - incredible. These ponds that fill from a salt water spring are used to evaporate the water and leave the salt which is later harvested. It is a process as old as time but the locale of the 3000 ponds is amazing. Salt prices are very low but these ponds are a great contributor to the local economy. Fascinating to visit.

Endless salt springs from the earth. We stopped by Salinas on the way through the Sacred Valley. Not far from Moray lies the ancient salt mines of the Inka, still used today and very much a part of the community of Maras.The residents are assigned salt ponds where the natural salt springs are diverted into the ponds, where the water evaporates leaving a very tasty salt used both for eating, cooking and healing...for people and the animals. The admission price of 7 Sole each goes back into the community and you can see the money at work in the nearby town of Maras.My excema on my hand has been bothering me for a few weeks and so I decided to dip my hand into the salt spring. Wow...it hurt for a bit...but within an hour my hand was already healing.You can even did your finder in nd have a taste...it's not like ocean salt water....this stuff actually tastes good...as does the dried corn the sell dipped in it.If you going to make the effort to see Moray, this stop is close and is another that is going to make the experience even better...not to mention the towering Andes in the background.It was snowing hard only a thousand meters up...quite the few.Lots of neat things to buy in Salinas as well, including sculptures made of salt, gem stones and mineral.Don't miss it, if you are touring through the Savred Valley!

Especially Salty. This is a really unusual place that is worth the visit. The "mine" starts as a tiny salty stream that is channeled into 3500 separate ponds. The drive in the area is also magnificent. Recommend getting a private driver especially if you have a small group.

Peruvian Pummakale. It's a bit like Pummakale in Turkey. Very unique place. It's definetely worth the visit. The view from above is amazing. Ask your driver to stop on top of the mountain when you are driving in so that you can take a few pictures.

Cool Sight. It's definitely worth a day trip from Cusco. Have not seen anything like that before in my life! The drive there is so scary, you're basically on the edge of a cliff before you get to the parking lot area. Worth it though!

Awesome place; never seen anything like it!. Maybe it's because I'm a hydrogeologist, but this site was one of my top favorites on our trip to Cusco and the Sacred Valley. Our local tour guide described how he and his grandfather had walked 6 hours to trade their Fava beans for salt, and how each salt flat belonged to certain families through generations. He showed us where the salty spring originated, and how the water is diverted through channels to different salt flats. Very very interesting place!

So Interesting!!. This was my second time to visit Maras and I was equally impressed as the first time. The area of salt flats is enormous and learning about the process to "make" the salt before it arrives at your table was fascinating. Would highly recommend!
