Great experience. Didn't know the Maras was such a huge place until I see it with my own eyes. The warm volcanic salt water running to different areas was amazing!!

Amazing!. Four times to the Sacred Valley and this was the first time to this place... really a must!
Very interesting place to visit not only to see but also to understand how this place is the main reason for many families that live from the salt.
Really worth seeing!

Quiet but spectacular. We got there by taxi on our way to other attractions - the taxi driver waited for us and we spend 30mins - 1hour there - unfortunately it was already closing time.There's a path leading you through salinas so once you arrive there it's really easy to wander around.I was positively surprised by this place - not that many people were there (it was 17.30 so it might have been the reason) what made the sightseeing quite peaceful.And the salinas were really something. You can watch the people at work - tending to the salt blocks and it makes you think how little you know about the power of nature and men.If you like to take photos it's a great place for that - both the salinas and the mountains around them are spectacular.

Great little day trip. I visited the salt terraces as part of a day tour from Cusco. It was great to see and Taste the salt and how it is made. The way there was rougher than I hoped for. But all worth it once you survived :) ahh and great fried banana snacks sold around the terraces!
Fascinating. This is a wonderful and really intersting place to visit.The salt pans are still used to this day by local families and this is really worth seeing.

Spectacular colours in a spectacular surrounding. The salinas are operating since Inca times. It is a bumpy track to get there, but well worth is. You should look down from a viewpoint on the access road - geometrical patterns in white/beige/pink within barren brown surroundings (during dry season). If possible, arrange for a walk down to the sacred valley, to be picked up by your transport there. This allows you to get away from the crowds and visit the lower parts of the salinas where less people go. The walk itself to the valley takes only 35 to 45 minutes downwards and brings you to interesting arid landscapes, to a hanging bridge over the Rio Urubamba and to a restaurant where your driver may be waiting in the parking lot.

Salty goodness. Super interesting but its kind of, you look at it once and youve seen it all - this place is definitely worth visiting but you dont need to allow much time for it, Such a unique sight. Also handy to combine with Moray ruin in one visit, could do it all easily in a day

Hundreds of salt pans. It is a bit difficult to get here unless you are on a tour. We hired a taxi in Cusco and went to a number of sacred valley sites in one day. It saved time, we were on our own schedule and since there were 4 of us it wasn't so expensive. Salt is harvested from these pre-Incan salt pans. The naturally occurring salty water is evaporated and then collected.
AMAZING INGINUITY. We were impressed by the history and resourcefulness of these ancient people! We bought some salt too.

Visually Impressive Salt Ponds. We really enjoyed our drive though the impressive Urubamba range of mountains and the high, snow-clad peaks as we drove to Moray, and then on to Salinas de Maras. You will find many wonderful photo opportunities even before you get to the visually stunning salt mines. Maras Salt Pools are an impressive complex of salt ponds, located in the area known Qoripujio. History goes that the locals were a angry at the Incas, so they invoked the Sun God and asked him to punish them. So,the Sun sent a rain of salt over that land so that it would become infertile and would not produce any food. He also made the water of its rivers salty so that the people could not quench their thirst. Perhaps the Gods thought ahead in the future because the curse became a blessing to the Inca Empire, and the current 380 families of Maras and Pichingoto as they are the only ones allowed to work these salt mines. It is a really enjoyable trip, you can get up close and personal walking along the salt ponds. Depending on the time of year, and the rain the pools will be either brown or white. There are stairs, and it can be difficult to navigate if you have a hard time walking. The salt pond themselves can be walked on freely, but they are slippery, so beware.

Interesting architecture by Incas. We did a whole day Sacred Valley trip with David Ramos (which by the way was so worth it). Our first stop was this location, and its a very interstingly built 3000 salt pools. There is a natural salt water spring coming from the mountain and has never stopped producing ever since the Incas first used it. There was a theory that the SV is once under sea water level. This is a nice and unique site to visit while in SV and make sure you ask your guide to stop before the bridge to take a snapshot of the SV with Urubamba river as a background. Also on your drive to the location, stop by and take pictures on the farm fields with the mountain ranges as background, very nice! Maras is not covered with the turistico boleto so plan ahead of buying the ticket (you can also pay it on the site). Take time to wander around and actually go close to the salt pans.

Did it as part of a mountain bike tour. Our mountain bike tour guides through Condor adventure guides decided this is where we would end our day. Very cool to see and very interesting to experience. I am not sure if i would have been interested to go and schlep out all the way from cusco just to see it, but well seeing if you are doing some sort of tour of the area. real hardcore mountain bike trails are all over the area and the views are amazing from the surrounding hills. best day in peru after machu picchu. also, we bought some salt and spice mix and used it when we got home for some delicious chicken.

Fascinating Inca Salt Pans. We went to Salinas de Maras on a one day Paso Horse trek, but it is possible to get there on a trip.It was fascinating to see, from the warm salty stream coming out of the mountain, to the 3000 salt pans that are still in use today. It was possible to walk in the area of some of the salt pans and see them close up. Well worth a trip if you like Inca history or just natural history.

Amazing!. Watching how salty water emanates from the mountain is an amazing experience! Try walking down to the Urubamba valley and have your driver pick you up there. Be there early if you do not want the sun to burn you!

Make sure you get a taxi and go there. Well worth the visit. wow. these are Inca salt pans with clever irrigation, all fed from a natural salt spring. Our taxi driver helped us walk along the pan walls and showed us how far into the salination process each little salt pan was.Nice shop where you can get Flor de Sal much cheaper than anywhere else.Great for kids. Not great if you are cautious or have poor mobility.Not ruined by touristsOff the beaten trackcloses at 4.30pmTaxi cost us s 140 from Urabamba and we went to the ancient propagation circles as wellAnother family paid only s90 but there driver did not act as a guide. I think s 110 is about right.
You have to walk over there. Thanks to our guide we try this small hiking by Salinas of maras, The photos you could shot be different and looks nice. The hiking very good.
Inca's salt. There is no doubt the Inca observed and learnt from nature. The Salinas de Maras are still producing salt as they did four centuries ago. Marvelous place!

Another unique sight and experience only Peru can offer!. Well worth a small detour. Known since ancient times for its pink, flavor enhancing salt, this natural source of salt has already been explored and highly valued by the Inkas. Maras salt is increasingly becoming known among culinary experts, however, its location has not been significantly explored by tourists until recently. Still, it lies off the trodden path, yet conveniently on the way from Cuzco to Machu Picchu. The views are unique and so is the nature and technique of this salt source, the like of which only exist in a handful of places around the earth.

Amazing views!. We went here as part of a mountain biking tour to Moray and Salt mines (I cant fathom a better way for active people to see the sites in this area). We were amazed with how large the place was and it was fun to walk along the salt pools and see people harvesting the salt. I recommend visiting even if its not on the tourist ticket the entrance is only 10 soles pp. I agree that the drive out was a little scary but we survived :) Tip: buy some roasted corn kernels and una Cusquena cerveza for an awesome afternoon snack as you browse the inevitable tourist trap shops.
Something different. The sight of "salinas" nested in a mountain is great. Although you have to go through a rough way the sight you get in the end is worth the dusty trip.
Absolutely amazing!. Never did I expect to find salt pans in the mountains! I learned so much about the harvesting of salt, and I was thrilled to be able to purchase some.

Scary drive but smazing salt mines!. The drive down into the salt mines is scary - dirt 1-lane roads + no guard rail + manual transmissions = scary drive down to the mines. Once there, the mines are impressive and lots of cool little vendors.
Amasing. Close to 500 years producing natural salt . Now this salt is being exported for its magnificent properties, at high prices. You can get it at location at very cheap costs.

salt production the hard way. this has to be like hell on earth, but in the sense of working here, not the experience. located in a deep valley you can watch small teams processing liquid brine from a natural spring which they divert into evaporating ponds, raking out the crystalline salt as the water disappears in the heat of the valley and the bagging it and taking on their backs in huge sacks with all the nimbleness of a mountain goat along narrow strips separating the ponds and up onto a main path towards sheds lower down the valley where the salt is graded and sorted before being taken by donkey down the valley to be sent to market. one can only admire these people working here. take clothes you can take off as it gets very hot and plenty of water to drink

Incredible!. My husband and I did a day of horseback riding in the Sacred Valley. We ended our ride at the Salinas de Maras. It was absolutely beautiful. If you are in the Sacred Valley, you should make time to visit the salt mines.
Amazing sight. Viewed from above the pattern of salt pans is just amazing. You can walk down and see the people working and taste the salty water.It looks sort of medieval! Don't miss it

Incredible experience. After going to Ollantaytambo we came to the salinas. It is an incredible view, since you are getting there you have to stop to take pictures because it is beautiful. When you get there you see the people extracting the salt from the water, and putting it into the bags. It is an impressive place, you can buy the salt that is extracted from there. While you walk through the Salinas you can taste the river and the water is hot (very weird because I went on winter) and it is very salty. I recommend to include it in a trip where you include Ollantaytambo, Maras and Moray.

unique experience. After a dirt road of about 45 minutes from Cuzco you are in a narrow valley (on the side of the sacred valley) and all the suddent this millenary Salinas appear in front of you. You can take a trail that within one hour walk takes you across the salinas and down to the river. It´s a shame if you don´t do it. It might be slippery wear good shoes

never saw such things. I had an idea that salt does not grow on supermarket shelves like pumpkins in your garden :) but haven't ever seen how it is actually extracted. and this particular site is just spectacular - set among mountains, shining on a sunny day.Beautiful! Striking!

VERY IMPRESSIVE. This is usually part of a day tour of the Sacred Valley from Cusco (round trip with other sites to visit). You could also make it part of a day tour from Cusco to Ollantay, then stay in Ollantay before visiting Machu Picchu. The site is off the beaten path down many small roads (some dirt, some paved). It is close toLooking down on the salt pans from high above on the canyon walls is impressive, but being right down standing on the sides of the salt pans and watching the locals tend their individual sites is more impressive. There must be literally thousands of salt pans here. All of the terraces have been engineered by hand into the side of the canyon over hundreds of years (as far back as pre Inca times). The salt here is not mined. A stream flowing through the mountain (which contains the salt deposits) is diverted into shallow terraced areas where it dries in the sun over a period of days, then is raked into piles, bagged and sold by individuals or families. There are many small vendors between the parking lot and the salt pans selling crafts, food (in small outdoor restaurants) and packages of salt they have collected from the pans. The walk from the parking lot to the salt pans is very steep - watch your step. This is a private site (not part of Peru tourisms tourist card), so there is a separate fee to pay at the toll booth on the road (a steeper fee than any of the Peru tourism official sites, but not that much - is it worth the fee - I think so, now that I've seen it).

Paradise for fotographers. Just come there and you will get an incredible impression. There is good quality unpaved road which leads into Salineras from Maras and from right turn from Urumbamba-Cusco road.

One of the best attractions. Incredible colors! Really different tourist attraction. Normally people miss this place, but it is really worthy. We've bought a lot of snacks made with the salt from the Salinas.
One of my favorites of the Sacred Valley. Really great place to explore and see something different. If you are afraid of heights this may not be for you.

Nice. I was in the way to Moray and we decided to go to Salinas de Maras and it was a very good experience; the day was cloud and even the opportunity was unique. I liked so much the tasting of the salt. We were during the rain seasons and even that we enjoy a lot. The dirt road was the part more difficult of the experience due to the rain in that day. But still well worth !

Salinas. A side trip on oir tour up to Machu Picchu, this turned out to be a real winner. Dramatic views of the salt ponds as you enter the valley far above on a switchbacked road. The history and explanation were provided by our tour guide (Apus Peru) and the best part was being able to see it close up and witness how it is worked.Stop at the little sales stand after you lave where you get your Boleto Touristico punched. Try the Canchitas, they're great. Also, you can purchase salt (plain and with common spices added) for about 1/5th the cost you'll pay back in Cusco.Enjoy!

Interesting!. We took a private taxi from Yucay in the Sacred Valley for 70 Sole (less than $30) and it included a stop here and several other places. We enjoyed seeing the active salt mines and the fact that we could actually buy salt for here - which we did!

Must see this strange site. Wow, I don't think there are any salt mines like this one. We took a horseback tour from Cusco For You up to the salt flats and was amazed by these thousands of salt ponds. It is remarkable how they harvested the salt that was more valuable than gold in ancient times. If you are in the Sacred Valley please squeeze this on your trip to Machu Picchu, you will not be disappointed.
Simple and nice. This is a very good trip near from Cusco. You can rent a taxi in your hotel and for S/.120 (less than US$50) you can have a private tour to Maras and Moroy. It takes 4 hours.

Amazing place!. We just returned from a 10-days Peru trip, including Lima, Cuzco, Sacred Valley, Lake Titicaca, organized by Gate1 Travel. It was really wonderful, everything was very well organized, all tours were very interesting! There was a bunch of optional tours too (including a tour to the Pre-Inca Salt Mines in Maras), we attended all of them, and were very happy we did! We especially enjoyed the visit to the salt ponds in Maras, where salt is obtained by evaporating salty water from a subterranean stream, in several hundred terraced ponds, owned by local families. The place really looks out of this world! And our tour guide Rogger Salas was very knowledgeable, with a good sense of humor. There is real magic in the Sacred Valley!This was our first trip with Gate 1, but certainly not the last.

Fascinating. As part of a taxi trip from the Sacred Valley to Cusco we stopped at the Salinas de Maras which we found very interesting. These terraced salt ponds are fed by a very small warm natural stream coming out of the mountainside. The stream runs via a series of open channels and diversions into the ponds where the water evaporates leaving the salt. Once this has dried in the sun it is collected and sold. We were able to wander around the ponds and encouraged to taste it - much saltier than the ocean!From there we travelled through spectacular mountainous countryside to Cusco.

Super interesting. The salt mines are very interesting. We did the mountain bike ride from the Moray terraces to Maras to see the salt mines. It was a fun active way to see it with Peru Path as your guide. These mines have been passed down generate to generation and was fascinating to see.

Very impressive from above. I am glad we took the time to see this. We stopped from the roadside to look down on it, and then wandered around inside to see it up close. I would have enjoyed it more if I wasn't having problems with what I thought was altitude, but it ended up being from the Coca Tea!

Pretty cool. We made a quick stop here and probably would have enjoyed it more if we had ventured further down/up into the fields. There were lots of tourists arriving on busses, and it got kind of annoying so we took some photos and left.

Super Interesting. We did the mountain bike trip from Maras to Moray and it was a 10.Fun to do with teenagers. Make sure you get a reputable company like Peru Path. We went with another company which was a mistake as all of our bike had broken gears and were missing climbing gears which is key on the hills and especially when you're not acclimated to the altitude.

A nice break from Inca Ruins. We went to this as part Sacred Valley developed by Cusco Tours By Edwin (tours by locals). It was most interesting. Fortunately, our tour didn't try to do the whole Scared Valley in one day but picked out a few interesting places and spent more time at each. I highly recommend Edwin for this.

A magic site. In the earth of the Andes, in a deep valley, an exceptional view ! Hundreds of pools where ground brine is dryed thanks to the sun. Al these pools are reconstructed each year after the winter rainfalls. This looks like a family activity, where grand-parents and family are concentrating and collecting salt in bags of 50 kg ! To be transported uphill to the storage house ! Exceptional !

Must see!. This was a favorite stop during our Sacred Valley tour. Very unique and scenic. Our private driver dropped us off at the front gates and had us walk across the entire length of the Salineras and down the hill on the other side, where he picked us up by the bridge. It was downhill the entire way, not very steep, and took a little over an hour. We got a gorgeous view of the valley and river on the other side and got to walk through a local street where we saw horses, donkeys, corn drying in a front yard, a local cemetery, and 3 puppies. it was just us and another adventurous couple behind us the entire way. Would certainly choose the same route again. I think most tourists just wander into the site and hike back up to the main gates.

Very interesting. This is a very interesting place to visit. A salt water stream flows out of the mountain and is channelled down the mountain into little pools. Salt is left behind as the water evaporates. We were there as the pools were being cleaned after the winter which added to the interest.Make sure you take a view from across the valley on the way down before you reach the Salinas.

Good place to stop when you get tired of Inca ruins. Probably should rate a little higher on the tourist scale than it does. After seeing a whole bunch of Inca ruins, it was fun to see somewhere different. And I don't think I've seen a view anywhere quite like from the top of Salinas looking out over the pools of salt. Definitely worth a stop.

A facinating place. A visit to this salt 'mining' site is like a trip back in time. You look down a hundreds of little lagoons where salt water is slowly dried to harvest the salt - looks like a moonscape. The people from Maras who work here have been harvesting salt for hundreds of years.
Amazing. Well-worth a visit to the pre-inca salt mines. The site is beautiful and the work to harvest the salt is amazing.

Really neat - get some habas saladas. This salt mine is huge and really neat to see. Entry fee is low. I recommend buying some "habas saladas" (salted beans) from one of the many handicraft vendors. We were reluctant to try the samples at first, but now we are hooked.

Salinas de Maras....very intriguing!. We had hired a driver for the day and he took us the back way from Ollantaytambo to Moray and then on to Salinas. It was a beautiful drive!Salinas is definitely worth checking out! It is very interesting and beautiful. We had binoculars and were able to watch various families working their area from construction and digging of a new site to tending to the various stages of the salt collection. It was part of the Boleta de Cusco (ticket that covers various sites in and around Cusco)

Was Fascinating............ I am so glad that we did this site. Was so interesting to learn the history behind the pre incas and the Maras salt flats. Reminded me so much of Pammukale in Turkey. Would definitely advise you to see this place if you had the extra day in Cusco. Amazing to learn how the different families cultivate their salt fields.
Nice but fast. Not so close to Cusco, you have first to go by car (or bus) on various trails before to arrive. Then an interesting visit in a short time, I would expect a bit more.
Fascinating. Different and really cool, worth the trip and close to Moray which I'd say is even better. Nothing about it to dislike.
Easy horseback ride. 45 minutes up the hill. Easy even for inexperienced riders. Very interesting. Our guide and horsewoman (I'm sorry, I've forgotten her name) was professional and well informed.
Nice side trip. Very interesting salt mines, can walk from one end to the other. We had our taxi drop us off on one end and pick us up on the other.
Nice stop on a tour of the Sacred Valley. Interesting to see how they harvest salt from the mineral springs and some cool photos. Does not take long, but worth a stop.

This was a great day trip!. Had read about the salt pans but once there I was awe struck. I am so happy I made this trip as when you come around the mountain, it gives a spectacular view. They still harvest the salt from these pans and I found the whole experience interesting and definitely worthwhile. Fantastic!
Very beautiful area. We did a mountain biking tour and this was our last stop. It's a very beautiful area and worth a stop to see.

can be skipped, but worth a look if you are passing by. This site is somewhat close to Moray, so if you go to one, you will be recommended to go to the other. It is actually interesting to see the patchwork-looking salt pans of different shades. And salt has been produced in the same manner here for a long time (centuries, I believe I heard). If you are short on time, go to Moray and skip this.

Far more interesting and impressive than expected--great visit. My husband and I were unsure about this visit, but we absolutely loved the Maras salt mines. Very cool, very unexpected, and very unlike anything we'd seen before. Walking through it and seeing the beautiful salt formations was intriguing and worth the time. We spent more than an hour exploring. Don't miss it if you have the time! The only thing more interesting in the Sacred Valley region was Ollantaytambo for us. We far preferred this to Moray, and Chinchero, and we despised the market in Pisac (cheap goods unless you're a touristy shopper looking for that!).

Nice views. It was interesting to see the salt mines and fascinating considering the construction of the diverted spring water. It's too bad they don't make that much money anymore from these mines. Let's hope the tourism it attracts will keep it up and running.

A small added attraction is an interesting region.. These extensive terraced salt pans fed by a saline spring go back for many generations. The dramatic entry road adds to the appeal. The story of their joint ownership and operation is an interesting side line. Sadly, they now make little money and may soon fall into disrepair so see them while you can.
salt mines. it was an impressive first view we had of the salt mines and seeing it closer and seeing the way the water was diverted and redirected was interesting. very nice scenery there.

Gorgeous and amazing. Good food too at the restaurant at the entrance. Definitely worth the extra trip to get here. The salineras are beautiful and the natural phenomenon necessary to create them is really amazing. Try to find a tour guide if possible to explain whats going on...although I'm not sure there are many at the entrance. Had lunch at the restaurant at the entrance (the one on the left) and the fries were amazing. Highly recommended

Salt mines leave you breathless. It was interesting to see how they produce salt from water that doesn't come out of the sea. To visit the site, you must be prepared to walk a bit and do a lot of steps, so better be in shape.

Definitely unique. This site is a refreshing change from the ruins and markets we spent much of our Sacred Valley time visiting. They are fine, but this was a welcome chance to experience something new.The salt mines have been operational for hundreds of years, and it was interesting to speculate how many more the underground store of salt will last. The view from above (there's a pullout to stop at) is impressive, but walking along between the various pools of salt and seeing them up close is pretty amazing.We spent just under an hour here. There are some shops on the way in which sell not only the fairly standard souvenirs but also bags of salt, corn treats, and small salt statues.

One of our favorite Incan sites!. These are totally different then all the other Incan sites. The salt water comes out if the mountain and distributed among hundreds of pools. Once a pool is full, the owner of that pool blocks the flow of salt water and allows the water to evaporate. What's left is delicious salt! Really interesting. Great place to mountain bike to.

Wish my photos did it justice!. It was so nice to see something like this working and producing, our salt grinder is full of Peruvian Salt, when you come over the mountain and get your first glimpse at the high Viewpoint the colours are amazing, then to taste the salt water from the spring and see how they oproduce the salt was so interesting, its a good walk down to the pans themselves from the car park so be prepared to get out of puff on the way up :o) Hey, if you have climbed over dozens of Inca Ruins....this is nothing :o) Highly recommended

Add this Non-Ruin Site to Your Itinerary. We saw a lot of ruins, so I definitely wanted to add in Las Salinas to our tour itinerary. We visited the site with our private guide, Chino, who explained the history of the site and how the salt pans are used today. There are no informational signs at the site, so either have a thorough guide book or tour guide to truly enjoy the site. I wish I bought more salt while I was there! There are plenty of vendors at the site entrance to buy salt and other gifts.
Gorgeous. 10 times better than its photos... it's amazing in person, stop by and hopefully take some better photos than in the ads, which don't compare...

Maras is very cool. It was the end of the wet season when we visited so the salt pans were mostly brown rather than the white you see in summer. But the place is very cool with thousands of the salt pans all fed by one warm, salty spring. And has been for hundreds of years. Some pretty touristy shops there - but the dried broad beans were sensational! We did a day tour organised with Llama Path to Moray and the salt mines at Maras. They also stopped a traditional textile place in Chinchero which was amazing.

Stunning!. Our guide suggested that we close our eyes as our car turned the final corner before the venue came into view - we rewarded with one of those 'wow' moments in life.I doubt whether any picture could do this place real justice, so do not miss it if you have the chance to see it for yourself.

Interesting if you have not been to a salt mine before. We did a day tour of Moray and Maras. We thought it was well worth it. THe salt mine was interesting and something you probably would not see in many places. If you have limited time, you could give it a miss.The inca angricultarual experiment is interesting and pretty. Once again if you have the time it is worth it. If not focus on Pisac rather.
Beautiful. Loved this part of our specially made Sacred Valley tour. I think people that don't come here are really missing something very important!

Very Photogenic & Interesting. About 1.5 hours drive from Cusco this is a very interresting excursion usually paired with the nearby ampitheater shaped Incan gardening experiments. Lods of tiny plots of salt and ladies in traditional dress working them.

Salt sensation. Really enjoyed a change of scene after seeing so many Inca ruins! I liked how you could wander over all the salt pools and found it interesting to hear other tales of inca life apart from just agricultural tales! The drive to the site was also fully of really impressive scenery! Great to break up grassy ruins!
Interesting. It was impressive. We bought some salt samples while there. It was more scenic from above than being down on top of the fields.

Very different to the other Inca sites. The salt mine was one of my favourite sites to visit because it is so different to all the other Inca sites. It is a working site and the tour is very low key - you could just wonder around - but it is very cheap to visit (but not included in the Cusco Tourist Ticket like most of the sites). We went as part of a taxi tour of the Sacred Valley but you could do it as a coach trip along with the Moray Ruins which are very close.We brought some of the pink salt home with us.

Awesome construction. This site is so immense, it is difficult to totally comprehend the difficulty in "harvesting the salt". Unbelievable beauty as the pans cling hillside, like a patchwork quilt, in a small valley. Try and walk down as far as permitted for wonderful pictures.

Nice. I really enjoyed this place, nice weather, and great view of the Andes.Water looks so pure and it tasted salty :)I recommend the half day tour of Moray and Salinas as these two locations are not included in the one-day tour of the Sacred Valley.

Worth at least a visit. This place is another that doesn't photograph well. The magnitude of the place does not come through on photos. The depth doesn't come through either. On the drive down, there is a look out stop towards the top that you should have your driver stop at and let you out for the view. But commit the view to memory because the photos you take at this look out will not do it justice.Once at the salt pans, one could take as little as 5 minutes looking around or a couple hours walking around. As is our fashion, we aren't happy unless we try to see every last thing so we ventured from the start all the way to the end and back. It took about an hour. Some of us made the trek by wandering the small pathways through the salt pans, some of which took us pretty deep into the site. We kept in mind that these belong to individuals and were very careful not to disturb anything or cause any damage.The kids especially liked this site.

Nothing fancy. OK, so this is literally a salt-mine area with construction debris and stuff. Basically there is a salt water source that flows (like a brook) and they made terraces for the water to be channeled on to so that the water can evaporate, leaving behind the salt which then can be gathered. Since at ay given time some or most of the salt will have been gathered already, it would be hard to see the terraces filled with white salt, which is what would give the place a visual appeal. Instead, the terraces are mostly earth-colored patches of dirt. The drive there is out of the way and there is a separate entrance fee (separate from the Tourist Ticket), so I would say go if you are in the vicinity and you have time, otherwise you didn't miss much.

Amazing pattern of salt terraces. I did pick up a few packets of salt from here and it's great. We enjoyed the experience of walking around and seeing the patterns formed from all the individual salt flats. A worthy tourist spot.

White as snow. This is the first time I have been there and I simply loved it. I learned many things about the process of working with the salt found there but what I highly recommend is the kind attention of Mrs Sonia. She invited generously 'cancha' , you will find there what is it : ) with salt mixed with spices and I fell in love with it. If you go there asked for her you will not regret it.

Interesting, but not worth going out your way for. I had been hoping to buy some of the famous pink salt when I came here, but the shop didn't sell it. It is interesting to see the salt wells and walk around, but apart from that it's not worth going out your way for.
Incredible!. This place is huge and very interesting! We went there with a local guide and he told us so many interesting facts about this place and how the salt is made!

Interesting and unique. As we learnt there is only another similar location out there - impressive to imagine that the planes are fed by one stream but nobody figured out yet the final source of the salt stream. Would be interesting to know if the seam might dry out one day or how limited the salt reserves are?We hiked down to Urubamba raver, a rocky and times steep path but very glad we did it - passing many locals living in their basic homes along the river.

Incredible views. I went during the rainy season so the salt mine was muddy but that certainly didn't distract from the views. Our tour guide did a wonderful job explaining the process used by the local peoples to gather the salt. The hike through the mine was great. A must do

salinas de maras. What an exciting view of the of the Cathedral looking salt mines, I think the salt crystals form mini-cathedral structures, before salt is harvested to be processed and sold.The subterraneanstream is of course salty. The salt terraces are beautiful and glistenning with the silvery crystallized salt!

Very Interesting Site just outside of Cusco. As if the altitude isn't high enough at Cusco, the site o Sacsayhuman is about a thousand feet higher ! It is a very interesting site with enormous stones fashioned and put together in the Incan style. I really enjoyed it and learned a lot about Incan monumental architecture.

Interesting walk in the mountain. It takes about 45 minutes to walk to the salinas. Before entering the path, in the middle of nowhere, a woman is selling you a ticket for 7 sols, but it is worth it. Just pray that the path doesn't become a torrent because quick floods happen all the time in the region. When you get there you see the remains of the salt mines and it is beautiful, deserted, you are surrounded by the nature and it is overwhelming.I would recommend to do the hike.
Salt flats. We had a really good time here. Took some great photos. We didnt buy any salt but heard this is a great place to buy the "pink salt"
Salt. You can appreciate old mines that continue to exploit comes naturally. International Chefs buy its salt for gourmet cousine.

A Community Industry. Many pools containing salt water at different stages of evaporation. The color varies according to the weather when the pools were filled. The community still maintains the industry. Salt is available for sale in different colors and consistency. There is a path to walk along the side of the pools as well as see the water path from the salt water spring that feeds the pools.

salt as far as you can see. This was neat to see, and neat to see how because this land was under water so many years ago they can now mine salt. Seeing the many pools was pretty but also a great for learning how they do it and have for years. A salt stream from the mountain feeds this area and they mine it. Ladies in dresses are out working the mines was neat to seem amazing that they dress up for this kind of labor. It's in the middle of the mountains, we did a hike down to "town" where our bus picked us up, easy hike except it was a narrow pathway at times (and not sure I'd want to hike up, that would be strenuous). Also near the bottom of the pools is the shed where they take the harvested salt to, those bags are big and heavy. Biggest complaint I had was that the gift shops where they sold the salt were at the top so I would have to buy before I saw it, although if you didn't hike down I guess not a problem. The bus ride in was a bit white knuckled, if you don't like steep cliffs sit inside and don't look out. Bathrooms were not so special; bring your own TP and handwipes (as many tourist palces in Peru).

Salt mines. Was captivating seeing a running salt mine, and seeing the multiple pools of salt. The mines are surrounded by a high mountain region, and the view looking down into the mines is brilliant. The sun was shining brightly and the whole place turned shining white, making the mines look even more incredible.

2,000 Pools of Salt. This place is amazing. 2,000 pools are etched into the side of a mountain, all of them fed by one small, extremely salty stream. The Incas recognized that many of their people suffered from a salt deficiency so they began developing these pools, where salt is harvested between May and October. Today the pools are owned by families who live in the nearby town of Maras; each family owns 2-3 pools and is responsible for harvesting. You can walk down into the salt ponds and see up close how they are fed by the one small creek that flows out of the mountain.

Fascinating and spectacular. Incan salt mine,3000 salt pools are still in use.Stunning color palette from white to brown. Salt mines, Salinas de Maras consists about 3000 small pools (or pans) with an average size of 54 square feet. Each pool yield about 150 kilos of salt per month. It is interesting to see how the salt is being harvested. Each pan is filled with water and water is trapped in the pans and evaporates, leaving behind salt crystals that can be extracted. Solid saat is beaten and granulated and packed in plastic sacks for sale. The Salinas de Maras peached on a brown hillside and blaze bright white under the sun. The most conveniet way to get there is by taking a bus from Cusco to the village of Maras. From Maras you can walk or take a taxi.We walked throgh mountain path (dirt road) and scenery was so beautiful and magnificient. Luckly we met local people who gave us direction and short cut to Salinas. It you walk from Maras, there are two road; paved and unpaved dirt road. Paved road takes twice more time to get Salinas. It takes about 40-50 minutes on walking through unpaved dirt road. The scenery all the way from Maras to Salinas is amazingly beautiful and impressive. The Moray is not too far from Salinas (7 miles). It would be better to visist both sites in one day. Most of pools of Salinas are owned by people of village of Maras.
So cool. The salt mines were so cool, like nothing I had ever seen before. Would definitely recommend visiting them along with the Moray terraces.
totally worth a visit. I think pre inca just have a quick taste of the water coming out of the mountain! great to visit. I liked how water flow was organised and directed.

Salt in the Hills. I had previously seen a video of the salt mines and it was great to actually see them in operation and appreciate the difficulties under which the locals operate. This is an interesting place as it is no where near the sea, the salt comes from the runoff of the mountains.Access to the salt pans is via a private road with a fee applied by the owner of the property and also another fee to actually enter the site and view the operations. However these are not expensive.The trip in and out calls for concentration by the driver/tour operator as the roads are dirt, windy, narrow and very steep. You can see the works in operation and how the salt is collected and carried(50kg) on the backs of bare footed salt workers. If you wish there are plenty of shops selling all types of salts(including pink salt), foods, drinks and the usual tourist nick nacks. Well worth the visit.
Visually Stunning. It is really a unique place. the importance of this place for the Inca immense. It is a must for visitors on their way to Machu Pichu
Wow! Salt pans!. pretty cool place to take a little walk. Prices were good on salt! Nice views and very different from the rest of Peru!
Interesting Visit. It was very interesting to see the salt flats and experience this industry, but I objected to the gauntlet of tourist trinket vendors on the way in.

Very interesting site in the Sacred Valley. We visited this site as part of a tour starting from Ollantaytambo back to Cusco. We hired a private driver/guide and felt the expense was worth it given how spread out the sites are and how much great info there is. The salt mine is something you probably have never seen before. There are literally thousands of tiny pools that they use to trap water and harvest salt in a natural, ingenious fashion. It supports many of the local families. You can to literally walk along the edge of the salt pools - it is a nice departure from the ruins and landscape you generally see in the Sacred Valley. They have some nice souvenirs to get (salt, assorted corn, textiles) for simple gifts to friends/family.

Unique and beautiful landscape. We went in January, so low season, and apparently in the busier months you can actually watch people mining the salt. However, for most of the time we were the only ones there which was very atmospheric and the salinas were really breathtaking - and a change from the rest of the Sacred Valley's stone ruins.

Combine with a visit to Moray, interesting ancient salt mine. The roads are windy and narrow but when you come round a corner and see the salt mine terraces covering much of the opposite side of the valley it is worth it. You pay a few soles entry fee and have the obligatory opportunity to buy hats and jumpers as well as salt.Do walk down and through the terraces. Our kids even clambered between them but luckily didn't fall in.

a reasonably short hike to this amazing place. To get to these salt pans, located up in the hills above Urubamba, you can (a) walk up from the river, (a really steep climb!) or (b) hire a car to take you to the car park at the entrance or (c) get the bus up from Urubamba from the bus station heading towards Chinchero and get off at the Maras junction, then in a colectivo (waiting at the junction for bus passengers) to the path to the Salineras (just short of the village of Maras). Then a superb and stunning walk down to the Salineras along a clear path (about 3 miles), and continue walking back down to the river (another mile or two). Cross the bridge and get a combi back to Urubamba or wherever. Take water with you. There is a cafe and toilet at the Salineras. Entrance fee is s/.7.The Salineras are quite unique, and the walk in the hills is a great way to spend a few hours enjoying the Andean scenery. Transport is easy, cheap and frequent.

Interesting ancient salt mines. These salt mines have been in the same family for hundreds of years and produce salt for eating and export, and bath salts as well. Scary, narrow road entering, but an interesting site to see when you are vising other parts of the Sacred Valley.
An experience. We stopped by the salt mines on our horseback ride to Moray. This was a neat place to see, the people were friendly and the fried bananas/chips were great!

Amazing Place to Visit. Maybe the most beautiful natural place to visit in Cusco after Machu Picchu,Now on january is rain a litle in Cusco but this is not an impediment to visit Maras Mora and Salt of mine

So cool. This was a great site to see that we originally didnt think we would include in our plan. We ended up going there with the idea in mind that it would just be OK but we loved it so much we bought salt to take back home!

To tie in with my Moray comment.....FANTASTIC!. I combined Moray with Salinas de Maras. As I inadvertently talked about salinas de maras for moray, I will talk about moray now. This was an amazing site with so much history. It was amazing to witness early time science of how plants cope at different temperatures. It is really cool! However, make sure you are in decent shape as the altitude sickness really affected me on this portion of the trip.
Worth a visit. Incan Salt mines. This place is huge and worth a visit.It seems like this is an option on most tours organised from Cuzco. It's an interesting place but its usually a rushed stop.

Another amazing example of Inca engineering. First, we got here as part of a bike tour that also took us to Moray. I would HIGHLY recommend finding a biking tour if you are in ok shape and a fan of biking. Even though my wife and I hadn't ridden a bike in 10 years, it all came back to us and we had an absolute blast! The bike tour ended here. It is at the end of a long and dusty narrow gravel road (which was terrifying on bike with tour buses blasting past). At first, high up on the hill, you can't even tell what it is. But as you get closer you see that all of the white is salt. This is an ancient salt mine! There is a small trickleof water that becomes a small, salty stream. The Inca built the baths to capture the water and let the sun evaporate the water and leave behind the salt. It is very cool to see. You can walk among the salt baths (not in of course!) and the locals still mine it. You will probably see them down there scraping salt. I don't think I would pick this as a destination alone but it is great as part of a tour. Seriously, I recommend biking there. It was just a bit chilly (spring) and just a gorgeous ride through small villages and ending at this impressive salt mine.
very neat. it was very different than most places i´ve seen. it´s not overly touristy, which was nice. Worth a visit if you have time.

enjoyed the scenery. The salt pools are set in a lovely mountain setting. The drive to the salt pools is very beautiful. Get a good driver with good brakes on the car because it is steep driving in. Very interesting to see if you have never seen anything like it. I enjoyed it much. Very worth while experience.

A Marvel. A small stream of warm water emerges from the mountain and its salt-laden water is diverted to feed hundreds of small salt pools as it makes its way down the valley. This is yet again another amazing example of Inca ingenuity that is not to be missed. Still used today, it is a source of income during the dry season for many people living in the town of Maras. We were so glad we took the tour!

A must-see in the sacred valley. Don't let tour companies talk you out of this. It costs them 7 soles to bring you here (entrance ticket) and many often skip it in favor of more spots on the Boleto Turistico. The salt terraces are beautiful in every season and they are the real deal - still mined by the local villagers using traditional methods!
Really stunning view of the flats. We paid 25 soles for this and moray and had a very good day. The tour did feel a little bit rushed but apart from that it was great day

Best to walk. This is a unique tourist attraction - it's a bit pricey to get to, and entrance is S7 by taxi (the only way if you don't walk), but if you're fairly fit, you can get a moto taxi for around S1.5 to the bridge about 10 minutes from Urubamba town, and walk about 40 minutes up to the salt flats, without having to pay entrance fees. Salineras is not included in the tourist ticket that you may get from Cusco - so by car you would have to pay separately. If you just want to see Salineras, and are not bothered/don't want to pay for Moray (which is normally toured simultaneously), I would recommend this route to save money. To get to Moray, you can walk another 1.5-2 hours uphill to Maras and get a return taxi for around S25...but there's not a lot to see in Maras town, so it might be better to try and get a taxi from Salineras itself...some taxi drivers are rather misleading, saying that there aren't any taxis to Moray from Salineras, but that is definitely not the case. Although, if you're planning to see Moray and Salineras, it may be better to get a bus from Urubamba to Maras, and then get a return taxi to Moray before walking from Moras to Salineras downhill instead of up.

AMAZING. You are not waiting to see this after being driving in a land road. The walk from the salt mines to the Valley and crossing the river is a great moment. Suggest you to do this and to have your lunch in the valley.

Scenic and Attractive Geometric Pattern From Afar. I saw the geometric patterns form the road and did nto associate them with salt beds untilw e got closer to it. The walk towards them saw steep and if it rained, it would have been slippery. On the way down there, we passed by numerous little souvenir shops that had colorful woven things as well as bags of grain salt, roasted corn ,dried banana chips. and other snacks. Some were generous with samples.When salt was a precious commodity, the residents of this area had enjoyed a higher standard of living as they made lots of money selling salt to different regions.

extraterrestrial place. what we did to get here was to take a taxi from Urubamba to Moray, Salinas and then to Cuzco for 90 soles. the views are amazing from the road leading to the Salinas. when you get to the place it is even more unearthly. worth visiting for something different in the Sacred Valley.
Not to be missed. We hiked the trail from Urubamba to the Salinas. Spectacular! Easy walk with one 10 minute climb. The views are mind boggling.

Beautiful at sunset. Quite a sight to see a functioning salt pans that been around for centuries. A little our of the way but works well if your combine with it a visit to Moray. IF you've had your fill of massive Incan citadels, this is something different. We got there with a car and driver that we hired for the day to drive us around the Valley.

Very interesting. We did a tour of Moray and Salinas de Maras, we enjoyed both as they are totally different. The colors of the salt were picturesque. We stopped in the town at the bottom of the hill and enjoyed some Chicha at one of the homes. We were very grateful that a family let all of us in their house, they were very welcoming.

Salty but sweet!. I visited the salt pans today, I've never seen anything like it. A man made wonder moulded into the landscape that creates this almost alienesque environment. On a blue sky day, it's like looking at thousands of panes of silver as the salty water shimmers and glistens against the light. Have a taste of the salt too! Will definitely get your lips smacking.The landscape that the Salt Pans is set in is equally stunning, with sweeping patchwork plains and colossal snow capped peaks domineering the land.If your in Cusco you can get here extremely easily. On street 'Au Grau' there is a bus station where you will see busses with Urubamba on. Jump on one of these for 4 soles and ask to get off at Maras. The locals were really helpful and considerate in helping me, so you should have no problem getting there. The Journey takes about an hour as the bus intertwines the stunning landscape.When you get to Maras you should see a number of taxis waiting here. I negotiated a round trip to Maras town, Moray and Salinas salt pans for 60 soles. I had thought about walking it, the landscape isn't challenging but the total distance including all sites here would be around 35km.When you are done visiting the sites, go back to the turn off for Maras and flag down a bus that is going the opposite direction back to Cusco again 4 soles.So in total I did this for 68 soles, don't let the public transport put you off because its cheap and fun and extremely easy to do.

A Nice change of pace. A visit to the Salt Mines is a nice change of pace from visiting all the ruins. There is a salt water stream that comes out of the mountainside and locals still use it to “harvest” salt. You should hire a guide for a few soles to get the most information about the site. There is also a cute little store.

Interesting and beautiful. What a great stop! We spent about a week in the Sacred Valley, Cuzco, Machu Picchu area. This was a very cool stop - a change of pace from all of the awesome Incan ruins. The salt pans are strangely beautiful and the views are fantastic.

DO IT BY BIKE. This was a day of adventure, and after being impress by Moray, we continue in our bikes to Maras and such a spectacle. I recommend a full day for this and if you can sleep at the Sacred Valley even better.
Cool ancient salt mines. This is a really cool site. Pre-Incan salt mines that are still in use today. You can walk past them and see how they've mined salt for centuries. Fascinating.

Very cool!. Booked a last minute trip through a local agency in Cusco, and saw Moray, Maras and Chinchero. It's a bit of a drive, and you can walk around for some great photo opps once you finally arrive. Cheap, and well worth it!! They have a market that sells salt from the local mines, as well as other souvenirs.

Valley of Salt. A verry interesting location that shouldn't be missed if you are planning to visit Moray anyway. You get a beautifull view of the whole valley on the drive down, once there the view across the salt pits is spectacular. While there you can purchase a variety of salts that were farmed right there.

Cool, but let's not go overboard. I combined a trip to Moray with a trip to Maras. By private cab from Cusco, the whole thing will run you about $60. 90 minutes to Maras, then another 30 minutes to Moray. I'm not sure what to say about this place. Visually, it's a unique experience. It's kind of crazy just to see over 1500 little ponds filled with salt water that will eventually be "harvested" by a local family in charge of the place. But really, there's nothing to do here other than snap a few pics and walk down the steps to get a closer look. So let's not go overboard with the 5 star reviews.If you have an extra day to blow while in Cusco, then I would recommend doing a Chinchero/Maras/Moray combo trip (which would take you about 6 hours or so, all in), just so that you can say you did it and so that you have some neat pics. But I wouldn't sacrifice a day to do this trip. There are alot of other things you could see and do in or around Cusco that I would say were cooler. Heck, I probably had more fun hanging out on the 2nd floor balcony of the Starbuck's that overlooks the Plaza de Armas and people-watching. :)ps remember that like most places here, they charge 1 sole to use the restroom!

Interesting and worth seeing. This is an interesting site historically and aesthetically. It is not as amazing as the LP guide would have you believe but, combined with a trip to nearby Moray Ruins (a MUST see) it is well worth the trip.
Incredible!. We took a taxi to look at the salt pits and then walked back to our hotel. We loved getting into the countryside and seeing the less tourist trodden route

So special. Something very special you can't see in other places -
thousands of terrases to produce salt since Inka's time.
Extraordinary. We walked up from Rio Sagrande. An amazing sight at the top of the valley, and well worth the climb.
Loved the 4,000 salt mines. If you would like to see something unique, consider visiting the salt mines of Maras. The drive is beautiful, the mines mind boggling, the salt tasty!

Worth the ride. Definitely interesting to see.
Would have been good to get a guide to help with some of the interpretation but a fun and worthwhile visit for sure.
Don't miss this. A great example of a sustainable project that started way back in the time of the Incas. The views from the top are stunning and beautiful. A truey unique experience.

Culturally very interesting Incan time until today. This salt extraction site is still being used by the local people of Maras. Using basically the same techniques as the Incan people did for years, you can see the process of manual salt extraction done in a lovely valley setting. It can be combined with other sites to make a full day tour.
Wow!!!. Pretty amazing to see all these salt mines. The water comes from a salt spring and they feed it into places to dry and harvest. In the middle of no where but worth it.

Don't pass it by just because it isn't a top of the list site. This is a great site and shouldn't be missed if you have the time to see it. I have never seen anything like it (like many things in the Sacred Valley!). I can't do the description justice so read about it before you visit. It might sound boring but it really is worth the visit. The road that winds down to the salt mines is a nail biter so just concentrate on looking at the salt pools.

Something quite different to do in the Sacred Valley. There are shops at the beginning with some tasty treats, but we did not see anyone offering to be guides, so not sure we got out of this experience all that we could have. I had done some advance research, which was helpful. It is not easy walking in the salt mines, so if you have small children or poor balance, I'm not sure how far in I would venture. I had read varying accounts of how to get to this place; in the end, the driver took us right to the entrance and you don't have to walk far at all; I had thought we might have to walk up to an hour (which would not have been worth it). We went in the morning, it was certainly interesting to see, but had elsewhere read to go in the afternoon for fabulous colors. This place is "off the beaten track", driving on dirt roads to get there. It was interesting to walk into the site and see the different stages of work going on, and by the far side looking back, it looked like an iced bundt cake!We hired a taxi for the day and had him drive us around the Sacred Valley; as the buses all follow the same schedule, this meant we were able to go to sites when the buses weren't there. It was awesome to be able to do this (we had many sites practically to ourselves), we spent as much or as little time as we wanted at each place, and had no "forced" shopping experiences that others told us about. Highly recommend this approach (it cost more than bus tickets, but I'm sure we saved money in the markets!!!). The taxi was also able to drop us off at one end of a site and pick us up at another spot, so we didn't have to backtrack.

Ancient Technology at Work Today. The ancient Incan salt pools carved into a hillside are actively in use today and create an eerie, exquisite geographical sculpture worthy of a visit to this remote site. Walk down the path from the parking lot, down down through a series of souveneir sellers and explore the pools. Best to hire a guide up top for a few soles to learn the history and process of 'harvesting' the salt - quite fascinating. We enjoyed purchasing several grades of salt in various size packaging from the little shops as we hiked back up the path from the pools. Don't forget your camera!!

Got salt? Yes it does!. This is just the most fun place to drive up to and peek over the side hill down to the ponds. Great pictures! But then drive on in and walk around. No guides and no rules, you can explore the entire area. The water running into the ponds from the hillside is intensely salty and the sources for the mineral. Workers were out in the pond area following the process of collecting this precious Peruvian salt. Apparently anyone willing to follow the rules and can identify an open pond can work it. There are multiple shops selling all forms of the salt and other typical crafts. My thought was to buy the packaged salt that has not set in the sun and caused condensation on the package. The salt is heavy, make sure you have the weight allowance in your baggage for the trip home.

Something completely different. These salt pools are so intruiging. Wander (carefully) along the edges of these incredible pools, formed by the local community from the hot salt water spring that comes out of the hillside. The pools are staggered down a fairly steep hill, and are all owned by individual families who used to be able to make a living out of gathering the salt. The site does still sell salt but is not a viable operation, except for the money the tourists bring. It is not overcrowded so a pleasureable sight to visit.
very nice day trip. we took a day trip to Salinas the maras an Morray from Cusco. it was breathtaking to see all the salt pools from above...very reccommended

Photographers heaven. Took a taxi, with Moray and Chincheros this was a super day out. An extraordinary site, like nothing else on earth. We didn't walk around because it was raining, but really it's the overall impression that is so weird.
Fantastic-Not to be missed. An amazing site. Glad we added an extra day to our trip to see this and Moray. Unbelievable to think the salt mines have been worked for 800 years.

Awesome!. Overwhelming, watching locals carry 100lb bags on their backs. Watched locals harvesting salt, tasted the stream. Know how privileged we are to hire our own private taxi and guide - would not have wanted to miss this. Awesome.

Salt pans. Doesn't take long to see this, but the harrowing little road winding down the canyon kind of adds to the adventure. Looking at the salt pans from up above is just something you don't see every day.

Amazing. This is a unique place to visit and I think it is not an overstatement to describe it as one of the wonders of the world. Personally I don't understand why anyone would rank it less than 4 out of 5 and to me it is a definite 5 out of 5 must see, alongside Machu Picchu.

Interesting site - worth a stop. I saw this on the back end of a trip to Moray (contact KB Tours about a mountain bike ride starting at Moray, then riding all downhill to Salinas) and liked it.On the surface it's pretty straightforward: highly salinated water comes from the spring, sits in pools where the water evaporates, the salt is harvested.The scale is that I found visually striking: it's a small canyon valley that really is filled with these pools. I'm not great photographer but the contrast between the brown dirt and the white of the salt pools is really stunning.Plus, I scored points on the home front by buying my girlfriend bath salts.

Great place off the beaten track. We visited the salt mines as part of a day tour to Moray with Condor travel. I looked at photos before our trip, but they just don't do it justice. This place is amazing! It looks like a patchwork quilt of little salt ponds, in various colours from white to chocolate.
Well worth visiting.

An amazing sight. It reminded me of pictures of Cappadoccia in Turkey, literally hundreds of individually owned salt pans stretching down the hillside like a patchwork, also an opportunity to buy salt and herbs that you won't get elsewhere
Salt Mines. Still in use today for country wide use. These salt mines are above ground and tended as they were hundreds of years ago. A modern day version of terraced mining.

Salt terraces in Sacred Valley Peru.. Amazing that these terraces are still utilized as source of salt.Built on the steep slopes of the mountains overlooking Sacred Valley on the route to the stae start of the Inca Trail. Peru is fascinating.
Pre-Inca wonder. These salt mines pre-date the Inca culture, and are being mined by the same families that worked them 800 years ago. I don't think you'll see anything like it anywhere else.
Fantastic. Wow, what a view the salt mines are, really fascinating. Definitely worth a vist. We came here as a joint trip to Moray as well

A remarkable place to visit. It is amazing how the nature works to give as essential nutrients to live: water, and Maras is not the exception to this. Salty water has been provided by the mountain thousands and thousands years ago. I was deeply fascinated with Maras and its system work to get salt.

nice landscapes. a lot of walking up and down hill, only do if you have extra time, could have done without it. The best part is the view you get from the road while getting there, very green , hilly and beautiful

Interesting. We didn't spend a lot of time at Salinas (about 30 minutes - it probably took longer to get there from the turn off to Maras than we spent at the mines), but it was amazing to see the network of salt pools and the trickles of water that were flowing down the valley. Interesting place and great photos! They also sell various products at the gift shop (but also on a national level) that use salt that was harvested in Maras.

Fascinating. After going to the salt plains in Argentina and Bolivia I nearly didn't go here as I thought it would be similar. It is totally different, shwing salt at different stages of prduction and with different colours. A wonderful place to take photos.
Stunning view of thousands of salt mines. The view is breathtaking. The colorful salt mines shimmering in the sun.A trail takes you around them. These are still used to mine salt.

Venture back in time. This hike was nothing less than amazing. My wife and I stayed in Urubamba and walked to Salineras. It was very hot (we went in September) and just about when we were going to turn back, we saw it. We were both blown away and spent quite a bit of time walking around. We are not the tour type and saw buses up on the hillside and thought they must have been missing out as they were so far away. As we were walking thru, a guy came up to us and said we needed a pass - we had not heard about this, but paid a minimal amount to get the pass - looked pretty official. Perhaps we were taken advantage of but who cares was very worth it. My wife remarked that as we walked along, it looked like icing on the cake. We watched people work raking the salt, and others walking their donkeys along the road. Probably like they have for many, many generations. If you want to go back in time and see simple, do not miss this. Not to be missed is the hike up alongside a small cemetary.

Don't miss this. I could not believe that such a place existed. I could have spent a week there doing photography of women in traditional garb working the salt works and men carrying 50 kilo bags of salt for which they get about 9 to 15 dollars. It is literally otherworldly to see and the hike out was really good and enjoyable.

Amazing!. We stopped by Salinas on our way to Ollantaytambo and were so impressed by the sight! Like nothing we've seen before. They allow you to walk around as much as you'd like and taste the salt from the pans. Didn't cost much - I think only 7 soles. Worth it!

Must see! Nice break from ruins. Tips for things to do while you are there.. The Maras salt ponds were not even on my sightseeing wish list before the trip, but they certainly ended up being one of the highlights.When I was planning the trip, I tried to include as many archeological sites (a.k.a. ruins) as practical in the limited time we had. However, the reality is that after Machu Picchu, all the other ruins are quite unremarkable, and frankly I started to find them boring. Fortunately, we had a wonderful private guide who adapted our activities on-the-fly to include attractions that were more interesting. The guide suggested the Maras salt ponds, and I am so glad she did! The salt ponds were very unique and interesting, and they really added some variety to our sightseeing. (The guide was from Peru For Less, and we were very pleased with their services throughout our trip!)Anyway, the salt ponds are quite a ways off the main road between Urubamba and Cusco. I’m not sure how you would get there if you weren’t with a guide. The ponds are tucked away in a steep little valley. Hundreds of years ago, people discovered a natural salty spring, and the started building small evaporation ponds to harvest the salt. Over the years, more and more little ponds were added. The spring still flows today, and now there are thousands of little evaporation ponds all over the hillside.It’s really a very spectacular place!Some people seemed to just view the ponds from an observation area near the gift shop. However, in order to really experience and appreciate the ponds, you need to walk down to where the ponds are. There is a pretty easy level path that goes along the top row of ponds. You can walk quite a ways out onto the hillside on this path, and see the ponds up close.There didn’t seem to be anyone out there who was really paying attention to how far about amongst the ponds we walked. If you have plenty of time, you could probably walk all the way down towards the far end of the sea of ponds, but I don’t know for sure. Maybe someone would eventually stop you, but it would be fun to see how far you could go. That’s what I would have done if we had more time.Obviously, you want to be very careful of the ponds and the maze of tiny canals that feed them. This is a working salt farm, so it’s important to not interfere with the operation. But from what I observed, they didn’t seem to have any problem with us walking around the ponds respectfully and carefully.One thing you definitely want to do is to stick your finger in the water from the spring and taste it. You’ll be surprised as how salty it is!Don’t forget to go through the gift shop on your way out, and support the local economy. The items they sell are very cheap for us, but even our smallest purchases mean a lot to the locals. I always try to buy a little item of some sort everywhere I go.Anyway, I strongly recommend that you don’t miss this place. Make it a sightseeing priority, and have fun!

Salty waters. It's amazing to see and try such salty waters in the middle of the Andes, it makes you realize how fast this land formation must have been made and how all was once part of the sea. It is beautiful, and wonderful to see how a community has also managed to organize themselves with their precious salt.

White and photogenic. Looked like nothing else we saw in the Sacred Valley. Easily combinable on a trip with Moray. Great photographs. Able to walk, with care, all over, and great shots down to the Sacred Valley further in.

Interesting but not a must-see. The drive to the salt pans was a hair-raising experience for us. The road is very rough and narrow and we had to stop in a number of places and back up so cars going the other direction could pass. At one point, our van was hit by a guy on a motorcycle who took a turn too wide. Fortunately he was okay. After the drive, the salt pans were a bit anticlimatic. They were interesting, but I am not sure they were worth the time getting there, particularly if you are on a tight schedule.
Also a must visit when in the SV. As said for Moray, this place is part of the tour and included oin your tourist ticket. This place has been producing salt for the past 600 years.
Salt mines. Amazing place to visit - breath taking views. Couldn't believe that this place is harvested by private families??

Interesting Attraction!. In my opinion, this place was worth a visit. The methods of harvesting salt by hand were interesting to watch and the number of salt pools is so vast that it's mind boggling. Even more amazing is the strength of the workers there who carry 100lb bags of salt uphill like it's nothing.

Interesting sight, worth a visit. I enjoyed the salinaras. Thought it was interesting to see and walk around and also liked learning about all the different products that can be made from the salt that is obtained. Worth a visit.
Off the beaten path. Well worth the visit, especially if you pair it with a trip to Moray/Maras site. These salt terraces are unique and the people are so very friendly.

Amazing! One of my favorite sites in the Sacred Valley. Don't miss this one. Unlike anything I have seen anywhere else in the world. Great peek into how Andean families work and make a living, and a thrilling walk too.

From the ancient Incas to us. Salt with a Denomination of Origin. Loved the fact that you can walk through the salt mines and see the different levels. Breathtaking experience. Bought some natural Fleur de Sel and flavored salt.

Wow - what a site!. Our family of four visited the Salt pans in Peru and it was an amazing site! It was really fun to learn all about the site and the process of mining salt in the area. Be advised though that it's a tricky hike requiring walking on ledges about 12-18 inches wide. Also it's a long trek to get through the whole site.
Loved this salty gem!. time to get there was in fact worth it; it is very interesting and self-guiding to see how salt is mined by local families.

I never saw a salt mine before so it was really interesting to learn how getting how it works. We bought some salt fou. Hated the road to the mines. When you pass another vehicle , you hold your breath. Looking down over the edge of the road was a little scary.

Strange but emotion to match.. This location is incredible but the road to get this location is very very dangerous without any protection on the very thin road. You can see a large ravin several hundred meter very close to the wheel of the coach;

Over 5000 salt ponds, wow!!. I never seen so many salt ponds in one place or salt that comes from the mountain. I am only acquainted with salt that comes from the sea being that I live in Hawaii. Salinas de Maras has over 5000 salt ponds, definitely a sight to see. Great to visit along with Moray while you are staying in Urubamba, Cuzco and Ollantaytambo.
Nice. This salinas are really different from the other i've met, in Bolivia and Argentina. Beware of the paths, they are not suitable for any kind of person.

Neat to See from Above. The view above the salt mines are neat. There is a store and shop you can go down to see. We skipped that as we found it a little boring. But it is an important industry as it employs many of the townspeople. Check it out if you are really interested in salt.

What a sight!. As you turn into this valley of the Salinas de Maras we were amazed that for hundreds of years people have been getting salt from a mountain spring! And the village is still working so hard to get the salt every year! It's fascinating. Please be careful and don't step into their salt pools!

Spectacular sodium chloride.... Located just a few minutes from the Moray Crop circles, Salinas de Maras are a group of still-functional salt pans still used for extraction in modern times. Admission is separate from the other sites in the Valley and paid at the gate directly to the company that manages the site. The descent is a bit intimidating and thrilling at the same time; maybe three feet separate your car from the cliff on the way down. There is a visitor’s center at the bottom that you pass through on your way to the mines proper. Most tours will start by the hot spring at the top of the pools (that “feeds” the operation) and then continue down into the dozens of miniature lakes (“salt pans”) that spread down to the valley floor. There is quite a bit of autonomy allowed with your route here; our guide brought us well into the field of pans before ascending to the top. It’s a bit of a balancing act between the pools although not slippery and we didn’t come close to losing our footing. There were still workers visible on a Sunday with the harvest which was interesting to watch. After about an hour of slithering around between the ponds we returned to the main entry, bought the requisite souvenirs, and were on our way.This was similar to the Moray circles in the sense of being more of a visual journey than a thorough learning experience but was valuable none-the-less. I would imagine a professional photographer would be overwhelmed with all of the opportunities. The shops had a different variety of items including (surprise surprise) salt for cooking and various decorative figures made from the mineral as well. Firmly (but not absolutely) recommended for a visit if you’re in the area.

Kinda boring. The drive out there is great as you wind around dirt roads in the mountains but the actual mine is boring. There are plenty of way more interesting sights and hikes to occupy your time. I just don't get why everyone is so excited about this place.
1000 years. the fact that these salt mines have been in operation for over 1000 years is amazing!! very interesting tour, worth a visit!!!

Salt Mines. When you travel through the sacred valley, this can be a stop for you. You will have to pay about 7 soles because it's not on your tourist ticket. They are impressive salt mines, but we didn't feel the need to walk through them. We got some cool photos, but we didn't spend a lot of time there. It is a working salt mine.

Simply Beautiful. Thankfully, we were able to add this spot at the last minute to our tour of the Sacred Valley of the Incas with the Moray ruins after I happened to read about it on a Peru forum - I'm so glad I went! It is a truly a gorgeous sight, so definitely check it out if you have the chance. I was told it gets brown and muddy during their summer, so it's best to visit the salt mines during their winter months of June-August when the mines remain white.

Interesting little stop. This site is neat to see, but is just essentially a salt collecting area from a natural spring. If you are in the area visiting Moray, for example go and see it, but I would not consider maklng a special trip to see it. It is a hairy ride the last mile or so,and you have to wander through a number of "gift shops" to get to it, but it is still an interesting thing to see.

very interesting!. We took a tour to visit this place and the Moray ruins. It was very interesting to walk around the salt mines. You can buy salt from the mines. We wished our tour allowed more time at this site.

Interesting. I'm not sure I'd go out of my way to visit the Salinas de Maras on their own, but I highly recommend it if you're traveling around the Sacred Valley and also going to see the terraces at Moray. The salinas is an interesting oddity, the the drive out there (and on to Moray) is far more fascinating as you'll see the heart of rural farm life in this part of Peru. We spend about 20 minutes at the salinas.
worth a visit. combined with Moray great day trip. Stunning place to see. Amazing views. Great picture oportunity. Fascinating...
