Worth the visit. This was such an interesting stop on our visit around Ollantaytambo and Moray. Enjoyed walking along the salt mines and observing the process. Didn't anticipate all the shops and souvenir vendors but enjoyed the variety of salted "corn nuts" we found there.
Working salt mines. Very worthwhile excursion to see the astonishing way the salt is procured from the underground streams. The area is a real spectacle and a photographers paradise

Fantastic place. The salt mines are not really mines like you would imagine. They are terraces pools on a hillside. You can hike down and actually walk amoung them. Well worth the vsit and great photo ops.

Worth seeing this site.. It's an interesting drive from Cusco, and it's a very unique site. You have to pay 7 soles per person when you get to the little dirt road to drive into the site. You can hike down into the salt flats to explore. Mostly it's just interesting visually if you like to take photos.

A trip Highlight. A break from ruins, Salinas de Maras is in an incredible spot between mountains. The road is a bit hairy-steep switchbacks with no guard rails, dirt and rutted in places, but when you get there its all worth it.The salt terraces are beautiful and you can walk out a ways. You can Buy salt from a couple vendors. Be sure and take a picture that captures the unique setting of the terraces within the context of the mountains its tucked into.

Very educational. If you dislike heights (like some of us), try to distract yourself during the drive. The road descends very low (and the way back up is "interesting") Once there, take advantage of the mini-tours, the restaurant (excellent capuccino) and the gift shops (great pink salt!) Wonderful adventure!

Another surprise. I have often gone up the river opposite of Salinas and wondered what there was in the "salt Mines". It is an impressive sight and I just wonder what it would have been like to see 1000 years ago. Plan to see Moray too if you visit here.

Salineras Salt Ponds. The Salineras salt ponds were a great sight and adventure. There are hundreds of ponds built into this one part of a small gorge that are fed by salt laden hot spring water and then allowed to dry out. The locals have been collecting salt from these ponds for hundreds of years. It is easy to get a taxi from Cusco or Urumbamba to do a combined trip to Salineras, Moray and Chinchera. If you start about 11 AM or noon and do Chinchera and Moray first, that will put you at Salineras in the mid to late afternoon when the sunlight on the salt ponds is great.
Otherworldly. This was quite a sight to see. After Machu Picchu, it was our favorite place in the Sacred Valley, although the switchback mountain road was a little unnerving!

Not worth a special trip, but okay as an add-on. We combined this with Moray, which most people probably do. It's worth about 10-20 minutes and is interesting, but not worth a special trip. You can walk all around the salt pits though, which I was kind of surprised about.

Another wonderful site in the Sacred Valley. It takes an expert driver to manoeuvre the track that leads downhill to Moray and the salt mines here. We stop half-way, almost at the edge, to get a panoramic view of the salt pans across. They're carved downwards in layers, in thousands of blocks, narrow channels supplying them with the highly saline water needed to form the crystals. To get a closer look we stop at the mines. A small trail leads to them, the salty water coming from a spring inside the mountains.We are told that the mines are a co-operative farming system, perhaps even pre-dating the Incas, where anyone could own a pond, but had to operate it within strict guidelines.The pans range from being brown, ochre, white, depending on how much water or salt each one contains.They look beautiful in the evening light.

Interesting salt pans. By the time we got here we had already hiked 2 other ruins so were feeling a bit tired. None the less it is an interesting system that individual families own their own salt pan & maintain it. Bought some salt to bring home.

Nature's Science Lab. Take an extra hour on your way out of the Sacred Valley to see this. My family and I added the salt mines to our itinerary at the last minute on our way back to Cusco. We were so happy that we did it and found it to be one of our favorite sites in Peru. The open air mine consists of a few thousand pools of salt (in various stages of harvesting) that are fed by a single, naturally salinated spring. It was fascinating to see how the water is diverted to feed each of the pools.

Just Fabulous. Travelled here and to Moray. Hired a taxi for half a day. Ask taxi driver to stop for an 'aerial view' of the place before winding road downhill - spectacular!!! Take time here as you can walkabout the place. Awesome sight! Watch people 'harvest' the salt and repair the terraces.

Cubist style salty shapes. Unusual place to visit - makes nice photos. They are working mines that apparently require a lot of co-operation to maintain. They sell a good selection of things at the small group of shops there. Some nice salt mixes for cooking and delicious dried corn snacks.

See these shimmering salt pools as you drive down the mountainside.. This salt mine has been used since the Inca times. They are breathtaking to get to, and amazing to see all the shiny pools where salt is being mined. If you just listen, you'll hear the ring of tools as people go down to harvest salt. So glad we got to catch a peek and the countryside just added to the drama.
Salt mines. Never seen a salt mine. The views from the high road that winds down to the mines are spectacular. Amazing that some of the workers there are in their 100's.
Must go See. Holy Moley! Harvesting salt is certainly something to see. Do not miss this if you go to the sacred valley
Beautiful. What a magnificent place! A must to visit in Sacred Valley
Amazing place. Beautiful views of an amazing location , which was unexpected for us

Weird salt pools on mountainside. I wouldn;'t have chosen this place to visit but our guide was correct. Spectacular location in pink-stone mountains. Salt water spring feeds these pools,dug in ancient times and still used today to harvest salt. From above it looked like a cubist painting. Also saw a shepardess walking along with her goats and texting on her cell phone!

An amazing place.. This place was a wonderful surprise.
It is truly breathtaking to see.
My children were fascinated and I took some amazing pictures.
A must see in the sacred valley

You have to see this place !. A salt mine built by the Incas and still used today. A massive complex of pools used to harvest salt from a spring. The design is awesome as well as the surrounding area. You can even buy little packages of the salt...great place.

Great photography. These salt "flats" are on a hillside and such an interesting place to visit! Be sure to get a photo from the pull out on the road down to the area. Once there, you can walk among the many natural pans of water which will produce the salt which is harvested by several families that have worked the area for years.

Beautiful Colors. Going to see salt pans may sound like a snore, but we found them fascinating. Also beautiful, as the different stages of evaporation created patchwork pattern in shades of white and tan in the midst of the mountains. Great photo ops.

Worth the Trip. The Sallnas de Maras are way off the beat path for most tourists but well worth the trip if you have the time. The Sallnas salt pools are quite a view to behold, as you drive down the mountainside on a dirt road. The salt pools are cut into the mountainside and scatter the near desert view with patches of brown, burgundy, and stark white. Plan to walk a little down from your car to get a closer look. Sit and watch the workers for a bit, as they carry salt from the dried pools up the mountainside. It is quite a tranquil site with a great view of snow top mountains off in the distance. Also, since this is well off the beaten path for most tourists, the site is generally not crowded.

Never did salt look so amazing!. This was incredible. Families own plots and manage the collection of salt from these salt mines. From a distance, they look like a very large honey comb but up close you can see that they are more like salt gardens tended by families. I found it quite interesting and we were able to watch people raking the salt up and carrying it in loads from their individual salt pan area. There are 5,000 salt pans..each a rectangular depression of 10 ft across and 1 ft deep. A natural spring delivers warm salty water to the pans...very unusual and interesting to see.
A very special place. It was beautiful. You'd better have a guide or do some homework before getting there to have a rough idea for what the place is and where the salt water comes from.

Amazing ancient practices still used!. I knew nothing about salt mines before and was amazed. We went with a tourguide while mountain biking and he was able explain a lot to us. This salt mine belongs to familes who are descendents from the Inkas, so cool! They let us try a little of their salt and we decided to even buy our own bag =) Still using it! Would definitely recommend checking this place out, very interesting!

a must-see!. I passed this up on my first trip to Peru, back in 2006. At that time I didn't think it sounded interesting, just some salt flats...Well, on my recent trip, I made sure to take the time to visit and it was one of the highlights of the two weeks spent in Peru. Simply amazing! This place along with Moray will blow your mind. Imagine seeing something you can't begin to understand; a way of life you couldn't fathom. The local people have been doing their salt harvesting for centuries.Go and check it out for yourself. You won't be disappointed!
interesting. imagine that pre incas civilization used it; incas, used it and now we use it! Very interesting

Salt pans. 258 local families own the salt pans that are fed by a small volcaninc spring and they co-operatively harvest the salt as the water evaporates. The poorer salt is sold for animal feed, cleaner salt is sold for cooking and flavouring. The site is built into the hill side and is a wonderful feat of engineering. If you go make sure you get a fully guided trip so you can be told the history, the technical parts and the culture behind this amazing site. It was a trip that was worth it.
Extraordinary. Huge salt pans in the mountains. A bit off the beaten track, but definitely a highlight of my trip to Peru.

very interesting, off the beaten path. We included this site along with Maray on a private tour. It is a nice drive through the countryside to the salt mines. They are still working them the same way as they did 1000 years ago.
WOW. It was incredible to see and the history of the place was extremely interesting. This was one of our favorite stops.
Salt ponds in the mountains. Hard to believe that salt is produced here. Stick your hand in the water, lick your fingers, and taste the salt.

Change of scenery. Looking back on my travel, the salt mines were a unique place to visit because they were a change in pace from the many ruin sites located in Peru. It was very interesting to learn about the salt and the scenery is quite impressive.

An addition to the history of Salt. The history of salt is pretty interesting. It used to be worth its weight in gold. It was cool to see this operation that has been going on since pre-Incan times. We hiked around the site and brought some home. I recommend a guide and pairing this with Moray (I reviewed that site also, unfortunately, I mispelled Moras as Morass in that review)
A must stop in the Valley. An impressive view to see thousands of salt pans in the mountain side. You will get an impression of size when you find workers in the salt pans.

Amazing visual impact. These salt flats are much more compelling than they might sound. Highly recommended stop. It would be great to do the bike ride to get there too (we saw several people doing this).
A long walk.. We walked from Urumbamba side across the bridge for 1.5 hours to vist the salt mines then return downhill.

Visiting Peru. I took this tour with Moray too.
Maras is salt natural place where originals work there.
The project of salinas is very itneresting for naturals of there and the view is really exiting.
There are a small place to take diferents tipes of salt as to cook or to relax.

Outdoor experience. I liked this excursion, Maras is one of the best excursions we did, for sure Feb is not the best period because in dry season you will enjoy better the landscapes, try to do this with a bike!!

Nothing else like it anywhere. My husband liked this even better than Machu Picchu! It's a huge series of terraced shallow pools that the community uses to harvest salt. It's in a dramatic, beautiful mountain location, and the pools turn different colors from different perspectives--white, cream, reddish, even green. They're divided by little stone walls you can walk on. Has to be seen to be believed.

unique sight of salt terraces. Entrance fee of 5 soles brought us to this terraces of salt. We got to walk on the terraces to view the other side of the mountain and etch our names in the ground of salt. Interesting place to visit if you have free time. Cost us 80soles cab ride from Urubamba to visit this and Moray.There are souvenir and salt shops here and 1 eatery.

Fantastic Experience!. Now I know why pink Peruvian salt could come in pink or brown. Every traveler to Peru must visit this site. Also, souvenir shops in Maras offer much better prices. And if food in Cusco tastes salty, one has to remember that Maras is just about an hour drive.

We had this all to ourselves!. We took a taxi from Urubamba for our visit - after several miles of dirt road travel (after leaving the main road), through beautiful high open vistas, with mountains all around - we pull up on the crest of the hill and see THOUSANDS of salt pans. Like nothing I have ever seen! It was such a contrast to all the Inca ruins we had visited. The ride there was a treat in and of itself - breathtaking. It was quite hot, so we eventually had to leave - it would be interesting to visit during the time of year they actually collect the salt. We did read of a trail that can be followed from outside Urubamba to walk there - I think that would be quite nice, actually - and also read of one that runs from Moray to Salinas (which is the direction one would want to go - downhill!). If I had an entire day to dedicate to this, that's what I would want to do - and just soak in the amazing peace and views. But absent that, a taxi is the way to go - no crowded tour bus necessary!!

Horseback is the best way to visit Salinas de Maras!. We wanted to see as many sites of the Sacred Valley that we could drag the kids too. Horseback riding to Salinas de Maras was a great different option for our family with two teenagers. The trail is a bit steep with a narrow path, therefore I would recommend that you are comfortable with horses and not afraid of heights. Just need to trust the horse, as they do it everyday. The salt terraces are beautiful and our guide was very informative and kept the interest of both kids. We chose Cuscoforyou, it is rather pricey for the outing, but the horses were healthy and the guides were very professional.

Loved the salt mines. We took a horseback ride to the Salt Mines, which was absolutely lovely. The area is gorgeous, and unlike anything I've ever seen before. We took full advantage of the little gift shops near the site, and I bought some yummy Peruvian pink salt to bring home as a souvenir.
Would recommend to anyone exploring the Sacred Valley.
Salt pans are interesting. Worth a stop if you are in the area. Dunno if Id go to far out of my way for this.

Interesting site with god local vendors (stuff not elsewhere.) Definitely worth it c/ w Moras. Little market boasts a high end collection of quality Peruvian goods at a reasonable price (by tourist standards) .... very interesting inland salt site... considering salt was an inland luxury in many places (in South Africa in the last century for e.g., in some places a person's status was literally measured by their salt...a salt tureen was sterling silver and the richest people had tureen's the size of a table.) One could wax Biblical... but definitely a lovely day trip from Cusco when combined with the amazing and perplexing Moray mystery site.

Surprising importance of Salt!. On the page, Salt MInes don't sound that interesting but this site proved me wrong. The history around the need for salt and how the locals harvested the salt during the dry season was very cool. Glad we went!
You'll never see anything like this!. Though a little off the beaten path, don't let that deter you because the spectacular view is well-worth the visit!
Amazing salt mines from Inca's time.. Spectacular setting, and beautifully done. You can buy little Incan salt bags to take home for cooking or as souvenirs. It's worth to visit it
Very interesting. Salt pits that make salt for ages from a very salty stream in the mountains. A must for the curious and kids who want to understand how stuff works.

Awesome Day Trip. Our groups do this on motorcycles if at all possible. The scenery on the way to the salt mines is simply breathtaking. This is a great destination/turn around point in conjunction with some other points of interest along the way in and around Chinchero. The road going down in to the Salt mines is freaky in a big bus, but car, van or motorcycle it is simply spellbinding. Once you are down as far as you can drive, you are free to walk down in to the sediment pools, taste the salt water and chip away at the salt crust. I love this place because it is not regulated so much that it is sterile to visitors like Yellow Stone Park, where you can't step off the pavement. This is a working salt collection area but you are free to walk around and check things out as you wish.It is about 90 minutes out of Cusco but there is a ton to see along the way. Do it in conjunction with some other site seeing or on our way back from Machu Picchu, Maras or the Sacred Valley. This is part of a great tour day. Don't miss it.

Another interesting Inca site. This was used by the Inca's to collect salt from the river that flowed through the Maras valley.The salt pools line the banks of the valley as the water is diverted into the pools.Looks good from a distance as well so be sure to stop on the road in.

Really cool.. This was on our list of desirable places to see. After taking the usual picture from up on the road/ridge, be sure to walk the little trail amongst th pools. Don't drink the water though (I saw some people doing that to test salinity...)
well worth a trip out of Cusco. Ancient salt pans on a hillside, a visual spectacle, still worked today. Few tatty gift shops.
A must see. Cannot believe that these mines were used since the Inca times. Beautiful geography

Beautiful site, worth a visit. This was the second time I visited this site. The first time was about eight years ago and I remembered how much I enjoyed it the first time.
Beautiful and tranquil, we visited late afternoon and there was hardly anyone there. Well worth a visit.

great colours. wonderful drive over the hills to get there, and just amazing to see. the water is so salty if you dip your fingers in they get salt crystals on them. the pools are beautiful to look at. go late afternoon to see the colours on the pools changing.

Very unique. We've caught a glimpse of the Salinas from the highway in the valley but still couldn't quite envision what the site would be like. And once we got there it proved to be one of the most unique places we've ever seen. Salt has been harvested here for hundreds of years and still is in the same manner. You can often see people working in the terraces, especially during the dry season.Of course there are also some small shops at the entrance that want to sell you souvenirs. We did buy some roasted and salted beans and corn and found them absolutely delicious!

Great site. Salt flats in the middle of nowhere or that's what it seemed like, especially since we were miles from the sea. It is relatively less known than other places, so there were very few people around, which made it even more enjoyable.
Great for photographers. Visually stunning, Salinas de Maras is worth it if you're a photographer. Try hiring a private cab and going in the early morning or late afternoon to avoid the crowds.
Salt Mines. These salt mines are a very interesting attraction. You will see the ancient way of harvesting salt
High Sodium views!. The trip into/out of the salt mines was quite a drive. The restaurant was very good. The views were lovely, even on a rainy day.
Salt mines used till the day of today. These salt mines were first excavated in the Inca times and are still used till today. Amazing site with great views.

The Maras Salt Terraces Are Off The Beaten Tourist Path. My wife and I came to Cusco with three goals. The Maras Salt Terraces were one of our three goals. It was as incredible as we expected. We met a woman there that controls 6 of the pans, and she scratches out a living for her and her family by harvesting and selling salt. We helped by purchasing several kilos of gourmet salt from her. Then it was an adventure to pack the salt back to our restaurant in Iquitos.Everyone wants to go to Macchu Picchu and the Sacred Valley, but I recommend putting Maras on your list.

Very beautiful. Sick of Inca sites ? Come here instead. It's very beautiful, also don't miss Moray nearby (no need for a tourist ticket in Moray, you can just pay 10pesos on the door), made for a great day out, but not an unmissable site if you're short for time.

3000 years of salt pans. The salt pans of maras are mysterious and beautiful... coming from a salty hot spring deep in the valley, where the same families have been harvesting mineral salt for 3000 years.
Worth the detour. To see people making a living by extracting this resource using terraced salt pans on the sides of a mountain. Dramatic location.

Never seen anything like it. The path from the parking lot down to the start of the mines was not well marked and I felt like I was wondering through someone's back yard, but once we arrived at the mines, we were taken aback. Yet another amazing use of the land and it's resources by the Incas. We really enjoyed exploring the mines as part of our afternoon in Maras & Salinas.

Simply Awesome!. I don't know why I liked this place so much. You can see the salty cascading patchwork from the top of the mountain but when you drive the scary road down, it is worth the hike down to the pools. We caught some women harvesting salt. This was a combo tour with Maras town and Moray and worth the visit.

Interesting side trip. To see salt collection still being workes as it was in Inca times and walk through the terraced fields of salt in different stages of maturation gives a broader view of Andean life.
Fascinating. A fascinating terraced salt "mine" where rice paddy-like pools of salt water are evaporated off leaving salt. The road in could be featured on IRT deadliest roads.

Not much time needed. This was part of our tour to view the salt pools. It did not take long at all and was well worth to see. It is nestle in the mountain and we actually saw a worker carrying these very heavy bags hiking up!

Well worth a detour. You can see the salt pools on the road from urrubamba, I am told that the locals walk up the hill to the salt pools but we went by minibus and it must have taken at least 40 minutes to climb up the mountain and across to the Salinas. I can't remember the entrance fee but it was something like 5 or 10 soles. The salt water comes out of the rock and feeds many pools which are owned by every family in Maras who maintain their pools and sell the salt as a cooperative.You balance along the edge of the pools as you walk around. There is an official shop selling the salt and salt products and look out for the warm, salted, roasted corn in the kiosks you walk through to get to the pools.Worth a detour or a hike!

Maras-Moray and Chincheros. Good experience but we would have liked to spend more time in Moray or Chincheros which were fantastic. These three locations are in the same tour and Maras was the lowest point of it.

Surprise in the mountains. Salinas was a pleasant surprise in the middle of nowhere. The salt mines looked like a patchwork rug in shades of beige/taupe/white, depending on how dry the salt was. The water running through was very salty and we watched one old lady worker as she stood in a wet 'square' of salt and shifted the salt about, bringing it to the surface to dry. Was unusual, but we were glad we saw it.

A beautiful taxi ride away and really worth seeing. You can get a cab out to Salinas and do a trip to some other sites at the same time as theres a few things that way. Go to the local tourist official centres, they're really helpful. Salinas is via a really lovely trip through great countryside and some really gorgeous mountain views.Salinas itself is quite something. The views are incredible and you can see people working on the salt pans. Its a really interesting place.

Hiking to Maras With Awesome Views. We hiked from Kuychi Rumi through the villages. The people along the view were polite and friendly. Cross the bridge and then follow the road to the mountain. It was a great, easy hike that gave us much more of the nature and culture of Peru. On the way back, as you cross th ebridge, there is a little restaurant/hotel-El Puente, and we ate there watching the birds on the river. Great place!!!!

Simply outstanding. Never seen something similar. The best choice around Cuzco apart from inka archeological sites. Easy to reach with local tour operators or with taxis, the entrance fee is ridiculous (3 euros) and there is the chance of buying aromatic sault for cooking. Also possible to visit the site with mountain bikes together with the moray terraces.

Thousends of salt ponds. We got to this place as our trips near Cusco. There is any salt spring on top of mountain and from there run small creek with salt water ti any plateau where it feed about 3000 ponds ,belonging to local community people .Ponds filled and after about one months after water was evaporated people collect salt .There is small shop with souvenirs like salt crystals ,and figures made from salt.

DO NOT MISS THEM. We were very close to miss the Salinas, despite our pre-trip research. Luckily, our local driver, Hugo ([--] if you care) remind it us. It's a gorgeous trip in its own to the Salinas, and then you'vegot the Salinas themselves! We had a blast there, nearly feeling we were walking within some sort of objet d'art! Hundreds of small pools desalinating water at different paces create a gorgeous vista. All that happens amid huge mountains under clean air and light!Enjoy! PS: I only rated Salinas de Maras with 4 stars because I wanted to leave the extra star for Machu Picchu:)

Worth seeing. We did a loop of Ollantaytambo, Moray and Maras. The salt ponds cascade down the side of a canyon while the warm to hot water source flows out the side of the mountain. We were told by our guide that it's safe to dip a finger in and taste - very salty. Another incredible setting in a valley full of man-made as well as natural beauty.

Very impressive!. Visited Salinas de Maras, with my wife and kids, on our way to Moray, just taking a short detour from the main road.Amid a beautiful landscape these salt mines appear, and the scale of the works and the ingenuity of the Incas, and the people that still work them today is quite amazing.You pay a very cheap entrance fee (U$3 per adult), but it's really worth it and you will be rewarded by a one of a kind attraction, full of history and ancient tradition.

Delighted we visited Salinas.. I had only expected to visit Moray on our day trek, and when I heard there were salt mines nearby I was not too bothered about seeing them. Fortunately the group I was with wanted to see the salt mines. The salt mines were spectacular and are one of the highlights of my trip to Cusco. Walking between the "salt pools" was fun because it felt like it should be slippery (Looked like I was walking on an ice path) One tip we got was to continue down through the salt mines and across the river to the main road to flag down the buses passing on the main road.

Great find, off the beaten path!. My girlfriend and I went here and absolutely loved it! It's somewhat esoteric -- seeing how salt was mined during Inca rule -- but the scene is absolutely spectacular and it's amazing to see them still in use today. It is like no other tourist attraction you will ever visit.Don't pay attention to the books that suggest taking combis or collectivos to get here. You'll want a taxi, at the very least from Urubamba but probably from Cusco. We hired a taxi from Cusco to take us to Pisac and Maras (waiting an hour at each), then drop us at Ollataytambo, for just S/.140 (for a total of 5 hours of services). You can likely get a taxi directly to Maras for S/.50 from Cusco, but you'll have trouble getting back out. There are some taxis that await people at Maras, but I would prefer not to rely on them alone.Anyway, this was probably our second favorite attraction in Peru (Machu/Huayna Picchu #1), and gives a great feeling of going beyond the typical tourist traps.One note: the "path" is not well-defined. Just stay on the high side of the mines and work your way across the top. There are miners there, but they will usually just ignore you or say "bienvenidos." If you have poor balance or a severe fear of heights, you may not enjoy this attraction.

A must see. We were very impressed with the Salt Mines of Maras. We have visited the World Famous Salt Mines in Krakow, Poland, and liked these just as much (even though the two mines are so different).This trip combines very easily with a trip to Moray and/or Chinchero.There is a lady that sells hand-woven corn silk baskets at the mines, as well as a pleasent young man who roasts pumpkin seeds with salt.

A true surprise. I knew very little about this place before going there - it came with the package. The visit took place in the afternoon, and the sight of the salt ponds in the sunset was an unexpected delightful surprise! The sight from above was absolutely amazing! Not just the view was amazing either. When you walk around the ponds you will be amazed about the engineering skills of the creators, the amount of ponds and the atmosphere. Take the detour to this place - it will not disappoint you!

Beautiful when the sun sets!. I went to Salinas this year and I have to say that the view was quite stunning!At Salinas, one simply walks along the salt pools all the way down to the Sacred Valley. I would recommend going in the late afternoon so that one can see the sun set on the valley in the distance while walking down alongside the pools.While Salinas is stunning, it is a little inconvenient to get there. Apart from walking (a long, long distance), the only way to get to Salinas is by taxi. Some drivers offer to drive to both moray and Salinas, it's definitely worth it if you carpool with other tourists. The way I got to Salinas was by taking a bus from from Urubamba to Maras, and then taking a cab to Salinas via Moray. After seeing Salinas, I walked to the main highway to take a bus back to Urubamba.A relatively cheap excursion!

Visit this unusual place!. During our visit to Cuzco, instead of doing the standard Sacred Valley tour, we decided to do a private tour with a guide to visit non- standard sites in the SV. Salinas de Maras is definitely something way unusual and worth a visit. The salt petres are terraced out on the mountain slope with an incredible channel irrigatory system used to divert water and flood the petres alternately. You also get to see people doing the actual hard work needed to obtain the salt. The white, salt covered terraced slopes are an incredibly sight, one that you cannot probably see elsewhere. Give yourself about 30-45 minutes to visit the site. Definitely recommended.

Take It with a Grain of Salt. We are visiting as much of the area as possible, so imgine our suprise as we come around the bend, and see all these salt pans from the top (where the salt leeches from the mountain) down into the canyon to the Urubamba River. It was nice to get the history about this area, and how the salt has flowed for hundreds of years. There is a nice gift shop, with salt for purchase too. A young girl, whose momma works in the gift shop let me take her picture. It was wonderful both coming and going, we got to see men coming in with their harvests on the backs of mules, and women walking their sheep into the plains.
